Watch for Gladiator to win oscars for cinematography, costuming, and supporting actor. (Russell Crowe will probably not be nominated, because the academy is notorious for snubbing the "hero" of action films.  Just take my advice, if you like any movies, and even if you don't, see Gladiator.  It's worth it.

Review title: Russell Crowe should have passed this one up!
Review_body: Slow, dark & dreary.  Action too gory.  Battle scenes too fast-paced with jerky camera--thought I was watching war movies while on acid!Spartacus on A&E Biography was much more interesting and entertaining.

Review title: As good as Braveheart, but cooler.
Review_body: When I saw the first trailer for Gladiator(around superbowl time), I thought about how much potential for greatness this film could possess. In a genre that has been ignored for thirty years, it's refreshing to see a movie that will no doubt be a catalyst for a surge of new epics. Russel Crowe = bad hombre. It's one thing to see a hero who displays excellent prowess with a gun - like the protagonists we love from westerns and cop movies; it's something altogether different to see a warrior slay his enemies with primitive weapons like swords, spears, and morning stars. I won't go into detail, but the battles in this movie are phenomenal. One last element of Gladiator that makes it a different type of film than Braveheart is the computer generated imaging that makes the ancient Rome real and possible for the movie. Also, this movie will probably not win Oscars like Braveheart because people viewed Braveheart as one man's(Mel Gibson) vision.You can't not like this movie.

Gladiator was a great film.  Although the beginning was a bit boring the middle and end were great.  An excellent story of the Roman Empire and the way things were back in that time.  Russell Crowe played an excellent role in the must see film of the month.  A HERO WILL RISE!!

Review title: Gripping from first to last fight
Review_body: Ridley Scott has certainly banished the demons of White Squall and GI Jane with this fantastic offering. Crowe is superb as the determined Maximus, but he is matched by fight choreography and the rich CG visuals of Rome at its height. The opening battle sequence betters anything in Braveheart, although the slow motion was overused. The standout feature of the film was the depiction of Rome; from the streets, to the emperial palace to the Colloseum. It equalls anything presented in Bladerunner or one of Lucas' offerings (with the use of CG birds being on a par with the Ewoks)This is the film of the year. It does not deserve the tag "event film" as it is not a shody piece of work held together by some shiny computer code but a heart-pumping, sword-swinging, sweat and blood soaked masterpiece with superb visuals, intellegent script and flawless performances from the leads.see it, then put aside another 3 hours to see it again

"Gladiator" exceeded my wildest expectations, and my expectations were very very high.  Ridley Scott's career has  been a little inconsistent, but when this guy's on-target, the results are impressive to behold.  Witness "Alien".  Witness "Blade Runner".  Now witness "Gladiator".  A simple story, beautifully told.  Unforgettable scenes of gladitorial combat.  Eye-popping visualizations of ancient Rome.  Russell Crowe makes a great hero, Jaoquin Phoenix a terrific villain.  The whole cast is superb.  "Spartacus" ain't got nothing on "Gladiator"  I can't wait to see it again...

Review title: A monumental hero-story that offers nothing new
Review_body: The roman scenery excluded, I´ve seen this film a hundred times. It has the usual ingredients of action, betrayal, heroic return and of course some sort of victory. This film is great judged from visual and sound perspectives, but the story is rather weak which makes this movie predictable and hard to have "feelings for".I categorize this movie as "American", because it is build according to a classical recipe designed to let the whole range of feelings touch the audience. Nothing is spared in effects and the music hammers on as our hero makes his entry, why does it always have to be so "monumental"? If played in modern time the camera should have altered between a crying audience and the american flag while playing the national anthem. I can´t stand those scenes.Despite the negativism, Russell Crowe plays his hero well and the 150 minutes passes quickly. Connie Nielsen leaves a deep impression, which cannot be said of Joaquin Phoenix´s performance as Ceasar. It is a pleasure to see the historic background of Rome, and that is this movies greatest advantage.

I can't believe how well this movie was made.  It has great acting, plot, and special effects.  I was looking forward to this movie for a long time and it does not disappoint.Some may be thrown off by the fact that the movie spends about an hour on plot before actually getting to the gladitorial combat, but you do get a nice battle scene as well as.....well, I don't want to ruin it for anyone.I've only met one person who didn't like this movie.  He said that it was too long.  Of course, he doesn't really like movies at all anyway.  I hear about people complaining about how long it was.  They should've expected it. I found it to be a lot shorter than I thought it would be.  When you consider how long Spartacus was, this movie is much shorter.I can't believe that people can hate such a wonderful film.  I admit that the directing seemed a bit annoying at times, but that's just because I don't care much for the small bit of "artsie" stuff they threw in there. Overall, this is one fantastic movie.  However, I must say that I saw a lot of people taking eight year-olds to see this film.  Don't do that!  This is a gory movie!

Oh my! I was really speechless when I saw this movie... great pictures, I've hardly ever seen anything like that. The music is perfectly matched too and the plot is fascinating... if you haven't seen this one, go see it!!

Review title: An epic for the 21st Century, visually stunning and absolutely engaging.
Review_body: Being lucky enough to get a pass to a preview of this film I was pleasantly surprised. I thought it would be good, but I had no idea. It was great. Russell Crowe plays Maximus, the great Roman general and right hand man to Roman emperor Marcus Aurelius. As well written as the film was, Crowe delivers an excellent performance as Maximus, making it nearly impossible to imagine anyone else in the role. Joaquin Phoenix delivers a great performance himself playing Aurelius' son Commodus who assumes the role of emperor after his father's death in an underhanded manner. Phoenix's portrayal punctuates Commodus' despicable demeanor. This film transports you to the era in the theater. It's totally engaging and shot beautifully. I really loved this film and I will gladly fork over my 8 bucks when it's released. Gladiator appears to be the first great Epic of the 2000's.

Gladiator is a good epic movie.  The plot is solid, the acting is good, and the action is fierce.  However as I watched the movie I kept thinking to myself, this sure is a lot like Braveheart.  From the action scenes to the storyline alot of this movie is taken from epics that came before it. Although it's good and it takes a new twist on some of the same ideas.  I couldn't help but think about how I saw this 5 years ago with people in kilts.  And Braveheart's breathtaking battle scenes are still superior. Russell Crowe's performance does stand out, and the Roman setting is nice. Overall Gladiator is a good movie, but not original enough to be great.

Review title: Ridley, Ridley, what have you done?
Review_body: This movie is one of the worst I've ever been forced to watch. I mean, I came out of the cinema and wondered why the sun wasn't already up. I thought it must have been at least 8 hours long. It's just so BORING! When you think about it, what happens in this movie? Tough guy kills some dudes. Tough guy talks about honour with old guy. Mean guy kills old guy. Tough guy kills some other dudes. Mean guy talks about honor with girl. Tough guy weeps for his family. Tough guy talks about honor with black guy, then kills some dudes. (Repeat last three lines until bored, and then some more). If they would have just stuck to the killing part, then it would have been a mediocre action film. But no, they had to add "depth" (=lots of "philosophical" (=clicheed) truisms, with about 30 seconds of pauses/reaction shots between sentences). Actually, the screenwriter packed the script with so many clichees he actually only missed one: Flavius (the nephew of the mean guy) is not Maximus's son. Bummer. I thought I knew everything that would happen after the first quarter of an hour.O.K. The good points: The first three fights or so ARE compelling (the other 20 or so cease to be). Ancient Rome never looked so real (Shame about the rest of the movie). The actors can act (their roles are just so clicheed the creators could have done with Muppets).One final question : Does Crowe really go from Germania to Spain in one day (Some horse that must be...), and from Spain to North Africa in another two? In a CART? I Refuse to have seen that. I must have fallen asleep for a few hours. It's possible with this movie. Zero stars.

Review title: A grand movie that can only be considered as a "must see".
Review_body: From the grand battle at the beginning to the final fight at the end, there are 2 1/2 hours of glamorous screenplay and some of the best acting to be seen this year. Russell Crowe as Maximus, Connie Nielson as Lucilla, Oliver Reed as Proximo, Richard Harris as Marcus Aurelius, and a host of other supporting actors.And the top actors are needed as this is a screenplay written by a team, and it lacks a unified vision. Small production errors, like Lucilla wearing a bra, detract from the authenticity. Will the audience care? When character arcs reverse without cause, will anyone notice? There is so much action, and even a weepy scene at the end, perhaps they will not care.Well worth seeing for what is good, but not for people with faint hearts. This is an action movie, and the violence is sometimes overwhelming, and the cinematic style taken too far. But worthy of a viewing all the same.

Review title: Mingling history with fiction in an entertaining, if gory, way
Review_body: The Roman Empire was not yet in decline when Marcus Aurelius died, according to historical accounts, from plague somewhere near modern Vienna. His son Commodus became Caesar at age 19. This screenplay accurately depicts Roman soldiers in combat. However, it takes liberties with history, introducing Maximus, the protagonist and main character of "Gladiator," who escapes death ordered by Commodus.As a whole, this film is highly entertaining and well-done.

I'd been looking forward to seeing Gladiator, since reading a review in the TIME praising it to the skies. I was disappointed - the story did not touch my heart. I think "BraveHeart" had a much better story and characters. I did not feel much empathy for the characters and the love story left me cold. The endless chit chat between the "Roman" characters was so boring with the dialogues utterly ordinary. The special effects were ok, but nothing extraordinary. Similar melodramatic stories have been seen by me ( as I from India) millions of times before. Wife, sister, parents, brother or son murdered and the hero taking his revenge. I would advise others who are praising the movies to the skies to start watching Indian movies. They will really lap it up. I also found the ending a big let down. The climax was so meek !! And I here I was expecting a big showdown between the the armies of the rebels and the emperor. Russel Crowe has acted well, but I believe any of our homegrown Indian superstars can give him a run for money in the melodramatic and action sequences. I found Joaquim Phoenix and the lady awful. The Gladiator isn't awful, but it's not particularly memorable either. You may want to see it to satisfy your curiosity, but not if you're concerned with getting value for your money.Arvind

I had high hopes for "Gladiator."  This is the first Roman epic to appear in years (not counting the recently released "Titus," as it is more Elizabethan than Roman), and with the promise of Russell Crowe and a large budget, I thought it would be a wonderful way to spend a Saturday afternoon. Though Crowe does deliver a fine performance, this film is crippled by a ridiculous script, delivering thinly drawn supporting characters and perhaps the worst ending since last year's "Pushing Tin." I admit, many of the gladitorial combats are amazing to watch, but they simply cannot support the story.  As far as accuracy to Roman customs and history goes, the filmmakers succeed in their portrayal of Roman death games as being widely varied: we see games involving animals, chained gladiator pairs, and battle reenactments ("the Battle of Carthage" scene in "Gladiator" is quite powerful and darkly comic), yet, they make the standard mistake of the "thumbs up/thumbs down" issue in the Roman arena.  When the crowd wanted an emperor, or other game sponsor, in Rome to allow an athlete to live, they raised their hands, not their thumbs, to indicate a show of mercy.  I admit, this is a minor point, but one could imagine that the filmmakers might have done a little more homework on such issues. Incidentally, there are numerous readable and engaging scholarly works on the subject of the Roman games, Roland Auguet's 1972 "Cruelty and Civilization" in particular.  "Gladiator" contains other glaring historical inconsistencies, but I dare not mention them for fear of spoiling the ending.If you're craving a Roman epic, I would suggest skipping "Gladiator" in favor of Stanley Kubrick's 1960 "Spartacus," an occasionally flawed, yet much superior film.

Plenty of other folks here have written good reviews about the acting/directing in this film, but I feel a need to whinge.I went to see this film with high hopes and for the most part I was far from disappointed but. there were I feel, failures.The much vaunted special effects were indeed impressive and there were scenes that are truly awesome. However for me the scenes that least required special effects i.e. the fight sequences were ruined by the addition of a bizarre blurring / juddering effect that rendered them unintelligible. Considering it is a film about gladiators you really would expect to be able to see what was going on, especially in the fights.In a sci-fi the effects can be up-front, in a film about gladiators the special effects should be invisible.There that's my whinging over. 7/10.

Well this movie does have a few problems with it but its a great epic. Scott captures that sense of awe with Gladiator. The locations, sets, effects, extras, costumes, and action all leads to a huge epic.The plot is fairly standard stuff. The ruler is killed by his son who wants to rule Rome.The ruler he wanted to follow him is imprisoned by the son. Son kills the rulers picks loved ones and man get angry...and what not. Its the good old revenge tale but told as an epic. The acting is good especially Crowe as Maximus.The film is visually very cool. From Rome to the fight scenes all well done. The worst scene is the begining battle. Its ruined because it was filmed in the dark, its edited to fast so you cant see whats happening, and the camera doesnt keep still. Also the ending is rather anti climatic. It leads you to believe that there is going to be a huge battle in Rome but alsa all we get is the hero and the villain dueling it out in the Colussem.Another problem that is too long. It could have a used another brawl or two its seems much longer then 2 hours and 30 mins. I never was really interested in epics of battle but i really enjoyed this one.Its got well done action and good acting thats leads to a well worth trip to the theater7 out of 10

Though not unique in plot, the movie is very well done.  Most powerful for me was Russell Crowe's portrayal of Maximus.  I fully believed in Maximus as noble and honorable and would have fought with him.  It is a hard role to do so well.  The movie was gorgeous to watch, Ridley Scott crafted some very memorable scenes.

I knew this movie was incredibly hyped, and I knew it was going to live up to its initial buzz.  It definitely did, but I would have to say I am biased to this historical period.  However, in comparison to Spartacus and Ben-Hur I think this is a better movie - that's just my opinion.  I came in expecting a lot more Gladiator action, but was a tad disappointed by how much I got.  However the action scenes that were present were spectacular and brutally violent.  The plot drags a bit, but it can be overlooked because of Russell Crowe - he holds it all together.  Definitely a must see.

No, the movie was not horrible. In fact, the movie itself was excellent. The music was mood-setting, the scenery exceptional, the graphics realistic, the storyline interesting and the cast outstanding.  Russell Crowe plays a general captured and sold as a gladiator after almost being killed by the late emperors selfish son. What was so horrible was the fact that killing for sport (The occupation of gladiators) was an all too real thing in ancient Rome. The graphic battle scenes in the coliseum depict the horror of what actually happened. This film is definitely one to be viewed in theater for full appreciation of sight and sound. Though not recommended for those with weak stomachs, this 2 1/2 hr movie will keep you into it from beginning to end.

This movie is a one of a kind piece of film. To watch it is like enjoying an independant movie with a big hollywood budget. Scott pulled out all the stops to make this one spectacular movie. I had not seen such excellent camera work since "Pulp Fiction." The scenes made you feel like you were right there in the stadium watching the spectacle. Scott also brought in many of the themes that have been left out of other roman based projects. Like the incestual tendencies of the latter Ceasars. The fans showering thier favorite gladiators with rose pedals. Slave camps, and the worldliness of ROME. You could walk down the streets of Rome and see people from all over the empire.
One of the best movies I've ever seen.Nice acting of Russell Crowe - he absolutely deserved the Oscar!Makes you feel you're part of battle - pretty scary and realistic.

This 2 hour 33 minute film was absolutely spectacular! Crowe and Phoenix were excellent actors in this film. The film was filled with tons of action and suspense, and yet, it kept a good plot through the whole movie. The opening scene started with a bang and kept your interest throughout the whole film. However, if you didn't like the graphic violence in 'Saving Private Ryan', this film isn't for you. This is a definite nominee for Best Picture 2000. A must see!

Gladiator seems to me the first good film of the year 2000. Many of the people I know have compared it to be better than Braveheart. I do not agree although I feel that Gladiator is up in that league of films. It has a great story although not historically accurate. People get into the characters and there is some very good acting here. The only complaint I have of this film is that of the camera views at certain times. They can be extremely close and quick which makes it hard to see what has happened. This is true in many of the action scenes. Still I was amazed by the action and the beauty of the many scenes. This film is very good. Go see it in theater if you can.

Review title: A triumphal walk down Main Street, Rome.
Review_body: Raw, realistic, gripping, atmospheric.  Great performances from the cast are enhanced by terrific special effects.  The (present day) ruins of ancient Rome are transformed, and we find ourselves in a majestic city built on a grand scale.  These images may be computer generated, but it's impossible to see the joins!Effects without substance would not be enough, however, but "Gladiator" has that as well - in abundance!  The Cast have really excelled themselves with a great script - there isn't a weak performance to be found.From Russell Crowe to Oliver Reed no one disappoints.Perhaps in view of his untimely death, Oliver deserves a special mention - talk about going out on a high!A movie not to be missed!

Review title: Now what it is cracked up to be
Review_body: Inaccurate and fake are all I can think of when I think about Gladiator. If you want to see a great Ridley Scott movie, rent Alien or Blade Runner. And if you want to see good acting from Russell Crowe, see him flex his muscles in L.A. Confidential.  Gladiator is just another big dumb movie that passes as an intelligent one.  No offense to Crowe(I really loved The Insider), but he's no Mel Gibson and Braveheart, with all it's weaknesses, is so much better than the computer-generated Gladiator.

This movie has nothing to do with history, is totally unrealistic and is packed with amazing action. In other words, it's exactly the usual kind of movie Hollywood has been producing for ages. It's not different from that silly "Hercules Vs. Zorro" movies that Titanus produced 40 years ago. Such a pity: Scott was my favorite director.

After seeing the ad for Gladiator, and realizing that Russell Crowe was the main character, I was determined to see it. His portrayal of Bud White was what made LA Confidential transcend to another level. Finding out that Ridley Scott was the director made it 100% certain that this was a film not to be missed.From the opening of the film, with the wheat blowing softly, leading up to a battle that combined the frenetic camera work similar to Private Ryan mixed with the brutality of Braveheart all set to Hans Zimmer's great score, I was hooked.Here is a film that includes all the pre-requisites of being a hit. Superb acting from all the leads (Joaquin Phoenix - I didn't realize he could act that well!?) Richard Harris as the elderly Caesar, the late Oliver Reed, and Djimon Hounsou all did superb jobs. What MADE this film what it was though, was Crowe's performance as the betrayed General Maximus.The sheer emotion and depth that Crowe brought to what could have been a cardboard replica of a historical figure proves with no doubt that he is now one of the top actors in Hollywood.The vulnerability mixed with the intensity, with the ever underlying thirst for revenge drives the character and subsequently the film. It is doubtful one will see a better performance than the scene where Maximus discovers his family killed.
With a lavish set design, aided by stunning CGI work, the viewer feels literally immersed in the world of old Rome. The battles (the best one being the Barbarian Horde) are staged elaborately, and truly evoke the quality of what they must have been like.This movie is similar in some ways to 1995's Braveheart, yet differentiates itself enough to be truly original. It is a strong possibility that come March, Ridley Scott could be standing at the podium holding Oscar. Of all the films that have come out in the past year, this is one that NOBODY should miss!

Review title: a real experience - especially the music
Review_body: I must say, that at first when I left the cinema I was not that excited about this movie. More interesting was, that it was the music that I still had in mind. But after a night to reflect over this movie, I have to say, that it was one of the best movies I have ever seen. A great plot, and although it is running about 2 and a half hours, it is never boring. Go and see it for yourself - I will do so again, too!

Gladiator has everything.  Amazing visuals, superb fight-scenes, and a strong plot with a fierce revenge angle.The first part of the movie is quite slow, but concentrates on building backgrounds for the various characters.  The movie really takes off when Maximus begins his Gladiator career, the action scenes are similar to Saving Private Ryan (like Gladiator, a film that also moved me) as the pace is frenetic and very 'in your face'.Check out the scene where the Gladiators first enter the Coliseum arena in Rome, wow, you actually felt like you were there.  During the fights you will be on the edge of your seat, willing the 'good guys on'.  Apart from the action, there is a healthy dose of drama, which didn't do much for me. However, this does balance the movie quite well, but after seeing the fight scenes you just want to see more action!The ending is predictable, but quite powerful, it really does go for the heart strings, I was moved, and that's no easy thing.  The best movie I have seen in ages, Star Wars TPM had the visuals but not the story, check Gladiator out, you won't regret it!

Review title: a great tale and vision but not flawless
Review_body: Ridley Scott has always encountered us with other worlds, he likes to create his arena from scratch, in this case the arena is the ancient roman empire, but sadly it is inhabited by more virtual people then toy story. It is a great loss that this great tale and well acted story suffers from this modern desease called cgi, the time of great masses of extra's (real people seems to be gone. now we have to asume that those awkward moving people are real, the movie suffers from it! And why does these days everybody has to have a deathwish be reunited with their family in the afterlife (startrek generations had it, end of days had it and so does gladiator) it makes it look a little bit rediculous. but the rest of this movie is so impressive that i'm still giving it an 8.

I went into this film with somewhat low expectations.  I don't consider myself a real fan of this genre.  My first thought upon seeing the trailer was "Spartacus."  After more research, I was concerned this might be a cheap Braveheart-esqe ripoff.  I was wrong in both cases.  This movie is in a category all to itself, and I loved every bit of it.  I haven't experienced a film like this in quite some time ... Gotta go with a "Thumbs Up" in my book.  I thought that Ridley Scott did a heckuva job keeping this film moving for the course of 3 hours.  I also would say that Russell Crowe is quickly becoming one of the better actors in the business today.  His presence on the screen carried several of the movies key scenes.  I felt that the plot of the movie was easy to follow, almost cookie-cutter like in that respect, but there were enough turns and twists to keep me satisfied through the course of the film.  The effects flat out rock, I was particularly impressed with the opening sequence.  This is one that you want to go see again and again.

Review title: It's LONG, but Russell Crowe is AWESOME
Review_body: It's long. What more needs to be said. You FEEEeeeEEelll The length of this movie and there's nothing you can do about it. Thank God for Russell Crowe or else I would've walked right out. It's actually beautifully shot and the costumes are exquisite. I've always been a sucker for armor. It's got blood and it's got war. It's got slightly interesting sub-plots and everyone in the movie is beautiful. I have to say, I was slightly impressed by the artsiness of "dream sequences" and the unashamed blood bath. But, too long, too draggy and there's nothing they could do about it. It had it's moment and it's memory but I'd never see it again. It's definitely a renter -- but it would be best if you had a wide-screen televison to enjoy the beauty of the filming itself. Defintely NOT an oscar contender. But like I said, Russell Crowe is IN the Colosium (in the house!)

while I do not possess the technical expertise of some of the commentors, I am an avid movie fan familiar with R. Scott. He and RC are the reasons I went to see this film. There are indeed many technical and logistical weaknesses but I believe RC's performance will carry it to a place in movie phenomenon history. The success seems to be a combination of excellent casting and artistic ability. I applaud the other characters as well. Because they are a human endeavor, I can think of no 'perfect' film. This one does what films are supposed to do, it captures the majority of the audience who sees it, touches a sensitive place in their psyche and leaves them with a fond remembrance.

Review title: A Great Way to Bring Rome Back to the Big Screen
Review_body: If you haven't seen Gladiator, you may be missing out on one of the best of the Summer Movies.  This film has a real plot, and characters that you'll both love and hate.  Every character was interesting, the cinematography brings back images of Saving Private Ryan and Braveheart, and the musical score compliments the visuals perfectly.In the same year that brought Battlefield Earth to the big screen, it is a relief to see a smart, well thought of, big budget epic film do well at the box office.

This film is one great piece of entertainment.  If you enter the cinema with this in mind, you'll have a great time.  The story is an oldie but a goodie - good guy beats bad guy.  The actors are supreme.  What more can I say about Russell Crowe that has not already been said here.  He's a gem of an actor whose ability transcends the sometimes weak script.  He manages to carry his dialogue and he is a credit to his profession.  Joaquin Phoenix does well for someone used to playing soft urban roles, Oliver Reed gives the performance of his life (except of course in 'Oliver' in which I think he is an absolute genius).  Yes its gory, yes its cheesy at times, but wow what a piece of entertainment. The music is sensational and the action engaging.  A must see at the cinema.  Those who wait for video could well be disappointed.

Review title: This film MUST be seen on a big screen.
Review_body: Don't kid yourself that you can wait until the video comes out to see this movie. Gladiator cries out to be seen on a big screen. Scott's talent for stunning visuals is used to the full here.

Review title: A Spectacle worthy of classic Hollywood
Review_body: Yes, my boyfriend complained that it was too much like Braveheart, but that's only on a superficial comparison.  Wow, I can't begin to explain what a great film this was.  It managed to captivate and excite the entire time. There was humor and great pathos and insane emperors and the noble warrior with a heart of gold.  All the things that MIGHT have added up to a cheezy overblown Hollywood machine if the actors weren't so fabulous.  Oliver Reed can be proud of his final performance, one of the best of his career. Finally Russell Crowe captures a starring role where he can let his fine acting talent shine while showcasing those gorgeous looks of his.  And Joaquin Phoenix makes you both hate and feel a modicum of pity for the tortured and malicious young emperor.  It's a flick that can appeal to guys and girls (if the girls can stomach the quick cuts of violence and gore) and DEFINITELY DEFINITELY go see it!  the visuals alone of the Roman colosseum, the tigers, and the gladiating sequences are worth the admission.

Review title: Best Movie I've seen this year.....
Review_body: Yes, it is gory and violent.  But it is old fashioned in the way it makes you feel like you want to stand up and cheer for the hero. Russell Crowe is great!  I wish it could have ended differently, but I guess that was the way it had to end. The only part I didn't like was the opening slow motion battle scene. I think the director got carried away with that.  Go see it. I gave it a 10.

Based on the director and the cast, I was expecting a good action movie, great acting, and a derivative story about our times. As an action movie, it wasn't bad, but not as good as I'd hoped, the acting was fantastic all round (especially Joaquin Phoenix), but I was amazed and gratified that it was mostly a movie about *Roman* themes, not modern ones. It looks to me like the writer understood the Roman concept of Virtue, knew about Roman religion and Stoic philosophy, and Marcus Aurelius' "Meditations".On the downside, there were a lot of minor anachronisms and inaccuracies:1. Stirrups hadn't been invented yet. 2. The Romans used "Greek Fire", not Napalm, and they did not use it much as field artillery. 3. The Romans generally did not use cavalry as a decisive military arm in this period, and certainly not against the germans, who had more and better cavalry. 4. Did the Romans have tigers?! 5. If they did, the tigers would have had elementary big cat training. At one point a tiger decides to chew on Russell Crowe's armor instead of deliver the Killing Bite, or just break his neck with its paw.

I found this movie to be great.  It was spectacular acting, and believable for that period of time.  I was glad that the movie had a story line and was not just all blood and death.  Russell Crowe was an excellent choice for the character of Maximus and should be commended on his acting.  Also the director did a fine job in making the movie and should also be commended. It is definetly worth owning or going to see in the cinema.

I just want to say that this movie did not deserve the oscar for best actor or for best picture.  I just don't understand it.  It seems like the Academy Awards aren't the best at picking who and what deserves it, just like Julia Roberts winning over Ellen Burstyn.  All she did was act pissed off and wear revealing clothes.  Many actresses could've done that.Anyway, this movie is just a bigger budget for a Jean Claude Van Damme movie.  A tough guy's family gets hurt, and he goes out for revenge, but along the way he gets tortured and hurt yet kicks all their butts.  That pretty much sums it up...

This movie one more time shows that Americans doesn't know and even doesn't want to know the history besieds their own. Does anyone really thinks that soldiers in Rome army applied as 'sir' to their chief. Or it was made just for Americans to understand it easier? And why Maximus is General. What's the rank of Rome army? Second, the story is a fake. There really was such emperor as Commodius, but he wasn't killed on the stadium. Third, does anyone thinks that the emperor, wishing to kill somebody will stop if the folk love that person? The screenplay is written very bad. All the dialogues are separated from each other and sometimes I couldn't understand what was the purpose of one or another dialogue.

I wanted to like this movie.  It got good reviews, it was set in Rome, it seemed like it had everything going for it.But, unfortunately, such was not to be the case.This movie was, quite simply, bad.The plot is pathetic.  It's basically a nonsensical mish-mash of supposedly momentous events, padding up the time between Russell Crowe brutally slaughtering his opponents in various inventive and completely unbelievable ways (yes, really, those Roman swords did chop through bone like it was tissue paper, I'll believe that.)The action is, for the most part, just a celebration of the power of the filmmaker to create violence even more brutal (and at the same time, more antiseptic - lots of blood, lots of cutting, no guts) than reality.  The true core of the movie isn't character, plot, or even Russell Crowe showing off a few muscles.  It's amputated limbs, heads, torsos.  The rest of the film is just a pathetic shell around numerous scenes whose only purpose is a celebration of hollywood's antiseptic version of the macabre.  Blood, dirt, death.  But no guts.The special effects are poor.  A few shots of Rome are attempted, but they look like nothing more than CGI drawings with some legions pasted on top. Even the best attempt, an aerial flyover attempting to portray the daily life of a bustling city, is just a quick glance from a strangled camera angle, and gives the impression more of a robotic ant farm than a great, bustling city of the ancient world.Perhaps, one might think, the fight scenes fare better.  After all, they are the only reason for the movie's existence.  But they don't.  Despite being patently unbelievable and absurd, they also manage to be rather poorly shot and boring.  There's never any real vitality to them.  Somehow, Ridley Scott has managed to turn human brutality into something that looks like nothing more than a special effect, and a poor one at that.  The video jerks in a strange, stop-motion filming effect that makes each fight look like it was done in claymation, while the arena, the stadium, the crowd all look somehow smaller than life, phony, unreal.Don't bother.

Review title: cool action for the big screen...
Review_body: definitely a big screen viewer...the fight scenes were excellent...the drama was a little cheezy but overall the film was worthwhile...kind of a braveheart type story but you felt more for william wallace than you did maximus...

Amazing stuff here. When I first saw it, I was totally amazed at what this film accomplished. The story itself was totally awesome, and the manner in which it was done was truly incredible. EVERY line in the movie had purpose and was acted out in a truly remarkable way. I LOVE THIS FILM! I actually saw it twice in 3 days and wanted to see it again. I'm anxious to purchase it when it is released because it is that DAMN good. Trust me, YOU DO NOT WANT TO MISS THIS INCREDIBLE MOVIE-GOING EXPERIENCE. The fighting scenes, the musical score, the computer graphics (i.e. backgrounds) are all top-notch and it is an unforgettable film. Gladiator is truly film-making at its best.

Review title: How could this win best picture!!!??
Review_body: How is it that a movie with such bad acting, predictable plot outlines and poor writing could win best picture? This movie made myself and my friends all incredibly restless in the theatre and count the minutes until it was over. Yes i am a chick, but i was accompanied by a group of 5 straight male friends, and all of us thought that there was not enough action and too much cheese. Sure rent the movie, and like it even, (parts of it that is...), but vote it best picture? Come on now!

Seeing this film immediately brought back the feelings I had when I first saw Braveheart. On further examination I found this story much more compelling and complex. The gore content is tastefully done and while brutal it serves it's purpose and is not the focus but rather the motivation for the story.The acting is excellent, Russell Crowe played the role of Gladiator with the necessary reserve, angst and passion needed. Joaquin Phoenix as the Emperor's son was truly distasteful. I loathed his character by the end of the movie more than most characters I can call to mind. Cinematically beautiful, musically enchanting. Would love to see this on DVD, because on VHS with surround sound it was fabulous.

Review title: THE MOST OVERRATED MOVIE IN HISTORY!
Review_body: This movie is a simpleton's epic.  The storyline doesn't pass the laugh test.  Here's the outline (I would warn of SPOILERS, but this thing is already ROTTEN):1) After a great victory in GERMANY, a Heroic Roman general (Russell Crowe) and 100-year-old Roman Emperor with BOTH FEET in the grave (a pathetic-looking Richard Harris) plot to bring back the REPUBLIC to Rome.2) The Emperor's EVIL -- that's E-V-I-L -- and effeminate son (a WAY-OVER-THE-TOP Joaquin Phoenix) gets p***ed when daddy doesn't want to give him supreme power,finishes pushing pops into the grave, attempts the kill the good general, but just wipes out his family a thousand miles in SPAIN instead.3) Just after he discovers his wife and kid are TOAST, the grief-stricken good general is conveniently abducted by slavers to AFRICA, where he becomes THE GREATEST GLADIATOR EVER!, killing off dozens of opponents with each rippled bicep and impressing his teacher, played by Oliver Reed (who played with similar scene-chewing bravado in his prime).4) The good general goes back to ROME, where he wipes out legions in the Colisseum simply by ripping off his shirt to show his MIGHTY PECTORALS! Heads and arms and legs and lots of bloody parts fly all over in the MOST RIDICULOUS GLADITORIAL FIGHTS EVER!  The EVIL SON, who is now the E-V-I-L EMPEROR quakes in effeminate fear of this MIGHTY GLADIATOR, who is now the MOST POPULAR MAN IN ROME!  He suggests incest to his comely sister (Connie Nielsen), but -- strangely -- she prefers the SHIRTLESS GLADIATOR GENERAL, who promises to bring REPUBLICAN freedom to all ROME.5) The E-V-I-L EMPEROR lops off the heads of all the free-thinking Republican Senators and fatally backstabs the CHESTY GLADIATOR.  He jumps into the ARENA himself to finish him off, but our HAIRY HERO manages to end the E-V-I-L ONE's misery, and our own.Russell Crowe has a primordial presence which obviously strongly appeals to both male and female audiences, but this movie is a joke.  It says a lot when the best performance turned in was by the Oliver Reed, who died during the shooting and had a few of his scenes filled with Oliver's face superimposed by computer over an anonymous actor.The movie also looks terrible with a computer-generated Colisseum which looks totally plastic and a darkness in most of the scenes that is near impenetrable, except, of course, in the ludicrous gladitorial scenes in which every eviscerating moment is in bright sunshine.This movie is Spartacus and Ben Hur for the plot-challenged, character-challenged, nano-second-attention-spanned modern audiences.  An Eviscerated Epic.

Review title: USE YOUR MIND, NOT YOUR GLANDS: WATCH "I, CLAUDIUS" INSTEAD!
Review_body: The biggest single indictment of this disatrous excuse for an epic is that the one truly great actor in the movie, Derek Jacobi, is (like Richard Harris and Oliver Reed) brought in to bring a whiff of authentic class (to hide the other whiffs), and, like the others, is quickly snuffed.  Jacobi, of course, was the absolutely brilliant star of the probably the greatest Roman epic ever, I, CLAUDIUS.  That scintillating 13-hour classic doesn't have a single boring or predictable moment (unlike this mess) and is all characterization and plotting, not spectacle, the exact opposite of this movie, which uses character stereotypes and a ludicrous storyline that wouldn't pass the cartoon test.  Half the acting is Russell Crowe swearing revenge and grimacing as he flexes his pectorals.  Even the spectacle here is MUDDY and BLOODY.  If you want to be like the Romans and enjoy the sight of people being disemboweled and torn limb from limb, then by all means check this out.  But, please, watch one of the classics instead and you'll quickly dump this pretender.

Despite what the critics say I think that this is a great movie and maybe not film wise,but entertainment wise.It's a movie that every boy dreams about and I think that every boy or man should watch.Gladiator is  a great movie for entertainment and is a ten in my book of favorite's.

Review title: Perfect exteriors, great actors, but poor screenplay
Review_body: I think that this movie could be one of my favorites, but it has really poor story. It is still the same, good guy, bad guy, pretty woman and some empire between them. Very good special effects but the battle scenes were very fast. What i missed was also some sort of idea, that i could remember longer that one day as it was for example in Besson`s Messenger. The end of the movie recall me antic tragedies, but in some forcible way. But what i really like in this movie was acting of Joaqin Phoenix, he was better than Crowe. And who doesn´t like Connie Nielsen is either gay or have not seen The Devil`s advocate. So it is good to see it, but it is not a revolution.

This movie undoubtedly works on a frivolous, popcorn munching level.  It seldom penetrates through the barrier that would make it a true classic with a resonant theme.  I came out thinking it was nothing more than Death Wish B.C.It is brilliant technically with astonishing visuals, and it is competently directed for such a massive exercise.  The performances are good too, adding a contemporary dimension.  Crowe is commanding as are each of the supporting players.  I do not think they will rate the same way 20 years from now they will get lost in the extravagence of the film.Gladiator probably ranks so high this year(2000) because everything else is pap.  As usual there are stronger films in the indie and foreign circles, but if the mainstream dominates this could very well be the best picture......depressing!

Review title: A movie that shows the true cinema
Review_body: The movie has a gold cast. The effects are quite good for the time it was made. An incredible soundtrack. The only problem is that it became too long.

This is a great movie is every respect. It was the Best Picture by far. Russell Crowe's performance was superb. Ridley Scott and Joaquin Phoenix were robbed in a major way as far as the academy awards go.  The only weak spot is the little boy (bad casting on that part).I have been reading the many comments written about this movie. I am not surprised that those of you who are obviously liberals do not appreciate the message of "Strength and Honor". Words like "Freedom" frighten you because you know that patriotism isn't far behind.

Review title: More than an action film, more than an historical spectacle.
Review_body: This film is a must see for all lovers of cinema. Tightly scripted the characters come to life - you sense the actors have become the characters they portray. The opening battle sequence is one of the best brought to the screen and I have seen Olivier's "Henry V", Kirk Douglas's "Spartacus" and Mel Gibson's "Braveheart". Ridley Scott's direction, not only captures the huge scope of the canvas, he has developed the personalities of the characters and permitted them to 'breathe' and become believable, depicting a range human qualities and deficiencies.Russell Crowe's performance is so dominant (worthy of the "Oscar") one cannot imagine any other actor in the role. Joaquin Pheonix truly establishes himself as a fine actor and Connie Neilson, Richard Harris, Derek Jacobi and Oliver Reed cannot be faulted.I would recommend this film for anyone who loves a strong story line, fine acting and an appreciation of the cinematic art. You could not be disappointed with this film

This movie is one of my absolute favorites. I loved Maximus, Commodus, and Lucilla. The plot was perfect, the violence appropriate for those times. I think that the character, "Commodus" was one we absolutely loved to hate. But, he was weak, and really only wanted to love, and be loved. I loved the fighting scenes, so realistic. Cicero was another one of my favorite characters. Always faithful to Maximus to the very end. He set things in motion for Maximus, when he contacted Lucilla. She paid him and thanked him. I think she loved Maximus, but it was not clear that they could actually be together, if he lived. Which brings me to the only part of the movie i would've changed. Maximus, father to a murdered son, husband to a murdered wife;who will have his vengeance in this world or the next, should have lived.

The gladiator is best film in Hollywood
Gladiator is one of the must-see movies.
Need I say any more....not really, since this is one of the best movies ever, regardless of genre !

I believe Russell Crowe will go the rest of his career and never make a film as good as Gladiator. A General who became a slave, a slave who became a Gladiator and a Gladiator who defied an Emperor.That does not even begin to describe the intensity and excitement of the film. It Is a very much an edge of your seat movie, up until the very end, i couldn't believe it when Maximus died. This film has everything for me, story line, excellent action scenes great acting particularly from Russell Crowe who very much deserved his Oscar for this film. I cant think of a similar film that comes even remotely close to this one. To summarise the film i would rate this in my top ten film of all time, its that damn good.

Every now and then, a film comes along with adrenaline-pumped action, first-class acting, delicious cinematography and with warm, old-fashioned storytelling charm. I believe that Gladiator is one of those films. Russell Crowe gives a memorable performance as the heroic Maximus Decimus Meridius, Joaquin Phoenix is sensually evil as the embittered, power-hungry Commodus and the late Oliver Reed gives one of his career-best turns as Maximus' idealistic trainer.The story had enough depth to compliment the action sequences and the score to the film was just sensational. One of Han Zimmer's most accomplished compositions, and one to remember with nostalgic sentiment. Connie Nielsen was also credible as Lucilla, the troubled sister of Commodus, repressed of hope by her brother's dark affections towards her. The sheer magnitude of Rome, the fight sequences in the wilderness and the battles in the amphitheatre elevate this film from the run-of-the-mill Hollywood crowd of films, and witholds a historic value to boost its credibility.I don't think its one of the best films of all time, because some of the subplots are not given the depth I would have liked, and some were given too much. The incestual relationship between Lucilla and Commodus lacked subtlety.  The ending though, is very special. I think about Maximus' ideal of heaven and I wonder how close he is to the truth.
This is by far one of the best Roman culture films out there. Scott welcomes you into the drama and culture that permeated the Roman empire. You can almost smell the dust and blood in the colosseum.

We all know the story, we all know the bitter end. From visionary director Ridlly Scott, this evergreen story Is something you can always play and know you won't be disapointed. From briliant acting to to such a good story everything Is at it's place.

This was a good movie. I Enjoyed every bit of it. It had a great start with a battle, then it dwindled down to many conversations and murder. But then the pace was picked up again and the movie was good from then on. I did expect to see more fight scenes in this movie, but what could I expect from a Drama-Action movie right? Overall I enjoyed this movie over the countless times I have seen it.

Gladiator was not a bad movie, but I must say that I was disappointed with it.  Maybe my expectations were too high (hard to believe with most of the movies coming out now a days).  But I came out of the movie feeling a bit ripped off.The acting was solid.  Russell Crowe made a good brooding hero.  But my main grievance with the movie would be the total lack of originality in the story.  Basically change Maximus to a NY city cop, Rome to NY and the Emporer to a corrupt politician and you would have pretty much every other action film to come out of Hollywood.  They billed it as a throw back to the epic Roman Empire era movies like a Sparticus or Ben Hur, but it just wasn't.  Basically it was the same ole, same ole with some good acting.

Review title: It's sad that this is considered some sort of classic
Review_body: An Oscar-winning movie?  Please.  Of course, the Oscars have a history of rewarding undeserving movies, while deserving ones are often not even nominated.  I'm not sure if Traffic was even nominated, although it won for best director, how ironic.  I didn't feel this movie was anything extraordinary even by "summer blockbuster" standards, much less oscar standards (which obviously aren't too high these days).It's not that I dislike the movie, it was an enjoyable summer flick.  I think Russell Crowe is a fine actor, although this is hardly his finest work.  I guess the Academy likes epics, as they've shown in the past.  I didn't even find the special effects to be that great, they were often blurry and disjointed.  Overall...the movie makes no real impact on me. It's a decent enough movie, certainly not great.  A bit overly melodramatic but not as bad as some movies of recent years.  A solid if uninspired film...but an Oscar-winning classic?  I don't think so.

WARNING - Big spoilers (but if you can't figure out the entire plot after the first 20 minutes, go back to TV)I just saw this movie on DVD, watched it all, enjoyed it as a fight movie, but felt dissatisfied.  Then came up with the following analogy.  The movie is like a 20 Oz high quality Sirloin stake.  The cinematography and fight scenes were great, but after the first 8 Oz you start to feel you have the measure of the thing, why eat the next 12?  The story was a very old one, the only question to be resolved - does Maximus kill Commodus before he dies?  12 oz later, the answer is yes.  Oh, the stake never lost its quality - the Coliseum was great, more excellent battles.  But 8 Oz would have been fine.The acting was very uneven.  Joaquin Phoenix turned in a great performance as Commodus.  Oliver Reed had the best role since Oliver.  Russell Crowe was just not there.  That he used a lot of the same tics for Maximus as for Charles Nash was odd - but this is the guy who did LA Confidential - what happened?  Derek Jacobi being saddled with the 1-d Gracchus made me want to cry - this is the actor who made I, Claudius!And it is not that Ridley Scott can't thrive with 1-D acting - he did after all, make Blade Runner with Mister Frown, Harrison Ford.  But that movie had a great, interesting, novel plot.  This one could have been lifted from any of a 1,000 different predecessors.But why is it so not compelling?  Compare to another period piece with odd accents - The Lion in Winter - lots of satisfying complexity there and Katherine Hepburn.  A story that could twist in many directions and characters that were passionate - with many different passions.  (OK - it did have an unfair advantage in screenplay from the Bard.)  But when the acting is gripping, you can overlook all the anachronisms.  And a movie motivated by the love of a woman, but with no strong female role, isn't likely to convince you of its passion.Finally (really!) there is THE MEANING OF IT ALL.  When Max is dying on his feet, but gives(!) democracy back to the Senate (Gracchus), to fulfill the wishes of a dying emperor(!), what are we meant to take from this? Hopeful interpretation - democracy handed over at the point of the sword has as much chance of living a long life as the dying man handing it over.  Pity President Bush didn't see that.  More likely interpretation - there is no deep meaning.  Ridley Scott thought that if you do a little regime change and "hand over" democracy, then you have yourself a Triumph.  Hmm, perhaps President Bush did see this movie this way...

Review title: One of the most overrated films of the decade....
Review_body: When I first watched this movie, I was expecting everything it promised: "A Spectacular Historical Epic From Ridley Scott" But after seeing it, I can't understand the reception it got (four Oscars!). As far as I can tell, it was a botched attempt by Mr.Scott to create a historical epic of Braveheart proportions, and since Mel Gibson turned it down in favor of The Patriot, took the next Aussie in line, Russel Crowe. But the casting is the least of the problems, as the story seems derivitive and uninspired, which usually leaves it to the special effects and editing to carry the film. Sadly, even these are quite amature and ineffective. There where many times I couldn't believe I was watching a Scott film, for a tight picture and perfect visuals have become his trademark. If you want my opinion, don't even waste time on this failure, there's much better ones out there. 1/10

Review title: One of the all time greatest
Review_body: I remember going to the theater the first time with tempered hopes. I ended up seeing it fives times in the theater alone. Then I burned a hole in my DVD afterward. Ridley Scott proved himself once again to be one of the greatest directors of all time, and this movie helped me to discover Hans Zimmer as well. I also think this is Russel Crowe's definitive role, and Joaquin Phoenix's performance absolutely floored me and turned me into a huge fan of his. Just a fantastic movie, with an absolute heart break ending. The recreation of Rome gives you the feeling that you are really there. Some of the cinematography, such as the scene where Commodus is looking out over Rome, just before screaming to his sister "Am I not merciful?!" is just unforgettable. Hans Zimmer's score is absolutely unbelievable and I've basically burned a hole in the soundtrack CD as well.

Ben-Hur, Spartacus, Quo Vadis - that was when they made movies as big as cities, proper, meaty, swallow-an-afternoon films. Well, what may have been out of vogue for 40 years is making one hell of a comeback. In the grandest tradition of them all, Ridley Scott, together with man of the moment Russell Crowe, has enriched the legacy of sandals, swords and leather wrist things to create a magnificent epic. Hammering on all the touchstones of yore while utilizing all the tricks the modern filmmaker has to hand, this is hardly subtle, but its impact is absolute, its performances loud and clear and its ambition all up there on screen.Commencing with a full-scale, extras unlimited, realism unabated battle sequence in a mud strewn Germanica, we are confronted by a general tired of war and an emperor, Marcus Aurelius (Richard Harris), near death. Furious at the bond between Aurelius and his beloved warrior, his unhinged heir, Commodus, kills pop and condemns Maximus to death. Big mistake. Especially when you kill his loving wife and child, whom he yearns to for, by burning and crucifixion.And so the plot follows Maximus rise as a gladiator - trained by a remarkably vociferous and effective Oliver Reed, whose face is peculiarly CGI'd in certain scenes from beyond the grave - driven by lust for revenge. In the meantime, Rome is in turmoil with the nutty new emperor, played with gleeful vindictiveness by Phoenix, attempting to dismantle the Senate while his doting sister Lucilla (Nielsen) seems to have other plans. And just to make things more complicated, she happens to be Maximus' ex.Russell Crowe was clearly born in a hard month, in a hard year during a freak outbreak of total hardness. The man exudes the physicality of a wild animal. Shifting testosterone like a pure-bloated Brando, he holds the screen with such assuredness and force you simply can't rip your eyes away from him. When he looks furious (as he does for 90 percent of the time), the movie possesses its own gravitational pull.Ridley Scott was also the man for the job. His trademark visual panache - making everything seem utterly glorious no matter how brutal or gritty - presents the events on a truly epic canvas of filtered light and ancient landscapes. CGI has recreated Rome's massive Colosseum and the gore splattered combat sequences therein are literally stunning - the face-off between Maximus' and his gladiator brothers and a stream of chariots in mid-arena makes a mockery of Ben-Hur's fabled race sequence, and utilizing Private Ryan-esquire frame-jumping techniques gives the fighting a tangible realism that crashes out of the screen.There is an interesting if token commentary on the use of violent entertainment to subvert the masses, but on the whole, historical accuracy is reserved more for the technical elements than any sense of political, religious or dialectic truth (accents are all over the shop). The film also bobbles in its need to cram so much politicking in, to draw in an empire in crisis to the more personal story of one man's revenge.Courtesy: Empire magazine

I will admit that "Gladiator" is a very good movie, but I'm amazed at how many people gave it ten out of ten stars. I know standards fall as time goes on, but that's a rating that should be reserved for a movie that will stay with you for years to come. All About Eve is such a movie; so is the Godfather. This isn't going to be one.Don't get me wrong, it's great to see old pros (Reed and Harris) and relatively new pros (Crowe, Phoenix, Nielsen, and Hounsou) go through their paces; Crowe in particular is better than I've ever seen him before. However, the plot is well worn, the dialogue occasionally lapses into silliness, and the CGIs bother me. I can remember a time (was it really only two decades ago?) when filmmakers who wanted a mindbogglingly spectacular set built one--they did the work, they spent the bucks, they expended the sweat. The CGI Colosseum seems like cheating, somehow, and several other shots are so obviously faked, they detract from the action.Speaking of the action, it is quite good. Scott has definitely lost none of his knack for tense pacing; I was surprised to see that two hours had gone by and I hadn't even felt them. The fight scenes are not only believable, which isn't even remotely a given in action movies, they're so entertaining they inspire not only excitement but a vague sense of guilt. And after being weaned on the mega-buff steroid stallions of the 80s and early 90s, it's very nice to see the athletic but not Conanesque Maximus in action.All in all, a good flick, but I'm pulling for Traffic or Crouching Tiger to take home the gold statues. This just isn't the kind of movie that deserves them.

...all a man can do is smile back.In a way that line sums up this movie.On the surface it comes across as a simple action thriller... and it is, in many ways. The dialog is stilted,the story unoriginal,the character's archetypes, the political commentary unsubtle and the ending predictable.But what transcends this film is the undercurrent themes of hope, despair and loneliness.For example, the film's villain Commodus at first seems like your typical villain but Phoenix shows us a lonely,scared,love-starved boy capable of kindness and worthy of our empathy.In his scenes with his sister Lucilla the two actors lift it away from just being about incest to a study of a relationship of poignant dependency.Lucilla half hates her brother -and deep down he knows this- but he overlooks this because he desperately needs her.Lucilla too is a lost soul, revealed in a line to Maximus:''I have felt alone all my life,except with you.'' The film says one crucial thing about human nature-our capacity for enjoying the pain of others. We are watching people watching people die. And we enjoy the death and violence as much as the Romans did. But the film's ending offer's some-perhaps unattainable-hope and is, in a odd way an affirmation of life.What Gladiator doe's best is bring to life a world now lost. If I ever go to the Colosseum in Rome, I will not now see the rows of empty seats but hope,terror,hatred,cruelty, small kindness,desperate courage,and even heroism..in short.. all Humanity.

Review title: Probably the best war movie of all time
Review_body: Ridley Scott's magnum opus is a specter of epic proportions- both in terms of visual treat and acting prowess. Crowe gives his best ever performance, and is the perfect portrayal of a leader- calmness in eyes during planning, intend while attacking and ruthlessness in killing, and a man who lost his family- haunted by memories of his wife and son. Joaquin gives a stirring performance as Commodus. The subtle hinds of mental insanity, raw lust and incest adds to his mysterious nature, with the hatred to him increasing steadily through the movie. Connie Nielsen as Lucilla gives a steady performance, but the portrayal of her fear of Commodus is outstanding. The emotional scenes- between Aurelius and Maximus, Maximus' first battle as a gladiator and the climax sequences- could have been overdone by glorification of the hero, but Scott does an immaculate job in creating the feeling in audience, probably by the portrayal of Maximus as any man, driven solely by his loyalty and purpose above desire.Music by Zimmer and Lisa Gerrard is instrumental in completing the feel of Roman era, with the final "Now we are free" being absolute goosebumps material, though on hindsight, I did find some similarity between the Pirates of Caribbean "He's a pirate" and the war theme. Nevertheless, I don't find any reason why it should not be given a 10. A must watch film for all.

Magnificent work by Ridley Scott and Russell Crowe. I watched both versions - the long and the short one, and I have to say that the short version of the film is no doubt better. It is like with many other films. I find that this movie shows real character, amazing battle scenes which do not take the attention away from the narrative. I liked being immersed in an epoch I know nothing about. I don't know if it is historically correct and I suspect it is not, but still it is a beautiful movie about real (well, in fact fictional) heroes, how can you go wrong :) Of course I will recommend this to others, to kids and grown ups alike. Nicely done work. I am giving it 9 out of 10 because of the longer version, which was on the verge of boring.

OK, my first ten on this site, but for what a movie ! Normally I have problems watching films more then once, but this one I can not get enough of. The story of a man almost defeated, to fight back to try to take revenge on his defeater, has been done before. But not in such a totally COMPLETE movie.Russell Crowe IS gladiator. He exactly fits the gentle hero model (as we can also see in other movies featuring him, like Master and Commander, and more recently Cinderella Man). Review title: If I Could Give This Movie 11/10, It Would Be A 12!
Review_body: Gladiator! A thrilling tale of a Roman general who must battle against all thinkable odds to avenge the death of his family and restore justice to the empire. The plot is simple, legendary general Maximus Decimus Meridius, after many victorious campaigns and battles wants to return to his peaceful home in Spain, However the kind, fair and dying Emperor Marcus Aurelius wishes to bestow his title on him over his cruel son, Commodus. Commodus is understandably annoyed and kills his father calming the title of Emperor. Maximus is sentenced to death along with the rest of his family back at his home in Spain. Maximus escapes but is unable to save his wife and son. His loss of will to live makes him an east target for slavers and he is soon sold as a gladiator. He fights his way into the coliseum in Rome were he wins over the crowd and uses his celebrity status to defy the Emperor, to whom he swears his vengeance for the death of his family, after many battles and political backstabbing he gets his chance to fight the Emperor in the Arena.This is just such an amazing film, it captures every emotion possible in only the way an expert director can achieve, we can go on for whole scenes without the need for speaking, everything is told through the genuine body language and expressions. And when there is conversing we get such emotion and wonderfully powerful quotes  "What we do in life, echoes in eternity" Wow.The opening scene is spellbinding, showing the true gore of battle, the fight scenes are marvellously realistic, discarding the popular "pretty" sword fighting for brutal aggressive force. The audience in the arena express every emotion, surprise, anger, and enjoyment. The cast is brilliantly chosen; we can really see Russell Crowe as a gladiator, in Commodus, Joaquin Phoenix gives us a man we can really hate, Connie Nielson shows real emotion and passion in the role of Lucilla. So apart from the spellbinding acting, scarily realistic fight scenes and the amazing script, what else can we look for? The music is just stunning, its exactly what we need brought in at exactly the right time, truly wonderful directing. And then we have the stunning special effects, we can really visualise the greatness that is Rome, the fight scenes really make you believe. Some critics have condemned the lack of historical fact, for instance an emperor would never fight a gladiator, and these comments cannot be denied, its true.But I think we can forgive them that one fault for such an amazing movie. Without hesitation I give this movie a truly deserved 10/10!

Review_body: If I could give this movie 100/10 I would. I have no words, been watching since I was 5 years old, over and over and over with my dad. Know every word, every melody. Hans Zimmer can never ever ever go wrong. Just absolutely amazing. Never fails me even though I've for sure seen it 100+ times, just keeps on getting better and better. Will forever be a classic!!! "What we do in life, echoes in eternity".

Gladiator is a well beloved film that is a fact. I can see why too. The acting is great! Russell Crowe and Joaquin Phoenix deliver terrific performances and the cinematography is certainly not bad. Even the directing is quite good which it should be coming from the brilliant Ridley Scott. I mean I love Alien, Blade Runner, American Gangster etc. I was expecting something really good but all I got was a mediocre epic.Enough praise though there is plenty wrong with the movie. A) Historically this movie is false beyond belief... In real life Commodus wasn't evil, fire arrows never flew from the sky, helmets werent chopped like they were made out of wood and nobody was swinging around two spathas at a time!!! B) The movie is overlong, unoriginal and bland. C) The story is poor and mostly a romanticized adventure straight out of the mind of a ten year old.All and all it isn't a horrible movie by any sense of the word but it also isn't anywhere near being a masterpiece or even one of Ridley Scott's better movies. Watch it if you like unrealistic stories and fantasy movie because that is what it is. Certainly not History...WEAK!!! 7/10

Review title: The return of sword and sandals!
Review_body: There was huge excitement when Ridley Scott decided to revive the sword and sandals genre that had been dead since the early 1960s. Gladiator was truly epic and gripping. It didn't really revive the genre in retrospect though we had Troy I suppose. My only gripe was that Scott edited out scenes that were longer on dialogue and shorter on action. Might have varied the pace and added more depth. Great to see veteran actors like Derek Jacobi chewing the scenery.

Review title: one of the most powerful movies ever
Review_body: Russell Crowe delivers his best performance to date as Maximus. He's incredibly charismatic and attracts all the attention of the audience which is the basic success of the movie.The battle sequence at the beginning is superb , cinematography is great. Not a perfect movie but definitely intense and with such a power and impact it destroys every weakness in the screenplay.

I didn't make any comments until I saw this film twice as I wanted to be sure I wasn't just overwhelmed on first viewing.  But the second time confirmed my feelings - this is a wonderful film.To those who don't think Gladiator is an epic - I'd almost agree.  It is really a very personal story - that of Maximus and his desire for vengeance against the Emperor Commodus.  The grand scope and effects in the film are really there just to underline this fact.  They do this very well - the opening battle scene is huge and the scenes in the arena are wonderful (but if you can't stomach blood - don't go!).  The scale of the film is epic with an excellent recreation of 'the Glory that was Rome'.The casting was generally good - concentrating especially on classically trained Brits in supporting roles.  But the real focus of the film IS Russell Crowe as Maximus.  He is on screen for most of the film and I can't imagine anyone else playing the role - he is the soul of the film and if he hadn't done such a good job the film would have been a disaster.  He portrays Maximus' grief and rage superbly - in words, looks and gestures (I don't think I've ever seen anyone act so much with their eyes before...) You will not believe how menacing the line 'I will win the crowd' can be until you hear it.This should be the role that finally gets Crowe the recognition he deserves. He should have had Best Supporting Actor for LA Confidential, the Best Actor this year was a very tough category.  Next year there shouldn't even be a contest - I don't think that anyone will dominate a film as much.

This film is stunningly bad.Russell Crowe is so wasted here.  And Connie Neilsen could be beautiful so much more entertainingly somewhere else.The sound is muddy, the effects attempt what they can't deliver, and the script is so relentlessly incredible that not even Crowe's acting and Neilsen's astonishing good looks can rescue it.The initial battle scene, like so many, is ridiculous.  The opposing forces are cheaply miniscule.  The Romans chose laughably bad ground (downhill from the enemy!).  And the ease with which the Romans position there cavalry behind the opponents is absurd.  It was nice, if incomprehensible, to catch Scott's homage to the great film, ZULU -- the Germans seemed to have the Zulu battle chants down pat.Most annoyingly, Scott seems to think that an occasional spray of blood and a sickeningly jostled camera equals Big Action.  More like Mild Nausea.  We see much of this, alas, later in the movie, too.OK, so we grant a little geographic and medical license to Maximus as he rides, wounded, across much of Europe, to find his family murdered.  But from that moment all credulity must be withheld.  Since when does a Roman citizen place himself in jeopardy of being impressed by slave traders just because he makes the grave error of being unconscious?  It might have made more sense if he'd woken up belowdecks on a British ship of the line in the 18th century.The climax of the film, though momentarily pleasing in the accuracy of its downbeat rendition of one's chance of succeeding in a plot against a Roman emperor, once again dismisses credibility: Commodus thinks he'll do better against a genuine heavyweight than Johnny Friendly did against Terry Malloy. Or imagine Al Gore suggesting that he and George Dubyah settle this thing mano a mano.  Same idea.  Puh-lease.The film was kind of a pagan BEN HUR, but without Jesus, the horses, the (real) crowds, and any significance whatever.  And it lacked, especially, a crazy emperor like Caligula of the ROBE movies, played in his film debut by the brilliant Jay Robinson ("Messalina!"). Too much post-modern dysfunctional family stuff among Scott's Caesars.Yuck.

Review title: Awesome fight scenes, but being long doesn't make it "epic"
Review_body: I saw Gladiator in a packed auditorium, where every drop of blood, beheading, and tiger bite was greeted with enthusiastic cheers.  And there was a lot of cheering, as the movie was filled with outstanding, original action sequences.Weighing in at close to three hours, this movie tried to be an "epic film," but failed.  It featured all the standards: the love interest from long ago, the wise old man, the ambitious son, the black sidekick, the "we must work together" speech, a man fighting for revenge, etc.   And it's all very good, but not great.Go to the Colisseum , see the bloodshed, cheer.  But don't expect much more than that.

I was´nt expecting much out of Ridley Scott´s "Gladiator". My opinion is that he have´nt lived up to "Bladerunner" and "Thelma & Louise" in the -90´s. But the story of "Gladiator" woke my intrest and there i was, at the cinema, with my low expectations.This was exactly the kind of movie that i´ve been waiting for! It got all of the parts to make this a classic; action, love, betrayal, hope & misery. The one thing that impressed me the most, except from Russell Crowe´s fantastic performance, was the beautiful world that was brought to life by stunning scenography and computer effects.This is a "must see movie". I can´t express myself clearly enough to give this movie justice. It can´t be described, just experienced!
