His movies always look good, but leave a lot to be desired other than that.This movie was carried by Crowe, who must have sold his soul to be as good as he is.There are TONS of anachronisms... forks in 180ad, longbows, etc.. but my biggest beef with the movie was the soundtrack. It wasn't bad, it was TOOOOOOO much and TOOOO loud!!  I think there was all of five seconds that didn't have soundtrack. The (I assume, as there wasn't any credit given) Lisa Gerrard stuff was great, but the Holst/Planets ripoff stuff was pretty dull...

Why this movie is so critically acclaimed is beyond me.  It is a boring a movie as its name. The characters are bland and one-dimensional. It is a B-movie in comparison to great Roman movies like Ben Hur and Sparticus. The only saving graces are the special effects, and Russell Crowe's big name. Russell Crowe wasn't even that great in this movie, he only carried the monicker of 'Next big actor'; the Hollywood flavor of the month.So now, just like Titanic, it has road it success all the way to the Oscars and will probably win when other quality movies like Almost Famous, Wonder Boys and State and Main get snubbed.  Once again the Academy screws up.

Review title: Strong story and a bit of historical fiction
Review_body: This was a strong movie.  It held my attention and kept a quick pace, building a few characters and spicing things up with admirable special effects. Although it is not based too strongly in historical fact, most people will not figure that out unless they do some research on Roman Emperors.

Review title: Blows away Sparticus and Ben Hur
Review_body: Loved this movie. Russell Crowe fantastic as Maximus! The story line was brilliant, and the action was non-stop. Pay attention to the sound-track - it was great, also. The attention to detail in the Roman soldiers uniforms and their battle tactics was very satisfying. It was nice to see that somebody read a history book before making the film. This is a Big Screen movie. It will not have the same impact on the television. See it!

Ridley Scott has done it again - he is the master of the light! Blade Runner had that wonderful atmosphere with rays of light slanting through windows, and in Gladiator he manages to do the same with outside scenes! My favorites: the initial battle scene in the German forests and the short sunrise scene in Rome. Absolutely brilliant settings and just powerful images.However, the cinematography is not all that stands out in this movie. The story is well-told, the acting great, everything comes together just so. The counterpoint of the stoic, down-to-earth Maximus Decimus Berilius (Russell Crowe) vs. the corrupt, slimy Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix) trying so hard to out-do the image of his father is perfect.I have to give this one: two thumbs up! ;]

I thought this film shows all that is wrong with film making at the moment, the story was really terrible, poor guy, doesn't want to fight anymore, oops, they kill his family, now I don't care about anything and I'm going to kill lots of people.This film would have been great if it was released as a comedy, as I laughed quite a lot at the predictable, boring story. The relationship between the Caesar and his sister was just ludicrous, and the effects, although no doubt very expansive, were not really very good.When I came out I didn't know whether to laugh or cry!

The last battle to secure Rome's frontier belies the turmoil within; Ridley Scott is stating that it is easy to be fractious and divided when there is no common enemy.  The crowds cheer the return of the fights to the death and glorify violence.  Are we not individuals in a different kind of coliseum watching a spectacle of violence in a time of relative external peace?  This event marked the pinnacle of the Roman empire and the beginning of its demise.

The fight scenes and such were spectacular.  It was a visually lush movie. The acting, especially on Russell Crowe's part, was excellent but if they are going to spend 100M on a movie couldn't they have channelled some of those funds into a decent script with believable characters.And I am always willing to suspend my disbelief but when it comes to historical movies I appreciate a little more accuracy.  For instance: Marcus Aurelius DID with the last of his strength (supposedly) declare Commodus to be his heir in front of the army.  And Commodus did quite often enter the arena as a gladiator but, it wasn't until about 10 or 11 years after he became Emperor that he was poisoned by his mistress and died. Though perhaps not as truly depraved as Caligula, Commodus' true history seems to have been interesting enough to have fledged a much more well rounded script, with a greater depth of plot.I went to the theatre expecting the kind of feeling experienced from viewing BraveHeart I was definitely disappointed.

The opening sequence is worth the price of admission alone.  As a student of Latin History, the CGI quality beats any drawn representation of Ancient Rome, and the Coliseum never looked better.  (But why does every CGI landscape artist opt to include a flock of airborne birds?  They never look right and almost always distract from the focus of the shot.)  Visually, the production team earned their credits and I give them kudos for their costumes, props, and above all, the true-to-life gladiator battles.But all that doesn't make up for the cheese-eater of an ending.  Director Ridley Scott has created a legacy of amazing films, most of which are science fiction-based, and maybe that's where Gladiator should be categorized.  The script is fairly solid except for one MASSIVE flaw.* SPOILER ALERT *For wanting to create a visually stunning, seat-gripping historical action film, why absolutely discredit the validity of the entire piece by having the most important person in Rome (at any given time) killed in the way chosen.  NEVER in the history of Ancient Rome could such a plot occur.  To have us believe an emperor of Rome would enter the arena, under any circumstance other than to award the victor, boggles the mind.  The film which was great-up-to-now totally unravels at this moment.Post-viewing, three simple alternatives came to mind.  One, keep the scope from being so grandiose.  Rather, use another general or a politician as the antagonist.  At least blur the historical lines by using a lesser-known Emperor, not Marcus Aurelius.  Hey, it worked for Caligula.  Two, design the story more akin to David Lynch's Dune.  The similarities are abundantly present, but maybe that's what opted Scott's direction.  Three, and this is my favorite idea, let the hero die WITHOUT "saving the day".  After all, the most popular form of theater in Ancient Rome was tragedy.I rated Gladiator at 6.  It deserves watching, but has problems too severe to ignore.  It begins with heart-pounding action and political intrigue, but ends as heroic-tripe.  I'd rather watch The Fall of the Roman Empire.

Review title: Good action, who cares about history.
Review_body: The reason I enjoyed this movie is for the same reason I enjoyed Independence Day.  You can sit back and enjoy the marvelous special effects, and revel in the endless action and drama.  At the same time, every ounce of your body is cheering for the protagonist.  Even with such a formulaic movie, it is a lot of fun to watch.

From the outset it should be said that "Gladiator" might appear to be a "blokey", "testosterone pumping" blood'n'guts movie. Nothing could be further from the truth.A conspiracy of glorious photography, inspired direction and a powerfully immaculate performance by Russell Crowe transports the audience to ancient Rome.   And the journey is immersive, visceral and compelling. "Gladiator" is a rivetting story of treachery, tragedy, deception and revenge and is made memorable by unforgettable performances by Joaquin Phoenix, Oliver Reed, Connie Nielsen, Derek Jacobi, et al.Joaquin delivers as Commodus, a simpering, treacherous psychopath with an apparently unfulfilled lust for his sister Lucilla and a penchant for over-vigorous paternal hugging. Ollie Reed (RIP) gives a cracker of a performance as sports agent, Proximo, whose catch cry should be "show me the denari".  He literally throws his clients to the wolves.But all the acting accolades should be showered on Russell Crowe. He thrives on the pressure of appearing in nearly every scene, a burden which would demolish a lesser actor, and he is absolutely mesmerising.  What a talent.
Ridley Scott has bestowed upon us a cinematic masterpiece. This is not just a 160 minute blockbuster it is a seminal event in movie making.

I had high expectations for this film.  In the end, I was somewhat disappointed because the film lacked the action, which it was marketed for. The film is more of a dramatic story than action.  Unfortunately, the story is somewhat lacking especially when compared to Braveheart.  Another disappointment was the choreography during many of the action sequences. It was very hard to follow and could cause some to have a seizure.  The acting performances were there with Russell Crowe and Joaquin Phoenix but in the end the movie was a let-down.  However, some of the gladiator battles were outstanding.  7 out of 10.

About time they finally got around to making another Roman Empire era movie. This one may be the best of them all, too! The special effects to show Rome & the Colliseum were awe inspiring. After this movie, Russell Crowe will start having action flicks lined up for him to star in. This movie was action packed with some violence on the gory side (though like Braveheart, does not lower the quality of this movie). If you like Roman Empire movies, historical movies, action movies, Conan the Barbarian type violence, epic Braveheart like story and battles (though only one battle between armies in this film), and Excalibur like soundtrack, this movie is for you!

Review title: All the cliches ever made up rolled into one movie
Review_body: My girlfriend had heard several great reviews from her friends so i had to be dragged to see 'gladiator', even though i had a very bad feeling about it.. Well, all my expectations were met, every cliche in the book was there and the worst part was that they were not even performed well. The whole movie tries very hard to radiate grandeur and epic heroism but it just totally fails. Acting was crap, most actors were statues talking without intonation while Crowe walked around the whole movie looking worried and silly and not like the heroic general he was supposed to be.. Music was junk (didn't expect it at all from Hans Zimmer, normally excellent..). The whole movie just didn't have the atmosphere it could have had. If you wanna see a good movie with Crowe watch The Insider (far better music too, incidentally also by Lisa Gerrard who did Gladiator together with Zimmer).

"Gladiator" is a movie with a lot going for it.  A big budget, a big director, an up and coming star, a summer release date, etc, etc.  But in my opinion, it falls just short.  Despite what you may have heard, this movie is predictable, slow, and corny.  The fight scenes themselves are stellar, even fantastic, but they are few and far between.  The majority of this movie deals with a whiny Joaquin Phoenix and his incestuous lusts and obvious motives.  Russell Crowe does well with what he's given, but most of the best scenes involving him involve so much CG background and action that it ends up taking away from the acting, as was evident in another so called summer blockbuster "The Phantom Menace."  The violence is overboard and gratuitous and the movie moves like molasses.  Overall, I say thumbs down.  Give me real action over CG action any day of the week.

Russell Crowe rocks as Maximilius, a revered Roman general betrayed by the new Caesar. To be sure, Gladiator is a bloody and at times violent film. But the gladiator is fighting for his life and for revenge.You will love the gladiator and hate the villain and come away two and a half hours later feeling very satisfied, even if some dramatic parts are slightly slower than they should be.Very enjoyable.

This movie had some good points but overall it was a boring action movie. The beginning was increadibly film and dramatic (I still wonder what happened to his dog).  Then there are two hours of slow parts with three minutes of gladiator fighting in the spurts.  The gladiator scenes themselves are full of choppy views and MTV style cuts.  This is a disgrace that people are comparing this movie to the classic epics (Sparticus, Ben Hur).  Even the special effects were only decent.  Russell Crowe was a bad ass, but one performance does not make a movie.  Actually make that two Damon (last name?) was great in it too.  Overall a big disappointment.

Review title: An all time classic in the making
Review_body: This film is undoubtedly the best film of the year, and has to be in the all time top 20. For me it had everything. Russell Crowe is just brilliant and puts in another oscar winning performance. This man can't put a foot wrong at the moment following his huge success in The Insider, although it took me a while to realise it was him as i am sure it will you. A good comeback also by Ridley Scott, who directed it well after a disappointing and not such a great effort with G I Jane. I just couldn't get enough of this film. It wasn't too long or too short, but i can see why the female of the species may not take a liking to it, as there was vast amounts of violence and blood which for me made it better, along with a terrific story line and a heart warming end. I recommend you seeing it but can't guarentee you'll like it as much as i did.

Review title: A wonderful movie that's about something important!
Review_body: What can I say, the acting, directing, writing--all hit the mark.  Special effects work, but who cares?  This is a movie about people and relationships and you really really care what happens.  When was the last time a movie made you think about integrity and loyalty and doing the right thing, no matter how much it hurts?If I were a moveimaker, I would pray that all my movies would star Russel Crowe.  And be directed by Ridley Scott.  This is heaven (or Elysium) indeed.

Review title: It was pretty good, with only a few flaws.
Review_body: This is one of the best movies I have seen in a while, it has everything too (Good story, pretty good dialoge, good acting, superb visuals, pretty good physics, and plenty of gore).  The characters all had pretty good backstories, and you never really knew what was going to happen.But I did see a few mistakes...one at the begining, at the battle scene, before anyone had even shot an arrow or swung a sword, they show a close up of the barbarians and they have arrows all around them.  Another mistake were the Tigers...now I know I couldn't have been the only one to notice this, but if they were so vicious and so mean why does it show them laying down after he let that other guy live?  And another thing wrong with the tigers was that they were on chains held by slaves, now after a while wouldn't you think the tigers would realize that they could go get the slaves?!  Hum...I'm not that looks for every error in a movie, but these stood out big time.Hehe, im getting all off subject here, but this really was a great movie and like I said it have everything and the characters stick in your head, it also had one of the best endings I've seen in my opinion.Final rating: 9/10

Review title: Dear Ridley, what have you done......
Review_body: After having enjoyed all these perfectly made movies like Alien, Blade Runner, etc. we should accept a weak period of a good director. Obviously dear Ridley was corrupted by nowadays techniques of film-making. I have rarely seen such a poor content wrapped into high-tec sceneries and excellent photographing. Dear Ridley simply didn´t reflect about the message of this work of blood, mud and tears: cheap heroes and a nearly fascistoid philosophy. Do we really need such matter or isn´t it better to look forward and forget about those primitive revenge stories. And by the way:  I cannot accept this way of falsifying historic facts.

A combination of all the best parts of Saving Private Ryan, Braveheart, and The Lion King, Gladiator opens, carrying itself like the great Roman war machine portrayed, then grabs the viewer and drags them through the story of Maximus.  His adoption into the gladiator lifestyle is almost as intense and emotional off the battle field as it is on.  Where Braveheart called for the audience to laugh or be shocked by the images on screen, Gladiator carries a much more personal feeling to their battles (mainly due to the size), allowing them to rile up much more emotional steam that has ever been seen in a war epic.  A veiwer must wonder as they watch, is it right that I support the brutality, is it right that I am rooting for a man to kill another?  It's quite an emotional movie, wait until you see it.Despite the moral conflict, the movie is still amazing.  Russell Crowe is, as always, amazing, and Joaquin Phoenix has turned what is probably his best performance of his career.  Ridley Scott's directing is excellent, keeping true to the worn, hot, aged feel of a gladiator movie, while at the same time, incorporating many techniques to heighten the experience, going inside the minds of the characters.It runs around two and a half hours, not too long for a Gladiator pic, and is naughtily entertaining.  Lots of blood.  Lots of gory battles.  Lots of extremely exciting battles, everything a gladiator movie should have.

Review title: A film with very little or no story
Review_body: After reading some reviews I did not go to the film with too much expectation, however even then the film proved to be a big disappointment. The initial battle scenes are very impressive but then the film deteriorates into one fighting scene after another with very little story line. The actual cinematography is also not very impressive by often being far fetched. However the film is worth seeing just for fun.

Just came from the movie expecting a good story. Instead got a great story. The film never gave you a moments peace but moved relentlessly toward the ending. The landscape scenes (regardless of how they are created) are breathtaking. It is a story of war between armies and individuals. A surprisingly good job is done on filling in personalities and motivation without bringing the story to a halt. I came away with two overall observations.While watching I kept thinking of other films. Try Viva Zapata or Rollerball for similar plot lines. I also got the impression Rome might have dissolved over sport at the coliseum and there were many parallels between Rome and the USA at present.But, the important person to watch is Russell Crowe. Mel Gibson broke in with action films like Mad Max and evolved into a very entertaining actor. Crowe is well on his way in the same direction.Academy Award time should have this film in the running for more than one category.

Movies are supposed to be about suspension of disbelief.  Nothing in this movie had me convinced that any of it could happen.  Russel Crowe only made it harder not to turn it off.  If not for my wife enjoying his looks, this movie would have been out of the DVD player five minutes in.By the way, the effects are horrible too.

The problem with movies today is that they try (and the key word here is "try") to enlighten us.  They attempt to push lenghty ten minute monologues on our materialistic existence or the superficiality of mankind down our throats.  What these movies and directors and screenwriters behind these movies fail to realize is that 98.9% of the world's population could care less about being enlightened.  When I sit through a 3 hour movie, I want it to be entertaining.  I don't wanna shell out 8 bucks to be preached at. Gladiator is the perfect example of a movie that the majority of moviegoers want to see.Gladiator has it all: a villain, a hero, a king, lots of gore, and beautiful cinematography and direction.  While not being a breakthrough film or a one of a kind masterpiece, it's got all it needs.  People want to see movies like this.  They want that adrenaline rush right before a fight scene, they want to root for the hero, and they want that instant feeling of gratification and pure elation when the hero wins, no matter how strong the forces against him are.The hero in the movie is Russell Crowe, and he's great.  The rest of the cast was good, but the one person holding this entire film up is Crowe. And why shouldn't he?  The movie is centered around him.  This movie is exactly what he needs.  He's gonna become a household name.I give this movie a 10, not because it's one of my favorites, and not because it's a masterpiece (because it isn't), but because it embodies what a film should be.  It's not superficial or preachy.  It's just a good old-fashioned story delivered to us in a beautiful package.  I'd be willing to shell out 8 bucks for the ticket (plus 3 for a Dr Pepper) to see this movie any day.

Review title: Great movie by Ridley Scott. Russell Crowe is outstanding.
Review_body: This is a movie well worth seeing. Ridley Scott has made a movie that is believable and brutal but not gory. It has fine editing. You get the impact but not lingering gruesome shots of bloody battle. It is undoubtedly the most realistic portrayal of Roman life that has ever been in the movies.Russell Crowe is a revelation. In a sea of wonderful actors, he carries the movie. Any army would follow his Maximus into battle. I will now have to go back and look up his previous work and see what I have missed. All of the actors including Joaquin Phoenix, Oliver Reed, Richard Harris and Connie Nielsen are wonderful.The photography is flawless and you can hardly notice the effects.The ending is a minor flaw in the movie. It is satisfying but you can see it coming from a long way off. They spent a lot of money to make this movie and it was well spent. See it.

Review title: Visual Feast of historic beauty and war
Review_body: Wow!  Never have I seen such a lively response of the audience after a movie.  The dialogue, cinematography, casting and music were extraordinary. I've seen it twice in two days and it was well worth it.  The beautifully detailed beginning battle reminded me of the Saving Private Ryan beginning scene, with the shakey hand held camera and in your face action.Good Job Ridley Scott!!

Review title: Its a joke that this film is up for an Oscar
Review_body: Oscar material? Hardly.  Gladiator is at best a "B" level action flick. This film is filled with endless scenes of gore and mayhem, which hardly constitute acting.  It is the typical B level flick with tension building to the inevitable encounter of good guy and bad guy, which good guy obviously wins. Crowe walks around for 2 hours and 35 minutes with a semi-pained expression, but not saying much and certainly not acting. A further disservice of this movie is the way it warps history.  Marcus Aurelius died of the plague. His son, Commodus, ruled for 12 years and although he was insane and  did enter the arena, he was murdered elsewhere.  The final Germanic wars of Marcus Aurelius were fought on the Danube frontier and I don't know how you go from the Danube to Italy via a desert, unless you're miserably lost.  Which is sort of the theme of this movie.  People see this and think they're getting a history lesson rather than just junk.  I can easily think of ten movies this past year which had more meaning, intellectual content and stronger acting than Gladiator.

I went into Gladiator with high hopes, thinking that my expectations were "too" high. I was not disappointed.  The film opens with an great war sequence in Germania, that somewhat resembled "Saving Private Ryan" and the jaw-dropping Gladiator sequences are breathtaking.  Russell Crowe is great, Connie Nielson is great, and it is fun to watch Joaquin Phoenix, play such an evil character.  Go See IT! 10/10

I approached Ridley Scott's Gladiator with an enthusiasm for spectacular visual effects and a testosterone-pumped craving for carnage along the lines of Saving Private Ryan meets Ben-hur. However, upon actually viewing the film, I found that there is much more at work here. Of course, Scott is no Joel Schumacher and Russell Crowe isn't a Schwarzeneggar type, so this came with only a minimal amount of surprise. To address my initial hopes, Gladiator does harbor a variety of extraordinary images. The Roman cityscape is worth the price of admission in itself. Although some shots exhibit that "too bright" look that a lot of cgi effects have, the majority of scenes are composed with convincing authenticity. But forget the settings. Let's talk about satisfying the "I want to see brutal murder and dismemberment" desires of most moviegoers. Don't get too excited. As far as the blood and guts go, it seems that all of the battle sequences were cut in extremely short takes thrown together with shaky-cam perspective(I'm guessing they were trying to avoid an NC-17 rating). The bottom line is: in most shots, you really can't tell what is happening except for traces of red derived from spraying blood and the occasional death scream. I understand some things are in bad taste, but when you are depicting the gladiator "sport", the exploitation of death is the center of entertainment. Points off for that one. Also in poor form is the editing of the film in general. Gladiator is either an edge-of-your-seat roller coaster ride or a soap-opera paced drama and never falls anywhere between these two extremes. There is simply no transition. So what you seem to be left with is two films: a Mad-Max-style, kill 'em all hand to hand combat action flick on one hand and an expensive period piece character-study on the other. It's not that the performances are bad. It's just that there is essentially very little plot, so the actors have no means of developing their characters other than in face-to-face emotional monologues. Which brings me to the overly-dramatic-at-points score. There is a scene in the beginning of the film where Commodus and his father discuss the future of Rome. It entails Commodus communicating great frustration to his father through an emotional out-pour. The scene is acted adequately, but the music is laughably out of place and you feel like laughing at Commodus rather than understanding his plight. Aside from that, and a rather weak ending, Gladiator is, by all means, a must see. It runs over older sword and sandal epics with a 4-horse chariot (ok, that was pretty lame...forgive me).

Quite simply, brilliant..typical Hollywood ending but still brilliant. Oliver Reed is masterful in his last performance, he steals every shot he is in.  Crowe is superb and Phoenix turns in a great display as well.  Imagine the greatest epics all rolled into one, then make it better and that equals this film...go see it, it really is this good.

This movie fills in all the criterions for a "Hollywood movie". A hero, his wife and children, death of his family, a new lover, powerful enemy, the rise of goodness and the fall of evil. Only thing what was missing is the dog of a happy family. What a cliché. The beginning was promising; the battle against the barbarians was convincing and realistic enough, but then... rubbish. The drama was hilarious, and the fights turned into sci-fi. Later in the movie happened the climax of the disappointment, the blast of (good old American) morality, when Crowe should have killed the other gladiator but was way too good-hearted. After killing thousands of barbarians and dozens of other gladiators he felt merciful. The rest of the movie was about as boring as "Titanic". Take my advice, and save your money, this film is a success only in USA, that tells a lot about any movie.

Review title: A little on the LONG side, but definitely worth the wait.
Review_body: This was an awesome movie!  I have no idea about the historical significance of this time period, but the story line was great.  At first it seemed like it was going to be an action film about the glory of Rome, but surprised us all when we started getting deeper and deeper into the lives of those involved.The actors do a great job of staying in character.The Special effects were cool too.  From the trailers, it looked like they were very poorly done, but it didn't show in the actual film.All in all this was a great film.  Definitely worth the two and a half hours it took to get to the end.

Review title: A hero will rise above the media hype and mediocre script.
Review_body: Maybe I would have enjoyed this film more if not for the media circus that surrounded it. This movie had a lot going for it, an excellent lead actor in Russell Crowe, great costumes, and beautiful scenery. What disappointed me about it was the use of familiar plot lines that are in almost every other film of this genre. A murdered family, so the hero is driven by revenge. A crazed leader in Mr. Phoenix as Commodus. Gee, I've never seen the son murder the father before to get control of the throne. And the downfall of this really long picture was the lack of action. Hey, I think the fight scenes were great, all four of them. The rest was machismo talk. Besides, if you know your history, you walk in already knowing that Rome never becomes a republic again, and the senator Gracchus meets a horrible untimely death. I would like to thank Mr. Scott for assuming we're all ignorant popcorn eaters.

Review title: Russel Crowe - Someone you would want on your side in a fight
Review_body: This is the kind of movie that they used to make, with a simple plot and some fantastic performances. What is there to be said of Russel Crowe - well he gives a performance which truly befits  that of a true Gladiator, The viewer of this film could easily see him as 'Rome's Greatest General' and at the same time believe that he is all that he as a gladiator and more. Thoroughly enjoyable, a must-see movie. Expect Oscars maybe not for the acting but definitely for the shear grandeur of it.

I was at first a bit skeptical about the renewal of the great Roman epic. But I must say that I was Blown away! Russell Crowe's and Joaquin Phoenix's perfomance's were Top-Notch (Both deserve Oscar Nod's). The Special Effect's were flawless and the  battle scene's awsome. All the actor's were great and kept me either in suspense, humoured, or almost in tear's. I Just had to voice my opinion on this great movie. (which I have already seen 3 time's ,bought the soundtrack and the Novellete.) I keep recommending it to all my friend's and those who said it was Just "OK" I told them they were nut's.

Review title: From Braveheart-like action to a great story line, Gladiator owns.
Review_body: The classic action movie, Gladiator starts with Maximus, a valiant general of the Roman Army of Marcus Aurelius the Wise, leading an army to a bloody victory.  Right from the start, the action scenes get your full attention. But don't let Gladiator's rough exterior fool you, there is a soft, lovable interior to this classic masterpiece.  Maximus is driven by the love for his wife and his son.  Action scenes are dispersed throughout the movie to keep the action fanatic busy, while Maximus' constant longing to meet his wife and child will move the more sensitive viewer.  Maximus influences the masses, from a quite large Germanic man (Ralph Moeller), who I call Tiny, to an African slave (Djimon Hounsou), to the attendants at the Colliseum.  The stories of these individuals, and the turmoil of Roman politics also play central roles.  See Gladiator.  Enjoy yourself.

I did not enjoy this movie very much, I thought that it was a good way for dreamworks to make a quick buck or in this case a quick 200 million bucks. I am saddened that Russel Crowe won his oscar for this movie, as opposed to his excellent ACTING in The Insider. Crowe was great in The Insider because that film showed that he can ACT in many different situations, as opposed to him showing how he can try to get revenge. I think that this will be remembered as a great action movie. This was a good movie because it was grand and it was big and flashy, however some of the other movies that were released in the year 2000 were good movies, because they had meaning, substance, and they were powerful films. These movies were good for reasons other than their special effects and their director and stars. I did not enjoy this movie because I was disturbed that this film won best picture as opposed to Requiem For A Dream, which was a powerful and groundbreaking film. I do not think it was the best picture of the year, no offense to anyone involved with this film, but.. that is my opinion.

Review title: The Narcissistic Exploits of Capitalist-Pig Producers In the Hunt for a Quick Buck!
Review_body: In this film, laughingly called Gladiator, there's all the glitz and glamour, the sets and costumes, the special effects, and actors necessary to make a decent film, but they completely miss the mark.  Well, you've probably seen this movie and you're thinking to yourself, I don't see how someone could say that...  And on the surface, the film does have two redeeming aspects...  the cinematography, which I must admit is awesome, and Russell Crowe in a little blue dress.  However, this beautiful, big-budget movie lacks one seemingly minor, but key element: a substantive plot. Although excessive violence, a forced hero, a sexy heroine, and a stint with incest may look like the makings of a great film, Gladiator would only measure approximately twenty-five minutes if you removed all the fight scenes.  You could probably get more plot from watching the Superbowl than watching this film.  In the first ten minutes of the film you know exactly what will happen in this movie and how it will end.  We've all seen this movie before with a better leading man, a smarter heroine, a crueler and more tyrannical ruler, and an actual plot.  It's called BRAVEHEART and it won five, count 'em FIVE Oscars!  This piece of trash that calls itself a movie is not even fit to be considered Braveheart's little sister.  First of all, Maximus Decimus Meridius (Russell Crowe) is not there to save his people.  He's there simply to get revenge on Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix), a ruler who's only concern is lifting the skirt of his babalicious sister, a woman who just happens to be madly in love with Maximus (shocker there). Why does Maximus want revenge?  Hmm, because his beloved wife and son, people who are barely in the movie and hence receive little pity from the audience, are savagely butchered.  Haven't we seen this before?  So Maximus is forced to fight for his life.  Yada yada yada.  This lasts about two hours.  He does the usual stuff...  He kicks ass, makes adversaries into friends, and shows off his shapely legs in a little powder blue dress... most fetching.  Then obviously, he faces the odious Commodus in a final fight scene so that he may unleash his terrible wrath.  Woo.  And he is, much like William Wallace, killed and reunited with his dearly departed. Filmmakers today think that they can pass off a movie that everyone's already seen as something new by dazzling them with sparkly lights and flashy special effects.  I'd like to point out that basically everything from Braveheart, even the Australian-accented Russell Crowe trying to be Mel Gibson, has been replicated but as with most copies, it ain't as good as the original.  And yes, this year's movie-pickings have been slim, but that doesn't make it good by default.

Ridley Scott is without a doubt, one of today's most gifted and talented film makers.For years he has given us incredible stories weaved around some of the most beautiful cinematography to ever grace the screen, and Gladiator stands as (one of) his crowning achievements. I can't give this film enough praise, except to say that two weeks after viewing it, I find myself still thinking about it, and for someone who's seen as many films as I have, that's high praise indeed. If you haven't yet seen this film, do yourself a lot of good and go now, I'm pretty sure you'll feel the same.

As I was sitting in the theater watching Gladiator for the third time, I was thinking of another movie that it reminded me of. Braveheart. Braveheart is easily one of the best movies of the nineties, and Gladiator is right up there with it. A moving story of a general who becomes a slave, a slave who becomes a gladiator, a gladiator who defied an emperor, Gladiator stuns and amazes. A magnificent spectacle of a movie, Ridley Scott has another motion picture masterpiece notch on his belt. Gorgeous sweeping shots of a flawlessly computer generated Rome make you gasp in awe, and the battle scenes are nothing short of spectacular. Russell Crowe turns in a typically impressive performance as the general-slave-gladiator Maximus, and Joaquin Phoenix is excellent as the young, impetuous, and tyrannical Emperor Commodus. The supporting cast is marvelous, with standout performances from Djimon Hounsou as Juba the slave, and Connie Nielsen as Lucilla. Galdiator is definitely THE movie to see this summer.

It was a pretty damn good movie, but they could have made it great.  Some of the action sequences were sped up, which took away from the coolness of it. Also, some of the dialogue was quite bad, which decreased the value some as well.  Plus, the villain, Commodus, did not strike any sort of fear in me at all, or at the very least, respect.  Last time I checked, the villains (esp. of movies such as this) were supposed to strike terror in people's hearts, but all this guy does is whine incessantly like a little girl, and I don't know about you, but little girls don't scare me.  However, even with all these faults, the movie is still quite good and I'd recommend seeing it. However, if you want a superior epic movie, see Braveheart.

This film has everything you need for a good night at your local multiplex. True it doesn't challenge the grey matter but neither did Ben Hur or Spartacus and this is much better than either of them. The opening battle sets the pace of the film and you are never left with a moment of boredom or the film slowing down, which is what happens a lot in films today. The story grasps you and even though you could probably guess the ending there are a few moments when everything is thrown into doubt and it makes a great experience for a Friday night. I found the two and a half hours flew by as I was enthralled by the excellent action scenes within the Colloseum and the breath-taking scenes of Rome and the Colloseum are what computer effects should be used for. Ridley Scott has once again gone to a genre and brought it something fresh. This is the definitive Roman epic and the best film of the year so far and it is going to take a monumental film to top this, watch it.

Review title: Best action movie of its kind since Conan the Barbarian!
Review_body: Russel Crowe does an excellent job! Very well might be the best movie for the entire Summer 2000 season. If you like movies like Conan the Barbarian, and books like Gates of Fire then you will love Gladiator! This movie is not just a guy flick, it is a movie that will touch all who watch it.

Review title: Simply the best movie I've seen this year.
Review_body: When I first walked into this movie, I thought it was to be a Braveheart clone.  After the first scene, I knew I was wrong.  This movie blew me away.  It had everything you could possibly wish for in a movie. Character development, which is sometimes lacking in movies where violence is overwhelming, was incredible.  The main character, Maximus, shows significant signs of perseverance and endurance throughout the movie.  I am not going to say what he does or how he does it because I want EVERYONE to see this movie.  I know, I'm some people have said "oh it's too violent" or "it was so gory."  Honestly, I think every slash of a sword was necessary. The producers did not attempt to tone down what would really have happened in a Roman-Empire style battle.  Actually, I enjoyed everything they threw into this.  I couldn't help having a great time watching some of the intricate fighting scenes.  Basically, if you are at all interested in Roman history, like good old fashioned war movies, or just want to have a good time, see this movie.  I recommend this to everyone.

I heard someone say that this is a "guy-movie" - I beg to differ.  While it is definitely gritty, the emotional value of this movie is what I found most impressive.  Russell Crowe's portrayel was completely convincing and moving. It never occured to me to take tissues to this movie, but I wish I had.
On a separate note, as dark, bloody and gripping as this movie was, the most disturbing thing I saw was at the end. As the credits were rolling, I saw a man several rows in front of me get up and leave with a boy no older than 10. That made my skin crawl.  Please take the "R" rating seriously; this is no show for children.

Everybody said this movie was worth seeing, so I went and saw it. The beginning was promising; mighty battle scene. After that, I just kept wondering if I'm missing the greatness, because I couldn't see any.Action scenes were very nice, otherwise very big disappointment.

Review title: A wonderful adaption to a traditional storyline from the inspiring Scott and Crowe
Review_body: The story revolves around Maximus, a noble leader who is chosen by Marcus Aurelius himself to take his place as commander in favour of his dysfunctional son Commodus.  Commodus then murders his father and sends Maximus to be executed.  Maximus survives the forthcoming execution and flees in search for his family - who he finds hung in his home town.  He then rides forth to become a gladiator to avenge the sinister Commodus. There are some fantastic battle scenes but what makes this better from all the CGI'd sci-fi films is content and depth.  Commodus loves his sister for more than just being a sister (reminiscent of Star Wars) and some of the minor characters are executed with precision.  Russell Crowe was believable, realistic, well hard and quite frankly a master in his role of Maximus, Joaquin Phoenix lacked edge but delivered as the sinister Commodus and the late Oliver Reed played a final memorable performance as Maximus' trainer. Ridley Scott's direction is awesome.  This movie shows what CGI effects should be used for.  Although gory, this is not disturbing - this is deep and portrays a powerful and awe-inspiring message.  Best movie of year 2000 so far.

Wonderful historical fiction!  People who have taken Latin will enjoy the sets, scenery, and costumes.  While some things are not and cannot be accurate to actual history; it is still a wonderful tour of the ancient world.  It really shows how much we lost in the Dark Ages.Very few bumps in the road from acting, all in all an enjoyable 2.5 hours. Rather bloody, but c'mon, it's a gladiator movie!

I am aware that if a movie makes more than $16.50 at the box office that everyone's supposed to call it corporate Hollywood crap and find fault in it, but I was VERY impressed with this film.  Of course I was amazed with the effects, but I also thought it was extremely well written and acted. Russell Crowe and Joaquin Phoenix portrayed their characters extremely well, with Crowe playing the hero to perfection and Phoenix being the perfect brat with moral issues.  There was a great deal of violence, but I found it to be used well in the story.  Go see it!

Review title: The first classic of this millennium.
Review_body: If I have to sum it up in one line, I'll say this movie is Spartacus with better effects and, forgive me, better acting. I don't know if the movie is correct as far as history is concern, but taking in account the effort put in, I would rank this movie a classic. The first classic of this millennium. It's refreshing, it's timely,as I am sure there are many who are beginning to feel that the movies of today have little to go by if not for sound and effects.  I want to say, "Well Done!" to Mr Scott, Mr Crowe and to all involved in making Gladiator a gem. So, who said they don't make movies like they used to? They do, and (forgive me again), they're beginning to do it better.

When I went to see this film, I half expected some formula film that had no substance. What I found instead, was a film that had a rich fabric of story, love, loyalty and determination.Maximus was a person of repute who wouldn't break his word to a friend or an Emperor. He wouldn't change his belifes just because the new Emporer could decide his fate. When it cost him his family, he was ready to give up, then he realized his chance was to become a Gladiator, not just any one, but the best. he showed what could be done if you had the trust and respect of people who would otherwise only work for their own reward.This is a powerful tale of what one man can do if he so choses. An Excellent film and well worth the price of admission.

Gladiator is the best movie that I've seen so far this year.  I worried about being disappointed by it, but I knew from first scene that I was in for a real treat.  The battle scenes were outstanding.  Every shot was like lightning, giving you a feel of what hand-to-hand combat must be like. Scott handled the gore extremely well, too.  You see blood, but it's not slow motion, throw-up from all the disgusting gore.  You THINK you see more than you really do. The characters are well thought-out and surprisingly complex.  Maximus is tormented by his lost family, and his personal bounds of honor.  He kills because he has to, in order to seek his revenge and/or survive.  Even with all that you think Maximus is, there remains an air of mystery about him, largely due to Crowe's brooding charisma.  We still don't know all that goes on behind that sloping brow.  Commodus is deliciously evil and complex. Yet, we feel that all his conniving and his wickedness stems from his longing to be loved, first by his father and then from his people.  He doesn't want to destroy Maximus; he wants to be him, for Maximus has the love  of the people and of the Emperor.  Commodus' unnatural affection for his sister Lucilla stems, again, from his longing for his father.  The Emperor Marcus Aurelius loves Lucilla; Commodus projects the love he is denied onto the child that their father loves.  Lucilla is a good example of a head-strong female ruler, much absent in epic films.  She knows what she wants (Maximus), yet in keeping with the times, she doesn't force convention if it is not in her or her son's best interests. The only problem I had was that of Maximus' and Lucilla's past history. I think that, instead of having them be past lovers, that they could have been friends, with Lucilla being attracted to him, but never acting upon it until now.  It never followed up enough with the backstory that was given, and I think this would have been a better, and easier explanation. On the whole, I give it two thumbs up. My friends and I already declared it that after the opening scene.

How the actors in this film could deliver such lines with a straight face is a credit to their professionalism. That so many people ate it up and loved it is a credit to Ridley Scott. I sit alone however on the other side of the fence. He who wins the love of the people, wins Rome. I get it already!I was hoping that the fight scenes might save this movie but I found Mr. Scott's MTV-style editing style to be distracting. Instead of the nitty-gritty fighting of "Rob Roy" or the impressive scenes in "Braveheart", we got a lot of flash to cover up for the lack of substance.Only Mr. Crowe and his charisma  and impressive Coliseum shots saves this film from a "1".

This movie is an absolute 10 in my book, taken for what it is: a quasi-historical action epic. It's a ride like Hollywood used to make... epic set pieces, characters that you can relate to, incredible action and effects. In the same vein as Unforgiven, Braveheart. You feel for the hero, and you feel the action. Not an Oscar contender per se, but comes close.I can't wait until it comes out on DVD!

I went into this film, not really sure what to expect.  With the likes of G.I. Jane being Ridley Scotts more recent films, i was not expecting a good film.  Well how wrong an i, with Gladiator he has gone back to the days of 'Alien' and 'Blade Runner' where he knew exactly how ro gage the visual impact.  Scott has done with the sword and sandles epic, that he did with the sci-fi genre breathed life into it.  I highly recommend this to action fans, as well as to anybody interested in flims and film making, there are some glorious touches in this piece.  My only downside would be the length a tad long in places might not be to everybody's liking.  Anyway only a small downer, on what is a true blockbuster of a film.

Review title: Magnificent epic? No. Good entertainment? Yes.
Review_body: A number of people have written how this is the best movie that they have ever seen, that it is a magnificent epic, and that it was life changing. Far be it for me to say that they have got it wrong...everyone is entitled to their own opinions after all.I, however, think that some of the acolades given to this film are not warranted.  It is a very entertaining film, and some of the camera work and effects are superb.  But is it a magnificent film that should be in the top 100?  No.  Check your brains at the door, go in looking for a bit of entertainment, and an interesting story line, and you will not be disappointed.  Go in looking for cinematographic brilliance or a life changing event, and you will be sadly disappointed.This film deserves a solid 6/10.

Review title: Some of the images, scenes are just etched into my retina.. gorgeous!
Review_body: Scott absolutely didn't disappoint me here. This is a masterpiece in the same league as Blade Runner and Alien. Some of the scenes are really brilliantly shot, the atmosphere is fantastic, and the battles are so mind-numbing real.. even the sound around you [the onlooker] is numbed after a while of frantic battle. The score's fine too. Especially the ending, and the credits come with some wonderful music.Ridley Scott has done it again.

This movie took my breath away.  i was so amazed at Crowe's performance (as well as the other actor's in the movie) that i even went to see it a SECOND time! It was phenomenial. Gladiator definitly ranks high among such films as: Braveheart, Saving Private Ryan and The Green Mile. I recommend this movie to anyone-- you  won't regret it!!! Starla

ok, u know what? RUSSELL CROWE IS HOT!!! but besides that, he is one amazing actor. i couldn't believe this movie- it was breathtaking. i even saw it twice, to understand what i didn't get the first time around. but it was WELL worth the time and money. i can't wait for it go on video. now, EVERYONE go see this movie!!!! if Crowe doesn't get 'best actor' for his role... i think i'll scream. this guy is a find.. truly top quality acting. so, like i said, GO see this movie! what are u waiting for??? i'm not gonna give u a thesis... that would ruin the ending. don't u wanna be surprised? thought so. ok, just go see it. go now. go again. an again:):):)trust me.LO

Review title: The Best Movie I Have Ever Seen
Review_body: Gladiator is fantastic. As a movie buff I have seen a thousand movies, but none of them can quite compete with Gladiator. I'm too young to have grown up with sword and sandal epics, but I have seen most of them on television, and I was very excited to hear about Gladiator when word initially got out. Now, almost a year later, I have seen the movie 10 times and it keeps getting better. Russell Crowe is amazing. His screen presence is so dynamic that it almost blows you out of your seat. He doesn't have to say a word, just look at the opening sequence with the bird, and you'll know what I mean. He has the audience hooked from the second he walks on screen and right 'til the end. Ridley Scott has made an epic without comparison. The special effects alone are a feast for the eyes. The cast is fantastic. Joaquin Phoenix who I before hand only had seen in "8 MM" was amazing as Commodus. I hated him for everything he did to Maximus and still I pitied him - he just wanted something he had never had - love. As a Dane I was also thrilled to see Connie Nielsen as Lucilla - the rumours about Jennifer Lopez trying out for the part made me laugh - only a woman with Connie's regal stature could pull of the part of sister, love interest and truly politically interested without making any of it look fake. That woman has my utmost admiration. I can't wait to see her next movie. The plot is believable - and heartmoving. As a viewer you feel for Maximus as you make the journey alongside him for a painstakingly two-and-a-half hours. But when he reaches the end, you know it was the only way to end the movie. If Maximus had survived, as he did in the early script drafts, the movie wouldn't have had the same impact. As he dies, he joins the ranks of heroes who, after performing their tasks, goes to the great beyond to join their loved ones. For some reason, seeing Maximus shag up with Lucilla wouldn't have given me quite the same rush as the actual ending of the movie did. Hands up for a Kleenex moment. I've always loved a good cry - and this movie provides it - along with some memorable laughs and smiles, for my part mostly courtesy of Mr. Crowe. And if you don't like Roman Epics, see it for Russell Crowe. The man deserves his following - and an OSCAR - if I had any say in the matter.

This one's a powerhouse. The opening of the movie with a blitzkrieg says it all...General Maximus looks at his soldiers and says 'What you do in life will remain in eternity',before he leads them to one of the most memorable battlefield scenes made in movie history....these moments linger in your mind as the movie unfolds into a larger than life epic. Well crafted and beautifully delivered with a great soundtrack evokes a terrific moviewatching feel. Rusell Crowe is General Maximus turned slave turned Gladiator..no denying that...his fierce menacing eyes says it all..what a performance by him and rest of the cast. Great come back vehicle for RidleyScott. Not to be missed!!

I have no reservations about telling people to see this film. It is very good. However, it isn't one of the all time greats. Like most modern films it relies on special effects and action in place of character and plot. Entertaining? Very much so. Thought provoking? NO.First class eye candy,. I give this film 8/10

Review title: Cinematically lush, but overly dramatic and predictable.
Review_body: It's a good movie to see if you want entertainment and you like gory violence. The battle scenes were fantastic. The plot seemed like an afterthought...overly dramatic and almost silly. The acting was decent, best to see it in the theatres.

Review title: Outstanding! Best film of the Millennium!
Review_body: Great movie....Excellent story line and outstanding cast make for a top notch film.  I went to view this film thinking it was a "guy movie" and left with a whole new perspective.  I recommend this movie for young and old alike and, for that matter, men AND women alike!  A+++!!

What a role model, that Maximus! Excellent plot, cinematography, not over-rated a bit. I also appreciated that the plot wasn't distracted with heavy romance/sex... that would have depreciated the flik. Not as gory as I was led to believe, still - there was gore, but the film was not a horror movie and it was realistic and fast. It contained all the right elements. Great acting, great audience response, an excellent "one man's" epic!

Visually the film is truly amazing, with convincing CGI sequences and amazing attention to detail. The acting is also strong, particularly from Crowe and Reed, with only Phoenix letting the side down. The script was above average for a film of it's magnitude. One of the few great films from Universal in years

Review title: Couldn't take my eyes off the screen
Review_body: Spectacular. Must be seen on a wide screen. Ancient Rome as it surely was. How did they create those crowd scenes. Has any film ever employed so many extras? The story line although weak did not real matter. As a spectacle it is the finest film that I have ever witnessed.

Yeah, so it's not the most historically accurate document on Roman times. Gladiator rules anyway!  Ridley finally hits one out of the park, succeding in delivering not only a very good movie, but one that crosses over to mainstream success... all without compromising his artistic vision, and giving us fans of his work everything we've come to expect from each of his works.Crowe is awesome, Phoenix enjoyably campy... and Oliver Reed, well, this final performance is just a sad reminder of what an amazing performer we have lost.Ten out of ten!

It's a film about Gladiators so where's the gore? Predictable in in the most part, especially for those who are familiar with "The Life Of Brian" or even several Billy Connolly sketches, but moves along at a reasonable pace. I fully expected to see John Cleese selling Otters noses in the arena, and is that really Big Gay Al running the theatre? Manages to keep your interest (it had better - it's a long film) but is a bit lacking in gore. It's a film about Gladiators for goodness sake so a little less mawkishness and a bit more of the old blood and guts wouldn't have gone amiss. It doesn't have to be Texas Chainsaw Massacre but it doesn't have to be Asterix either. And Oliver Reed is fantastic so yah boo sucks to any director who worried about working with him.

Review title: This was clearly the best movie of 2000
Review_body: This was clearly the best movie of 2000. From a well written script to near perfect direction by Ridley Scott who understood the genre in which he was working in. The music as scored by Hans Zimmer can and does stand alone. Every one was ideally suited for their roles from Joaquin Phoenix as the deliciously wicked Commodus to Derek Jacobi's senator. But the film belongs to Russell Crowe who is quickly becoming one of the finest actors of his time. Crowe simple excels as Maximus as man who only wanted to go home and go home he did. All hail Maximus !

Review title: The second time it's even better!
Review_body: I have seen the Gladiator twice and it was even better the second time (which says all about the film). The parallels to Ben Hur (another of my favorites) are extremely strong: the good guy vs. the bad guy, both important persons, both of the same age, the goodlooking but not flashy hero of unwaivering moral integrity, who never lets fury get the better of him (even if provoked), who loses everything he has in life (both lose their family, both lose their status, both become slaves) but nevertheless regains happiness (Ben Hur not only finds his sister and mother but also christian faith, Maximus meets his wife and son after death, another reminder of christian faith.) For all these common aspects, Russell Crowe gives Maximus enough personality to create an entirely new hero.I think the plot is well written, the story intense, the shooting and the computer graphics great. 2 1/2 hrs pass like nothing. I especially appreciated the lack of the nowadays nearly inevitable (but in most cases not only superfluous but also boring) sex-scenes and the happy end that left Maximus with his family and not (out of character) with a new (or old) love.

And his name is Russell Crowe. As Maximus, Crowe is incredibly masculine, heroic and charismatic, yet human, believable and sympathetic. His performance powers this movie in a way very few actors are capable of. When he finally achieves his initial goal, the true goal of every man's heart, all you can do is weep with joy. Gladiator is a much welcome return to artistic form by director Ridley Scott, maybe his best work yet--and that is saying a lot.

This film is drivel.  But it's kinda funny drivel, like when a five year old kid shows you a picture he drew, and its a terrible picture, but you laugh because it's cute that a five year old is proud of his terrible picture. Ridley Scott is the five year old in this case.  Of this nearly 3 hour long film, I would say a good 20 minutes were landscape shots, with a poorly mixed musical chiming in to make them seem important.  Speaking of the score, that battle theme music (again poorly mixed) is more than slightly reminiscent of Gustav Holst's famous "Mars". This film is derivative in so many ways that it hardly matters, but why didn't they just use that piece instead of paying some guy to imitate it? That opening battle scene was the most poorly filmed sequence of events I have seen in awhile.  The cinematography is pretentious and irritating throughout the film.  It's truly terrible, but it seems that everyone involved genuinely wants you to take it seriously.  That makes for good camp at least.  I would like to point out one irony.  The film criticizes Commodus, and the Roman empire in general, for attaining wealth and power by providing trashy entertainment for an unintelligent mob, who love every minute of it.  Well, Gladiator is certainly trashy entertainment, and judging from the user ratings, I'd say the mob loved every minute of it.

This bodes not well for the future of the film industry.  I don't care if the film is historically inaccurate, but a best-picture nominated film should at least exhibit coherent writing and competent art direction.  I guess as long as your decapitating people with swords, you don't have to make a good film to win an oscar.  Ken Lonergan must be gnashing his teeth. Oh well, at least Erin Brokovich got nominated.  Sigh...

A truly worthy film from Ridley Scott.  He has done his homework within the historical context of the story.  All the locations had a unique atmosphere which only added to the realism of the film, and the whole production stands out as having the maximum amount of professionalism devoted lovingly to it, by all concerned.  The first ten minutes alone made my heart pound, and I was hard-pressed to keep tears of amazement back.  The film only got better from there.  Everyone involved deserves an oscar.  The film really puts the audience in the stadium along with the casted actors.  This is how it was back then, folks.  I have never seen anything closer to what the truth must have been.

I think this would make a good film for kids, if it wasn't for all the gore. Kids who are easily impressed and haven't seen a lot of Hollywood movies. Because they are the only ones who wouldn't notice that this movie was made 1000 times before!!! With the exact same flat characters, stupid dialogues and F*ING HOLLYWOOD CLICHÉS! Grrr...

I saw Gladiator at a sneak preview in New York and I must admit, I walked away disappointed.  I felt that the battle scenes at the beginning were too computerized and pixiliated--they just zoomed by so fast that the audience did not have a chance to see what is going on.  Someone later made the comment to me that, "Well, isn't that how you would experience a battle?" And I would have to saw, I don't know, I've never been in one.  But compared to the opening sequence in "Saving Private Ryan" (not a perfect movie, in my eyes, but the opening battle scene was far superior to Galdiator's), Gladiator's battle was all whiz-bang, wham-bam, with no emotion.  I whispered to my seatmate that it was too pixiliated and he whispered back, "That's how they cheat," which pretty much summed it up.As went the opening battle scene, so went all the gladiatorial scenes--all speed, no substance.  I couldn't even tell how the Russell Crowe character won some of the battles, they were whipping by so fast, with such fake, fake computerized effects. To compare, a couple of days after seeing Gladiator, I saw Sparticus on the big screen.  There is only one gladiatorial battle, yet it is much more exciting, suspenseful and real than any of the Gladiator scenes.  I CARED what happened!On a postive note, I did think Joaquin Phoenix's performance was fantastic, as were all of the performances. The computerized amphitheater was also pretty cool looking. Too bad the film makers felt that the computer could somehow take the place of realisticly choreographed gladiatorial fights.

This is the best movie I've ever seen. It's one of those three hour movies that seems like it's an hour long and you're disappointed that it has to end so soon. There is never a dull moment thanks to the outstanding direction of Ridley Scott. The cinematography is equally amazing as is the performance of Russell Crowe. The story is riveting, thrilling, captivating - yet plausible. It has all the ingredients of the perfect guy movie: a villain that you develop a seething hatred for, and a hero with such courage, strength and conviction that you can't help but feel his every pain, share his every emotion, and admire the hell out of him. I was so impressed by the movie I had to go back in the theatre and watch the very next showing.

I would like to say that the special effects where totally awesome.  The scene with the camera breaking through the clouds landing into Rome, was quite remarkable.  And had no problems with any of the acting.  But, I have also watched Rocky IV and Braveheart.  As they started chatting MAXIMUS, MAXIMUS, I found myself ringside, hoping Rocky knocks out Drago.  And can anyone want to defeat the bad guys without killing off the family? Hollywood, AGAIN, fed us another movie, filled with special effects, and a used up story.  Damn computer animation, and the abiltiy to come up with a simple story that moves you without hitting you in every sense but the brain.  I did shed a tear at the last scene.  Kudos for that one. OUT
one of the best movies I have ever seen... Russell Crowe shows his true potential... excellent action I am very impressed by this movie... Probably the best movie made in the year 2000...

I saw this movie first when it came out on the big screen, but unfortunately was not able to fully appreciate it because of the people in the movie theater. Fortunately this Christmas I received the DVD as a gift and was delighted when I watched it. It is just one of those movies that when it ended I wanted to know more. I HIGHLY recommend this movie to EVERYONE! So if you have not seen it yet, please do!

Review title: "Gladiator" has got everything a great movie should offer
Review_body: First of all, I'd like to mention that I didn't go to the cinema to watch "Gladiator" because I'd thought it was only another high-action spectacle with an oversized hero, set in ancient Rome. However, I'll never forgive myself for that mistake, or will forgive Dreamworks for putting so much emphasis on the no-doubt impressive fight sequences (in fact, the trailers rather deterred me from watching this film earlier). It almost made me miss one of the finest movies that in my opinion has ever been produced.The strength of this film is to my mind the fact that it beautifully combines the action part with a good story, a rich dialogue, beautiful shots (with and without CGI) and, above all, excellent actor performances not only by Russell Crowe's portrayal of the title-hero. Likewise, the movie itself is well-balanced because the hero is counterbalanced by an equally convincing "villain", who is brought to life by an absolutely marvelous piece of acting from Joaquin Phoenix. Of course, there might be some smaller detail that could be improved (though I honestly couldn't put my finger on it), but then, who cares? This movie has got well-developed characters, romance and tragedy, deep-running emotions and sheer violence, touching and intimate dialogues and grandiose views, no one could seriously ask for more in a movie of such scale. In any case, this is most certainly more than films like "Braveheart" and "Titanic" have to offer, plus, in Gladiator you've got a Joaquin Phoenix to admire who alone makes the film worthwhile for everyone who appreciates first-rate acting! (And yes, in case you couldn't have guessed by now,I happen to be a great Phoenix-fan since I first saw the movie on dvd.)

I think there's a great difference between a FILM and a common show: Gladiator was made to be a show machine, with special effects that doesn't reproduce realisticly the ancient Rome. It may be not very important, if Rome wouldn't seem a little America, with its peculiarities and its typical characters...  Screenplay is well thought, and goes on, but it remains a simple "epic movie", with its exaggerations and its stereotypes.   (sorry, but my english is not very good...)

Review title: For pure adventure makes Castaways look like childs play
Review_body: From a person who is normally cynical of almost all movies seen in the past few years, and one who rarely sees a film with brutal violence, I still have to rate this film outstanding.  Although not historically accurate from a biographical point of view - it is extremely accurate from the poor gladiators point of view. Yes it happened exactly as the film depicted. The untold slaughter of these poor souls was carried on with Super Bowl style hype for generations for the amusement of the general non-slave citizenry and its patrician class.The acting is good, the plot sound, and the scenes displaying the ancient way of life accurate. Though the results are inevitable, the film is powerful. For anyone whoever wondered what life was like in ancient Rome this movie is a must.  Oh yes, do not be late for the opening scenes, they are terrifyingly  real.

Review title: The Greatest film I´ve ever seen
Review_body: Russell Crowe as Maximus is brilliant and Joaquin Phoenix is great as emperor Commodus. Other actors are equally good. Gladiator is the best film in this year and it deserve title " The best Film 2000". It has everything.!!!

Review title: The best movie I have ever seen
Review_body: Gladiator is very good movie. I hope that it win all 12 Oscars. Russel Crowe and other actors are very good. I have seen this movie already 3 times and I can see it again and again. It is the best movie this year.

Throughout my life I have watched many movies and there are few that I could compare to Gladiator. Everything that makes up the movie contributes to why this movie will be one of the best ever, such as the great plot, character struggles, acting, and historical setting. When I watched this movie the first few times, which has now been years ago, I remember being so embedded in the plot and how the story was developing that I was becoming to feel as if I was in the movie myself. I felt this way mostly because of how well the movie follows the guidelines of what I think the requirements of a good action/adventure/drama should be. While the movie does specifically target people who prefer action, fighting, and history, it can be satisfying for almost everyone because of how well the movie is done, and it shows by the sheer numbers and accolades Gladiator has.
Gladiator released in 2000 at the start of the 21st Century and was under the direction of Ridley Scott, who in 2015 directed The Martian, and is well known for being one of the best in the business. Along with the directing is the amazing acting, award winning acting. The main star in this film is Russell Crowe, who is a widely known actor nowadays because of the films he has been in such as: Noah, The Water Diviner, 3:10 to Yuma, Robin Hood, etc. The other main cast members include Joaquin Phoenix, Connie Nielsen, Oliver Reed, and Richard Harris. These five actors did such an amazing job and their performances did not go unnoticed. In total there were 102 nominations of Gladiator for numerous prizes, from Russell Crowe winning an Oscar for Best Actor in a Leading Role to Ridley Scott getting nominated for Best Director. Out of the 102 nominations it won 59 awards; from the Golden Globe Awards, Academy Awards and BAFTA awards. Before Gladiator dominated all of the award shows of 2000, it became the fourth highest selling movie of the year domestically, and is credited with revitalizing societies interest in ancient Greek and Roman Culture.
In order for a movie that is a drama/action & adventure to do well it needs to accomplish certain things. One of those things is character struggles in both internal and external ways, and I really believe that the way Russell Crowe acts as Maximus is what solidified this. Throughout the movie there are numerous struggles that Russell's character faces, and with each one the audience is getting closer and closer to the edges of their seats. Another thing that makes Gladiator one of the best is the plot, and it begins to start twisting almost as soon as the curtains open. When Roman Emperor Marcus Aurelius (Richard Harris) is murdered by his son Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix), Maximus (Russell Crowe) is arrested because the Emperor wanted him to take his place and not Commodus. While escaping his captors he gets brutally injured to the point he can barely ride a horse, but he must face a long ride, so his family won't meet the same fate he was supposed to meet, execution. After seeing his family murdered, the extrinsic journey of Gladiator really begins. I like this because that is a justifiable reason for revenge through death, and the writers of the movie know this, they appeal to everybody's pissed off emotions that we all felt watching the movie. The only reason this movie is one of the best is because it is the type that you love, but that you hate to watch, because of how well the film puts you in the point of view of the character, and all of the emotions and drama that he faces throughout this film.
Gladiator is one of the best movies ever released because of the acting, plot development, character struggles and historical setting. It isn't easy to make a masterpiece of a movie that is historical and not completely accurate, but this Cast and Crew is basically like a dream team or an all-star team because they pulled it off and can claim they have one of the best movies in history because of it. If you have not seen this movie yet I recommend seeing it as soon as possible. Not only will you be impressed by the splendid acting and story, you will feel as if you are actually watching a real story unfold in front of you. If you are curious about ancient times and love really good dramatic movies, watch this movie and the story it tells, you will not be disappointed.

I admit walking into the theatre to watch 'Gladiator' I thought that it was going to be just a rip-off of 'Spartacus.' I was pleasantly surprised to see that it wasn't the case. 'Gladiator' was a very visualy rewarding film, it was probably the best technical achievement that I seen last year, but on the other hand for it to get an Academy Award nomination for Best Picture was a little much. I believe that it no doubtly deserves to clean up the technical Oscars, but just because it is visually a great film, I don't think that makes it one of the best films of the year. I said the very same thing about 'Titanic' which was an amazing technical film, but to say that it was the best film of the year, or in some cases I heard some people say that it was the best film of the decade, was ubsurd. Just because you spend a lot of money on a film does not mean that it makes it a great film. I feel that it is the same case with 'Gladiator.' Don't get me wrong I really enjoyed this film, but sometimes hype can get the best of me.
Best movie i ever watched in my whole life.Go and see the movie now, if you never watched it before.It is a must see, if you will not cry at the end, then i don't know what to say.
I remember watching this with my dad for the first time back in 2010, now in 2019 it's still a masterpiece

Finally we are back to films that have everything: Great actors (you just love to hate Joaquin Phoenix!), Brilliant music, moving storylines and all the action you could possibly want.  From the historical accuracy to the marvellous recreation of Rome I cannot fault Gladiator.  I have never before seen such a movie that almost (note ALMOST) puts Ben Hur and Spartacus to shame. Russell Crowe deserved his Oscar and it's a shame that Joaquin Pheonix missed out. Brilliantly entertaining and marvellously accurate.
