Review title: This review contains spoilers... it is a close analysis of the opening sequence of the first scene.
Review_body: The general who became a slave; the slave who became a gladiator; the gladiator who defied an emperor. Striking story! "But now, the people want to know how the story ends. Only a famous death will do. And what could be more glorious than to challenge the emperor himself in the great arena?" When a Roman general is betrayed and his family murdered by a corrupt prince, he comes to Rome as a gladiator to seek revenge. Director Ridley Scott uses the contrast of light and dark; peace and war; good and evil to make a unique opening such as the one in Gladiator.Unusual, dramatic, historic. How many films open with historical facts? Not everyone was happy; not everyone likes politics; not everyone is in favour of the Caesars. Gladiator opens dramatically with the appearance of four small paragraphs written in Roman Calligrapher of gold indicating that "over one quarter of the world's population lived and died under the rule of the Caesars." It gives the audience an idea of the past; what it was like to live under the reign of the Caesars! According to the word 'died', it was very unpleasant. This is definitely not a fairy tale story. Set "in the winter of 180 A.D.," one obstacle "stands in the way" of Emperor Marcus, who wants nothing but "victory and the promise of peace through the Empire" fulfilled.The use of close-up of the hand hides the identity to which the hand belongs to. Touching the wheat of the harvest, a part of the body is feeling the pride of an unknown person, satisfied with its field. The sunlight in the background suggest the time of the year: spring or summer. Light is associated with good and the golden tinge makes it seem like a memory or something heavenly, making the surroundings look golden. Or perhaps, the gold was shone because of the fully grown wheat which symbolises there's hope for the world and the young generations. The growth could suggest life and fertility. A wrinkle hand touches the life of the wheat; the wrinkle itself could suggest the age of the unknown identity and by touching the soft wheat, he establishes a memory. The ring on the finger of the wrinkle hand signifies the marriage or engagement of the unknown identity, and the silver suggests his wealth and status in the society of the Roman Empire. It is a sentimental value. Lastly, the black of the sleeves is very symbolic as people believe it relates to death and when there's death, there's a funeral. This person may have returned from a funeral or perhaps it his favourite colour.

Those who applaud this movie do so for it's excitement and action. Those who denounce this film focus on the derivative plot, lack of character development, campy special effects, and sub-par acting. I choose to be with the latter group.This film is worth seeing, in the theater alone, but please don't expect a masterpiece. Gladiator's massive decor is entertaining viewed on a large screen, but that's where the film's success ends. The plot took quite a few ideas from BraveHeart, Spartacus, and other epic period pieces of the past, but in this case, had nothing new to add. I would like to stay away from the comparison's to BraveHeart, but the similarities between this film and the former Oscar winner is too common.  Another highlight of the film is Phoenix's character, Commodus. If you don't already know, the commode's namesake was this Caesar, so you can basically conjure up the outcome of this evil emporer.I highly recommenend this movie if you enjoy 'neat' fighting scenes and 'cool' special effects. But I am still baffled from the fact that this picture is receiving so much attention from the Acadamy Awards. This film, like Titanic, will not stand the test of time.

Gladiator was, without a doubt, my favorite movie of 2000, thus far.  I am not a huge action kinda guy, but this movie actually had a tremendous storyline and magnificient performances by Russell Crowe and Joaquin Pheonix.  With staggering battle scenes on the battlefields and in the collesuem, this film was absolutely the definition of a great epic. Crowe's performance deserves an Oscar for Best Actor, though I am sure they will give it to Tom Hanks or Ed Harris, which is fine by me.  I am sure Crowe will get his Oscar in the future sometime.  Richard Harris's role as the aging emperor is also good, and should have been noticed for Best Supporting Actor.  All and all this film is truly and beautifully shot and exciting action/drama worth seeing 50 times.

Once again, Director Ridley Scott proves to be as professional as one can be. The recreation of ancient Rome is splendid, with all its magnificent buildings and atmosphere and he is able to show with all brightness the greatness of the Roman Empire, with its political problems and military discipline, and love and treason, of hate and jealousy, that still have a place in our world today. But the story has a glow of its own, to which all the beautiful scenery and great cinematography are just balancing factors. The plot is a rich one, that is as dynamic as it is present. He once again, after Blade Runner, 1492, and others helps us visit the depths of the human soul, which remains the same over all our historical and social experience.

I would never say that the Acadamy Awards mean anything, but still I must say that I take a perverse pleasure out of watching the whole affair. Ridley Scott's Gladiator will most definitely go down in history as one of the most gaudy, inept pieces of commercial pap to come down the tube in a long time.  In terms of films that have been nominated for Best Picture, it will rank right up there with Cimarron (and that won!).  Have a little perspective, people--there were some great films made this year, and this is an ugly little movie.  With barely the inclination to turn its own lens on the idea of our modern audiencing of violence (a theme that would seem pretty obvious, and fairly easy to follow up on), Gladiator is another example of our movie going cultures' willingness to be spoon-fed every little detail, and unwillingness to be the least bit reflective. Did anyone see Hannibal (another Scott crap-sterpiece)?  Is there anything left for the imagination these days?

Review title: A good film being confused as a great film
Review_body: This movie basically came off as I expected, a good film, fun to watch with a lot of eye candy. However, a great film it is not nor will it ever be (let's see what history has to say). The script is horrid and predictable. Crowe does his job, maintain a dark and quiet intensity throughout the film (much like L.A Confidential, a projection that he did even better in that film than in Gladiator). The character of Commodus, with all of his flaws, was perhaps the most inept bit of scriptwriting I have seen (in a film that is supposed to be of high quality with great writing). Some have said that he lets down his guard and shows us a pitiable side (and a depth of character). There is nothing that comes across as pitiable. He wallows in self-pity, and when combined with his depravity as a human being, there is nothing there to like, nevermind find sympathy for. The script took an easy way out by giving us an antagonist that is far too easy to hate. If there was anyone deserving of a "best supporting actor" oscar nomination, it was Richard Harris as Marcus Aurelius and not Joaquin Phoenix. All in all, it was a good film, fun to watch, not quite as nice on the tv screen as the movie screen, and definitely not deserving of a best picture nomination (take off chocolat and gladiator (saw all 5 nominated) and put up Almost Famous and Billy Elliot for the award...now those are great films and worthy of the honor).

This film has all of the intensity and drama you could wish for in an action/drama.  Russell Crowe gives a stellar performance as Maximus and is definitely securing himself as a major leading man.  If you have not yet seen this film, GO GET IT!!!

Warning: some spoilers ahead!My personal impression of this film is that it is a good film, but I wouldn't have given it so many oscars as it got(my choice there would have been the Ang Lee film instead). Let me explain. The movie is set in a very realistic roman environment and its clear that the makers of this movies intention was to make it feel as a genuine part of roman history. I don't think the movie quite succeeds on this point. If you look below the surface the typical American stereotypes are even so present. Like for example when Maximus says "Bring em hell on my command". Its really ludicrous that such a line is in this move. Its just like something that Sylverster Stalone, Bruce Willis or some other American macho-hero would say. Lines like that fit in their particular genre but here its really silly and I am not even sure that the concept of "hell" was invented at the time the story takes place.Its really hard to pin down the exact details where the sterotypes shine through but they are present. Instead of being pictured as a person with many sides the emperor is pictured as an althrough evil person. Just like the standard "badguy" in any standard hollywood action movie. When the emperor cheats by stabbing Maximus with a dagger we are supposed to get the impression that the people view this as a very injust thing to do. I'm not so very sure that the morale of that time really worked that way. Why would the people care about a gladiator? And why would an emperor fight a duel with a slave? That seems just like something an American macho-emperor would do, nothing for a civilized roman if you see my point. Anyway too much of the American culture shows through in this movie in subtile ways. This makes the movie less interesting than it could have been. I guess the American audience will never notice this and maybe thats why it got so many oscars. To me it was entertaining to see once but nothing more than the fantastic scenography and some music in it is worth remembering. All in all it adds up to grade 7 in my opinion.

Review title: Great film! Read this and then see it!
Review_body: Gladiator, I thought, was an excellent movie in abundant ways. It was not only visually stunning, but the characters and the feel of the movie made you actually feel as if you were really there. I gave this a ten, and (if you haven't yet) once you've seen it you will too. I will admit that it is wildly graphic, but I like how it really gives meaning to the word "combat." The movie (to sum it up) is about a general named Maximus. This is in ancient Greece/Rome. "Ceasar" (not the (italic) Ceasar, but...) knows his life is ending but wants to crown Maximus Ceasar, instead of his (I think I will be...) son. His son then overthrows his dad and becomes Ceasar. He orders Maximus to be killed, but instead Maximus gets away, becomes a slave, is bought, becomes a very good Gladiator, and that's the movie (kinda). See it!

I went to the movie theater to go see a good action filled with fighting and bloodshed.  Instead, I witnessed a truly awesome story that happened to have some fighting and bloodshed.  From the acting to the directing, and especially to the screenplay, this movie is spectacular!Russell Crowe turns in a fine performance.  Many of his critics who feel that he shouldn't have won an Oscar for his performance are taking it one step further and saying that he was downright dull.  I don't know if Crowe deserved the Best Actor Oscar, but I do know that dull he was anything but. He is the only one I know who could have played Maximus and given him any depth and at the same time be convincingly intimidating.  Kudos to the arguably best actor in showbiz!Joaquin Phoenix's work as Commodus was severely underrated.  It didn't take but one minute before I hated Commodus with a deep hatred.  His scenes with Lucilla (Connie Nelson) are just plain eerie, causing me to hate him more.
This is easily Ridley Scott's best job as a director.  He gives "Gladiator" an elegance and a darkness that together make the movie quite unique.This is my all-time favorite movie and I think anyone who doesn't go see it is losing out!

Gladiator is probably my favourite movie ever - if not, it's my favourite period piece without a doubt.I love anything to do with ancient Rome. This movie, although not entirely historically accurate (nor is it meant to be - but it still is realistic), really draws you in with it's sets, colour palette, and storyline.Connie Nielson does an incredible performance. Russell Crowe + Joaquin Phoenix have a compelling energy in their scenes together, but also individually throughout the movie.Overall, 10/10 for me

Joaquin Phoenix annihilated this role with his terrific performance and he is definitely one of the best villains ever written. It should have ended a few seconds after his death, but it kept on going and somehow those last 70 seconds made it lose a star for me. Despite the historical inaccuracy I still managed to enjoy it (even if the frustration got the best of me).

Take one part awesome, one part incredible, and one part inspiring and you have one of the greatest movies of all time. Easily on my top ten list this movie "defines" good movie making. With incredible cinematic deftness Mr. Scott has outdone himself, I doubt he will ever be able to top this masterpiece he has created with no little help from incredible actors, Crowe, Phoenix, and the rest of the spectacular cast helped to bring life to this film in ways I have never seen before. The talent brought on by all creative teams involved is amazing and I can only hope that more films will follow in the footsteps of excellence that this fine production has laid out. A true 10 without question.

**SPOILERS**It saddens me to see so many uninformed and under-intelligent reviews for this film, which is unfortunatly the same for many other films on this site, "Russel Crowe was pathetic" is one comment,  this user must have been blind or concentrating too much on their popcorn to realise that this could not be more wrong. The comment on the box, "Russel Crowe's performance hits the screen with such force that you can't rip your eyes away" is far more closer to the truth, the film deserved very much the oscars that it received.Many would see this movie as old by now, but I am writing this today after watching it again and after all these years, it still has the same staying power that it had when I watched the first time.The movie is about a Roman general who has the utmost pride and loyalty to the Emporer, played by Richard Harris. Who has been betrayed by his son, Claudius, **Spoiler** who murders Richard Harris's character in order to circumvent his father's decision that Claudius will not be emporer after his father dies.  In order to succeed the throne against that wish. ** End Spoiler **There after, the General, "Maximus" played by Russel Crowe is also betrayed by the mentally disturbed Claudius, who murdered maximus's family because Maximus would not swear loyalty to Claudius as the New Emporer.
Maximus ends up as a slave to fight in the gladiator battles that Claudius has planned.Maximus now sets out to get revenge on Claudius and from there the plotline develops into a tangled web of good versus evil, in places it seems that the good will not prevail and in others you think that it might. Quite a twister!One thing I will say is that there is probably too much gore throughout the film, although this is balanced by the fact that games such as those actually happened in Roman times and probably were a lot more gruesome, something to think about....Anyway I think that there was no need for so much gore to get the plotline accross effectivley.The ending leaves no loose ends, which improves my opinion of the film considerably.Loose ends really annoy me at the end of films, some of the films that I had initially thought were good, end up with disappointing endings and many loose ends, which greatly reduce my final opinion of them.If I was to give an overall opinion of this film, I'd say that this is probably the best film I have seen to date, followed closely only by "Titanic", "Lord Of The Rings" and/or "Men In Black"10 out of 10 See it if you havn't and watch it again if you have! LOL :)

Having grown up watching historical epics like "Ben-Hur", "Spartacus" and "El Cid" it was wonderful to see this type of film making a comeback. The first film I watched on this scale was Cecil B Demille's "The Ten Commandments" starring Charlton Heston which even now still amazes me how they achieved those effects seeing as the film is now 50 years old.However, where the older films costumes seemed to be a little too clean, there was an element of realism in the look of this film. I cannot flaw any part of it. It has very strong performances from Russell Crowe (a well deserved Oscar winner), Joaquin Phoenix, Connie Nielsen, Djimon Hounsou as well as veteran actors Oliver Reed and Richard Harris. It was beautifully made and designed, accompanied by an excellent dramatic score which captured the elements perfectly. I thought it was a wonderful story which everyone can relate to about a man (Maximus, played by Russell Crowe) who just wants to go home to his family and his journey to get there "a general who became a slave, a slave who became a gladiator, a gladiator who defied an emperor". Despite the sadness of our hero dying at the end it was also happy as he had freed Rome from the dictatorship of rival Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix) and returned to his family in the after life. The look of the film was so real it made me believe that they had actually built models of Rome and had all those people in the Colosseum and all those soldiers were on the battlefield of Germania. I loved the fact they did not feel they needed to glamorise it just to put bottoms on seats unlike other epic films like "Titanic" and "Pearl Harbour" which had to put a love triangle in the movie which to me ruined the background events.In short, one of my favourite films and the best epic ever!

Review title: Maximus, the great general of Rome, turned into a slave, a Gladiator. He fought for Rome and his mentor and idol, Marcus Aurelius.
Review_body: Maximus, the great general of Rome, turned into a slave, a Gladiator. He fought for Rome and his mentor and idol, Marcus Aurelius. Maximus wished to rid Rome of the oppression of Commodus, the greedy and power hungry son of Marcus Aurelius. He does so, but he dies in the process. His death however wasn't tragic, in fact it was happy, as he ended with his reunion with his family.Gladiator was all about Maximus, a general in the roman army under Marcus Aurelius. Maximus braves yet another battle, in which he ends victorious. The emperor, proud of Maximus, offered him the position as emperor after he died. Maximus was to think on the offer. But Commodus, the son of the emperor, killed his father, and hence claimed the thrown of Rome. He ordered Maximus's death but the general escaped. But his escape was futile, as his family was murdered by Commodus's men. Broken hearted and worn out, Maximus was captured to become a slave and was sold off as a Gladiator. He later fought as one, killed Commodus and died himself.

After finally getting to see this film, I wondered what all the fuss was about. By the end I was bored to death by the trite story and corny dialogue. The special effects are terrible (as bad as any film of the 1950s about ancient Rome), and it is only saved somewhat by the fact that the actors (if a little camp) seemed to believe that this was real life. And who chose the terrible music that burdened the film with meaning it did not possess? Has anyone noticed that when millions of dollars are spent on a film (Titanic, Pearl Harbor, Gladiator), very little of that is channelled into the dialogue? In the end the only thing that holds these films together are the actors (not all, but usually just enough of them).As my parents used to say, they don't make films like they used to. Well, they do still make good films, but only if there is a very strict budget.So, thumbs down.

Review title: Powerful acting makes this an epic film
Review_body: An impeccable film set in ancient Rome sends us on an emotional, adventurous, and entertaining journey. Maximus (Russell Crowe) leads the Roman legions to victory in their final battle against the Germanic tribes and longs for nothing more than seeing his wife and son back in Spain. Knowing Maximus owes him his loyalty, the Emperor audaciously over looks his son and rightful heir to the thrown and ask Maximus to succeed him. His son hearing about this plots for Maximus to be killed. Though Maximus escapes his assassin, he gets back to Spain only to find his wife and son murdered by the Emperor's son's orders leaving him devastated and broken. He is then sent into slavery to become a Gladiator and if that's not enough, he has to fight and entertain the very man who killed his family. Will he get his revenge? This is one of my favorite films of all time. It's absolutely worth your time.Spiritual Content: Many references to "the gods." Maximus talks about the "Elysian Fields," a paradise of classical mythology. Maximus carries small statues to represent his family and ancestors and prays to them. The film several times shows Maximus imagining meeting his family in the afterlife, symbolized by going through a door into wide, green fields.Sexual Content: Nothing explicit. There is a barely hinted-at past between Maximus and Lucilla, and the film leaves open the question of whether Lucilla's son, Lucius, is Maximus' child. A gladiator master asks a man, "What do you want, a girl? A boy?" Commodus makes several incestuous advances against his sister, Lucilla.Violent Content: Frequent and extreme. The film opens with a headless Roman soldier on horseback and the Germanic leader taunting the Romans with the soldier's head. Opening battle scene shows men impaled by spears, pinned to trees by arrows, and frequent killing by sword. Gladiatorial combat features just about every possible way to kill a man short of nuclear weapons. To his credit, Director Scott does not dwell on gore; once the point is made that a man has been killed, the camera moves elsewhere. Still, the gruesome images burn deep.Crude or Profane Language: A woman is called a b--ch. One s-word.Drug and Alcohol Content: Little. Emperor drinks wine.Summary: Gladiator is a great film cinematically. The acting is powerful and the story is strong, even if it is a bit of a rehash of the Ben-Hur story—without the redemptive ending. Still, I left the theater feeling vaguely ill-at-ease, and it took me several hours to figure out why. I then realized that the degeneracy shown on screen—Emperor Commodus happily clapping his hands as a gladiator is decapitated, the crowd roaring its blood-lust—is too close to some forms of entertainment today, particularly professional wrestling. The gladiators of Rome took on certain contrived personalities, and gladiatorial combat was intended to tell some sort of story, just like today's equivalent of gladiatorial entertainment. And as the crowd's appetite was whetted by increasingly bizarre and violent combat, so too are today's wrestling maniacs. Gladiator serves as an object lesson as to what can happen to a society that proceeds down such a violent path. The extreme violence used to create that lesson, however, prohibits children and teens (and will dissuade many adults) from getting a chance to experience it.

after a row of forgettable films Ridley Scott returned to former glory with this glorious adventure straight out of the realms of the 60's peplums(which can still be seen every easter and Xmas,full of adverts,on TV.it was surely a risk,however, ticket sales,DVD sales,critical reviews and a handful of Oscars,showed the production team had got it right.what they hadn't got right was historical correctness,the list of errors is longer than the final credits,but who cares,this is a film to sit back and enjoy,not improve your knowledge of roman history.a visually beautiful movie,with wonderful performances by all involved,gladiator has something unusual in todays cinema for the masses,Maximo.Crowe's interpretation of the general as a family man,loyal comrade is full of fateful exoticism perfect for the times he lived in,and worthy of Crowe's place as a great actor'.

Unlike many Hollywood blockbusters, the huge-budget special effects are justified.  The Colosseum scenes are truly visceral, and it took a giant budget to really bring them to life.However, there's nothing in this movie that will enrich or edify you in any way, and it doesn't stand up to repeated viewing the way a top notch film would.Utterly undeserving (in contrast to "Spartacus" and "Ben Hur", both of which having uplifting messages and strong acting to go along with Roman period pic fun) of Oscars, but not a complete waste time, especially if you see it on the big screen, where some of the imagery will linger with you.(Some small spoilers follow).I will cite this irony in Gladiator's defense:  Some of the 'cheesiest' parts of the film are also the closest to historically accurate.  For instance, Joachim Phoenix's performance will constantly remind you that he's an actor 'playing Commodus.'  The irony here is that by the best historical accounts, Phoenix nailed it;  Commodus *was* an actor, playing himself. (Also, he did enter the gladiatorial contests, and was a complete lunatic).The wistful longing for the Republic was probably passe by the time of the passing of Marcus Aurelius (known as the last of the "Five Good Emperors"), but certainly something that had been a common sentiment in Rome for the first two centuries after Augustus (mostly due to the motley crew of idiots, lunatics and monsters who ruled immediately after him).

Review title: Highly Overrated Popcorn Movie about Ancient Americanized Rome
Review_body: Somehow many people seem to like this Roman empire set action drama flick. I'm definitely not one of them.It's a cheap, yet expensive, excuse of a story, already seen a thousand times (i.e. basically revenge), to cover the real reason for this movie: the fights. In this it is quite similar to 'Braveheart'. It falls far behind many, if not most, other films taking place in the same era, like 'Spartacus' or 'Ben Hur', although these included action scenes, too.The monetary success most likely originates from the same reasons that sports do--among them handsome people, villains/opponents, heroism, "blood, sweat & tears", and plenty of pathos. I honestly think this ultimately proves that today's people would visit real, bloody gladiator fights, if they were still allowed.I must confess that I didn't watch it on the big screen, so maybe I missed the full beauty of larger-than-life landscapes and deaths, after all it was pretty well done technically. It also was dubbed in German.

If you go into this movie expecting straight-up action packed scenes, a muscular hero, and the blood and gore that we've come to expect then you will get what you want, but soooo much more.  This movie has all a good action movie should have; a ton of fighting scenes with blood flying everywhere and a central hero who is unstoppable.  On top of that Gladiator is a story that highlights an ancient empire, both its glory and its corruption.  Russel Crowe is stunning as a humble, softspoken general who becomes a slave and fights, at first to keep his life, and later, to save an empire.  Russel Crowe is incredible as can also be seen in A Beautiful Mind and is one of the greatest actors of our day.  Crowe manages to play a gladiator who, although he fights for a living and does it amazingly well, also can be caring and humble. Joaquin Phoneix plays just his opposite and is also incredibly good.  In this movie you hate him so much because he is able to play a bad guy who you can't stand and want to see die a horrible death.  But that is what makes him so good.  He is ruthless and cunning, but is blind to his flaws and his hunger for power.  I think both of these actors are great in this film but Crowe takes the cake because he's the good guy and he's the one you're rooting for.  The scenery is also breathtaking as the filmmakers recreate ancient Rome including the palace and the Colesseum.  Of course since these places don't exist entirely anymore they were all computer generated but are blended in superbly and it looks like they're actually there.  This movie is definetly in my top 3 movies ever and perhaps I dare to say my number 1 ever.

Review title: One of the greatest films ever made.
Review_body: Gladiator is a thrilling tale of a Roman general who must battle against all thinkable odds to avenge the death of his family and restore justice to the empire.  Ridley Scott creates a magical, believable, and effortless picture of ancient Rome.  The score is beautiful, and perfect for each scene we come across.  Perhaps the best part of this film is the performance of Russel Crowe as Maximus, the lead character.  Crowe creates a heroic yet human character who demands both attention and respect.  Joaquin Phoenix is wonderful as the antagaonist, Commodus, and the rest of the roles fit in without err.  Gladiator is one of the greatest films ever made.  It entertains.  It thrills.  It terrifies.  And, most importantly, it inspires everyone who sees it.  Absolutely incredible film.

Gladiator is an ill-conceived Braveheart knockoff with a tired, predicable plot. Joaquin Phoenix, is unbearable as a one dimensional, stereotyped, sniveling, overwrought, incestuous Roman villain. Russell Crowe's performance was fine, satisfactory--as usual, but certainly not particularly inspired or stalwart. He is one of Hollywood's most overrated actors. The action sequences were entertaining and well choreographed, but story and originality of plot and characters suffered. Gladiator is standard, action fare, albeit with a setting infrequently revisited in recent years. What a shame this won best film.

I like to try to "switch" roles in movies; then when the actors/actresses just don't measure up the same way the final cast does, then we can see just how hard casting directors must work to fulfill this delicate cog of the silver-screen wheel.Russell Crowe as Maximus was a role just for that actor. Also the Emperor Commodus, played by Joaquin Phoenix, that part was well cast. But the two fine actors just cannot be reversed with the roles, can they? Of course not.The medium of movies requires tons of man-hours, equipment, then post-production, etc., all of this just to tell a story, entertain people for a very short time. Gladiator was that movie that utilized all available facilities and human potential to closely portray this tale of the Roman Empire circa 180 A.D. This movie really did not stray too far from reality as a lot of movies do, just for the entertainment value. We do know that the Coliseum existed, have historical accounts that closely resemble the living conditions and daily life of the people of 180 A.D.Gladiator has a moral center in which the main characters never waved from even when it could be expected to do so under such conditions.Maximus drove everything he had to accomplish what he did, against the insurmountable odds, and that makes a great story.

And therefore you can complain about this and that perhaps with good reasons but you got to get over it cause the fact is that it is a great movie "YES A MOVIE" and truth is that there are those who are much worse (The Last Legion for example), so try to enjoy the movie aside from historical errors which will always appear and accept it (to a certain degree) So enjoy this fantastic movie and love it :) Vennlig hilsen Simen

Review title: Who said it was based on a true story?
Review_body: I've just finished re-watching this film for the 20+ time and felt compelled to search IMDb to find those who believe it to be anything other than a magnificently crafted film and why.From what I could gather the common point of contention was that this film was not in fact linear to the actual course of history. So what? Does every film that is based on a period of the past need to be historically accurate? Ie. Shawshank Redemption, L.A. Confidential, The Mummy, Saving Private Ryan, 300, Inglorious Basterds etc. The answer is simple - NO! It's called creative license and it's been used by authors/script-writers for countless years.If you wish to watch something that has been extensively researched and is historically accurate then find yourself a nice documentary! In the meantime, accept this film for what it is; A beautiful recipe of directing, acting and music that combine to make one of the all-time great films.10/10

Without a shadow of doubt this is one of the best movies ever made and certainly the making of Russell Crowe. Crowe puts in a performance of epic stature as the General Maximus Meridius and its brilliantly directed by the awesome Ridley Scott. Never thought Mr.Scott could surpass 'Blade Runner' or 'Alien' but I think this movie has everything and some!! I just cannot say enough about this film except believe the hype - I've just watched the extended blu-ray version (all but 3 hours) and its as good now as the first time I watched it. Every actor in this film puts in a stellar performance - as well as Crowe there is Joaquin Phoenix as the much reviled Commodus, the amazing Richard Harris as an all but too brief Marcus Aurilius, Dijimon Hounsou as the slave Juba and other great performances from the likes of Connie Nielsen, Oliver Reed, Thomas Arana amongst others. Not for one moment during the entire movie do you find yourself losing interest - it is just totally engrossing to the last minute.

Gladiator is the film that first made me truly appreciate Ridley Scott as a director. I was a fan of Russel Crowe before this film but his spectacular performance as Maximus made me appreciate his acting skills even more.I won't go through the plot because let's face it, you've probably already read up about the it however I will say that although the plot is amazing, it is not spectacular. I believe that what made this film amazing was a combination of the incredible acting, directing, scriptwriting and the incredible soundtrack. The fight scenes in this film are some of the best I have seen, there is one specific scene that I have in mind. If you have seen Gladiator, I am sure you will know which one I am talking about.Gladiator is one of my favorite films of all time and it will remain that way. The only reason I did not give this masterpiece a 10/10 is because I do not believe that any film, or anything is truly 'perfect', but Gladiator is pretty damn close.

Review title: Everything you could want, and more...
Review_body: (some spoilers, not many)Some people lament this films not-completely-accurate interpretation of ancient history, citing that though a good deal *is* accurate, other parts are not. Others deem this film unworthy due to the fact that it was too "Hollywood".While both are valid points, I don't believe them to be at all damaging to what should be the central part of every great movie - not the cinematography, not the score, nor even the acting - but the story. A good story tells itself, as all of us should know, and a good story can overcome any other limitations.Gladiator does just that.Reminiscent at times of Spartacus, at others of the infamous "I, Claudius" series, Gladiator does a good job of introducing people (many who probably have only cursory knowledge of anything prior to when they were born unfortunately) to ancient times, with obvious emphasis on Rome.The depictions of the Roman senate are correct. All of the soldier's equipment is also accurate, as are the tactics employed in the opening battle sequence. Yes, yes, yes - there was no such thing as a "thumbs up" at the true Gladitorial games, but there have to be some sacrifices to relate to the non-historically inclined.Ultimately however, the story is what truly shines. And I'd say it's as non-Hollywood as they come in some essential ways. First of all, our hero and protagonist, Maximus, is not your typical hero, bursting with bravado and dropping one-liners like some bronze-age Swarzenegger. He is a capable man, thrust into a role he wants no part of. Right from the beginning, it is established that all he truly wants is to return home to his family, and nothing more. He dreams neither of glory, nor wealth, but peace after many years of war.The terrible tragedy that befalls him is not of his own doing - he is a politically naiive man, defamed and stripped of rank by politicians, an entity he cannot comprehend. Embittered by the betrayal of the nation that he fought so hard to protect and expand, Maximus is a sullen, resigned character, who only shows brief spurts of contentment throughout the rest of the film - and after what happened to him and his family, he has every reason to feel this way.Ultimately, as may (or may not) be a surprise, in VERY much anti-Hollywood fashion, our hero dies at the end. After all he has accomplished, all he suffered, he still dies anyway. This made me quite sad actually, but enhanced the emotional pull of the picture ten fold. As an almost unwritten rule, the hero does not die. Sure, he may get beaten, stabbed, shot up, and sworn at, but in the end, he still lives, gets the girl, and life goes on...None of that happened here, and so we were fortunate to bear witness to one of the few great cinematic moments of the last decade.9.5/10On a purely "guy" note - wonderful combat. Enough blood and hacking and slashing to keep me properly entertained :0)

Either you want to make a movie which is true to the facts (as we know them) or you just want to make a big screen spectacle, not bothering too much about the details. This movie is neither. Considering all the "realistic" scenes and scenery, it wants to be a depiction of true historical facts, but it is not! So for people who know a little bit about Roman history it is hard to take the story very seriously, but, on the other hand, because the makers seem to take it very seriously, it is hard to watch it as simple entertainment.To name only a few examples. Which Roman general would ever leave his troops in the middle of a (political) conflict? His army is his power basis. Of course, had Maximus done the most sensible thing and called his army for help, then Commodus would have been wiped out and the movie would have been over within 15 minutes. But no, Maximus runs, away from his army.Second example. In the end, when Maximus returns to Rome as a famous gladiator, he is recognized by people who remember him as general Maximus. Remember, when he became a gladiator, it wasn't as general Maximus, but as an anonymous. Is he released....? No, but only because the story dictates that we should wait for the climax, not for any logical reason.The coincidence that Maximus, fleeing from Germany to Spain on foot, which would have taken a few months at least, finds his house still smoking is just too much.So maybe the old Hollywood epic historical movies didn't look so realistic (actors were clean and had white teeth), but Errol Flynn and Douglas Fairbanks were so much more fun to look at, because they didn't take it all too seriously.

Review title: The singing,dancing Hollywood extravaganza goes back to Rome.
Review_body: I was absolutely shocked by the rating this movie got here and elsewhere, I thought it was a poorly written, pseudo-histroric dribble.<Some spoilers ahead>First-off, the story. I'm pretty sure it's been ripped-off from "Fall of the Roman Empire", removing all original parts from it and replacing them with various "gritty" decapitation and disenbowling incidents. The characters are fac-similies of any cheesy action blockbuster role: the vengeful general-turned-gladiator, the power-mad emperor and the grieving orphaned-widow only searching for a little tenderness, c'mon!! The story evolution itself is lacking: the people of Rome are ready to rebel just because they like some gladiator's fighting-style, and the praetorian guard who kill Maximus' family and allies suddenly turn to help him on a whim. Any attempt for character studiy is abruptly interrupted by more gore-tastic antics.Now the acting. Let me say that this is not one of Crowe's good acting days. I loved him in the "Insider" and a "Beautiful Mind", but here, he is wooden and amateurish: they say the indicator of a bad actor is his "angry scenes", well Crowe's look-at-the-ground-tense-my-biceps-ball-my-fists-and-growl routine (the very same from L.A Confidential, just different costumes) is definitely an indicator. Joaquin Phoenix, an amazing actor normally, is bogged down in his horrible, horrible, role. Even Richard Harris's and Oliver Reed's stellar performances aren't enough to save this picture.Finally, the history. First-off, Commodus wasn't a power-hungry arrivist, he was a retarded, fornicating party-boy who had to be dragged to the throne. Secondly, all historians agree that Marcus-Aurelius died of natural causes. The historic details are so badly done that some latin shop signs have spelling errors (it's not my opinion, I read it in a film magazine).It seems Ridley Scott is about to join the hallowed mass of directors with great technique but no regard to content.

Gladiator is an underrated movie to say the least. It should be on the top 10, and in my book it's at position 1. People tend to think it's bad because it's not 100% historically accurate. Guess what, it's not a documentary, it shouldn't be judged as one.The dialogue is strong and the story is the one we all love, and it plays out without flaw in Gladiator. The movie sets a new standard for the definition of epic. If you watch Spartacus or Ben-Hur after Gladiator, you notice how plain and un-epic those movies are in comparison. All the actors performed flawlessly, especially Joaquin Phoenix (should have won an Oscar) and Connie Nielsen, I love the "Am I not merciful" scene, so much emotion with so few words. No single actor could be replaced to make this a better movie, it was a perfect cast.The musical score is magnificent, it's so in sync with the action and the emotions on the screen, and so majestically epic, it's in itself destined to become a classic. Too bad Hans Zimmer was robbed of the Oscar.The scenery is phenomenal, the landscapes are perfect, the CGI is top notch. You can FEEL the grandness of Rome. Splendid use of light and color in every single scene. I especially like the scene where Commodus and Maximus are elevated on to the arena, protected by a tortus formation of praetorian guards.Are you not entertained? ARE you not entertained? YES, yes we ARE. Maximus, Maximus, Maximus, Maximus...10/10 - A classic.

Once again, Director Ridley Scott proves to be as professional as one can be. The recreation of ancient Rome is splendid, with all its magnificent buildings and atmosphere and he is able to show with all brightness the greatness of the Roman Empire, with its political problems and military discipline, and love and treason, of hate and jealousy, that still have a place in our world today. But the story has a glow of its own, to which all the beautiful scenery (believe me, it's awesome!!!) and great cinematography are just balancing factors. The plot is a rich one, that is as dynamic as it is present. He once again, after Blade Runner, 1492, and others helps us visit the depths of the human soul, which remains the same over all our historical and social experience. Even the fights, are displayed in such a way that all the blood is quite discrete, but still, making us feel like screaming and jumping out of our seats. I would also like to point out the performances of the cast, that is surprisingly good. We have some actors and actresses, who are not Hollywood icons, but are are greatly able to move the audience among screams and tears. All in all, we have guys like Russel Crowe, who are coming out to be part of a new and extremely promising harvest of people who are making each time more fans around the world. Well, you should see for yourself!

This is one of my favorite films, and having watched the DVD recently I still find it to be a tremendous movie, excusing its liberties with history and minor plotting niggles. However, one of the most refreshing aspects of the film was that, as an Englishman,it eased my movie paranoia. A major epic, internationally successful- and the villain's played by AN American! And the hero isn't! And most of the "Good guys" are played by Brits! If recent Hollywood epics (E.G "Braveheart","The Patriot", the one where the bloody boat sinks) are anything to go by, we English are all sadistic, devious, perverted Nazis! (Actually, the whole "need a villain, get in a Brit" thing goes a long way back- George Sanders as Shere Khan, Basil Rathbone and Alan Rickman as Sherrifs of Nottingham ) And if "Private Ryan" and "U571" are anything to go by, we just curled over and downright surrendered to Hitler without a squeak! (Mind you- does anyone remember Errol Flynn in "Mission Burma"?- plus ca change, plus c'est la meme chose, as the French sometimes say, when they're not too busy collaborating with Germans (That's a joke, by the way). Oh well, it's nice to see a thoughtful film with a memorable cast and visual appeal go down well with the public. Am I the only one who thinks that cinema goers are getting a bit brighter and perceptive? I hope I'm right.

Review title: A movie for the more philistine viewer
Review_body: It is a pity that the type of person who thinks that this movie is "great" is the same type of person who thinks that a Clint Eastwood movie is better than a John Wayne movie, and who is interested in shallowness and simplicity, shallow entertainment with no depth. Such viewers would be perfect public at the Colisseum where the final struggle takes place. The movie is a rather poor remake of "Fall of the Roman Empire", a movie which was not memorable but which had some point to it, for it showed the way in which the Northern blonde people were shamelessly butchered which provoked the reaction which was to seal the fate of Rome. That movie had a more elaborate story and showed how a system can go wrong. There is a worrying trend in these epic remakes such as Gladiator, The Passion of the Christ and to a much lesser extent Troy (Troy is actually quite a good movie) for gratuitous violence and no real message, no real humanity or depth. It seems we have regressed to Roman times. It is almost like we have become blood thirsty and unchristian.
Stands shoulder to shoulder with the greats like 10 commandments, Ben Hur etc.

Review title: If this were a novel, it would be terrible
Review_body: Historical inaccuracy aside, the movie features a reactive protagonist who only wins because the antagonist is a total idiot. Fights come his way and the protagonist fights because he has to. He is a fighter from the beginning, he doesn't learn anything new. The only character development to be seen is probably his depression.Major SPOILER:The antagonist is stupid and miserable and nobody on earth likes him. He has neither brains nor charisma. He is insane and hopeless from the beginning. And then he, the emperor, challenges the best gladiator to a fight.

"Gladiator" is a classic contemporary piece of Hollywood Production. It sees Russell Crowe as Maximus a general within the Roman Army betrayed and framed by the Emperor's corrupt son and exiled as a result. However, he becomes a gladiator to seek his revenge, and to ensure justice will prevail.It captures every emotion possible in only the way an expert director can achieve. Ridley Scott direction allows for more believable characters. You will be truly moved by Maximus' resilience and determination. Russell Crowe's portrayal as Maximus was Oscar worthy and truly rousing. The sets are very impressive too taking into detail a feudalistic and ancient Rome; with breath-taking scenery, magnificent structure of buildings and arenas. Ridley Scott also makes his directorial impact known by embracing both beautiful acted scenes and glorious bloody battles. The epic battles touch on both violence and emotion to keep the viewer engrossed by the action. The screenplay is also excellent which captures the true emotions of the film. Although some view the film as being historically inaccurate I feel the film captures the time period superbly and with only the odd historical inaccuracy.Gladiator is a true master piece and gives the likes of epic films such as Spartacus and Ben Hur a run for their money. In both cinematic effects, epic plot and excellent acting.

Although this film was made 13 years ago, I only watched it today for the first time, and I can safely say its been added into my favourite films list. The whole storyline is compelling, and although I found it a bit slow at times, I really enjoyed it as a whole. I'm not sure how historically accurate it is, but the storyline certainly feels very real and gripping. Russell Crowe shines bright as the main character in the story, his acting is brilliant and believable, and he looks absolutely GORGEOUS too, with shortly trimmed hair and his body in perfect shape, he is definitely eye candy, an added bonus! I'd recommend it to everyone !

I loved Gladiator. It's moving and makes you really feel absorbed by the Roman world, as director Scott aims. It doesn't matter if many historical details are not right. Scott depicts the period as an excellent painter and the screenplay is full of beautiful sentences that remain impressed in your memory. Russell Crowe is absolutely gorgeous in the virile role of Maximus, the general/peasant/family-man who becomes a hero not only because he is an excellent soldier and leader, but mainly because of his humanity and his solidity (strength and honor! ), his principles and his moral values. Leader/manager roles suite Russell Crowe best. His voice impresses: he can roar like the tigers he fights against in the arena, but he is also able to whisper love words in the sweetest way. He definitely deserved the Oscar for this movie, certainly also for other movies like A Beautiful Mind, but especially for playing Maximus. The plot may be simple, but the study of the characters' minds and the historical period are what really matters in this movie. The actors' performance is splendid. The unrelenting, massive fight scenes can be appreciated also by a woman when they are breathtaking and are depicted like that. Gladiator made me think of certain characters in Shakespeare's plays, who live as if they were caught in the "wheel of history".

Gladiator has little to teach us about the past. In fact, it has little to teach us about anything save what not to do if you're trying to make a thoughtful film of artistic merit. The beginning has some promise. We are presented with the main character, a general named Maximus, who has seen battle for untold years and desires to resume his humble life as a farmer with his wife and daughter. If it weren't for his unshakable sense of blind civic duty he would have done this long ago. We see Marcus Aurelius, the old, passive emperor known for his stoicism. The movie does not paint him as the relatively aggressive imperialist he actually was, and perhaps we wonder why it doesn't, until we realize that the movie is following a simple rule: all characters must be one-dimensional. Our first impression is the correct one. There is no more than meets the eye; these people are either good or bad. For example: Maximus is good. Anyone trying to kill him, e.g. other gladiators, a.k.a. people who have probably been forced into exactly the same uncomfortable position as him, is bad. It's that simple. Gladiator does have an attention to certain historical details. The costumes, including the armor, for example, that the soldiers (Maximus included) at the beginning of the film are wearing is likely what Romans of the time would have been wearing. This is a departure from previous Roman epics, which tend to use the brass breast plate with the muscles etched into it for Roman soldiers regardless of the time period. So, score one for Gladiator, right? Maybe. But who cares, when we consider the absurd battle that follows? It quickly breaks down to a chaotic melee, with a lot of slashing, that looks completely uncalculated and un-Roman. The Romans win it easily anyway, but if they had actually fought like this they would never have been the consistent victors that they were. They had a method, and they used it, and it definitely wasn't 'every man for himself!' Another perfect example of the film simplifying history comes when Marcus Aurelius says that he wants Maximus to succeed him, so Commodus, Aurelius' son, murders him before he can tell anyone else. In actuality, the succession of the throne to Commodus was not in doubt. The film wanted to make it clear, however, that Aurelius is good, Maximus is good, and Commodus is bad.To examine the character Maximus in detail, we ought to look at his deeds. In the eyes of the filmmakers, he is without flaw. But look how he behaves!He spends the film ruthlessly seeking revenge on Commodus for the murders of his wife and daughter, and eventually his revenge is satisfied. There are no negative consequences for his brutal, murderous revenge. In fact, he gets exactly what he wants: on one hand Rome is handed back to the senate and thus becomes a republic again as Aurelius wished (and what Aurelius wants, Maximus wants because of his sense of duty). On the other hand, he is reunited with his family in death. The movie never tires of telling us that this is his ultimate goal, and then has the nerve to show it literally instead of knowing that it is understood! Remember the moment when Maximus is first handed a sword at the gladiator training camp. He throws it down in protest, either because he refuses to obey his captors or because he is opposed to gladiatorial combat (or both). Roughly two minutes later, though, he is in the arena fighting, though his life never appears to be in immediate danger, because he is so much stronger than his opponents, and such a superior strategist and swordsman; it seems more likely that he enjoys the killing. The movie refuses to acknowledge this completely, because Maximus is the hero, and a necessary condition of being the hero in this movie is flawlessness. Consider also the people he is killing. They are just like him, probably abducted or born into slavery against their will, and forced to fight, yet somehow the movie pretends that they are evil or inhuman. It masks them and makes them out to be the aggressor. At one point Maximus spares a man's life against Commodus' thumbs-down (which should have been a thumbs-up, but that's merely a historical point), but he isn't being merciful out of compassion. As a matter of fact, he is not being merciful at all! All he is doing is showing that he and he alone has complete control over whether a man lives or dies. It is sadistic.The contemporary relevance of Gladiator that I was able to uncover is its warped political perspective. Its sentiments are republican, in the Roman sense of the word, and in the sense of the Republican Party in America today. It values things like civic duty, being a manly man, a family man, a strong man, someone who isn't afraid to kill to defendwhatever. It views liberalism as controlling, preventing Maximus from living the humble farm life that he might enjoy in the state of Montana or thereabouts. It opposes sexual irregularity, and seemingly with it homosexuality. If it were aware of stem-cell research, we could guess that it would oppose it. Essentially, its year 2000 release was the perfect kickoff to eight years of hilarity with the Bush gang. A better way to be contemporarily relevant is to make a thoughtful film that asks deep questions about human nature, or the best way to govern people, or something like that, instead of flaunting some obviously hypocritical moral code.

Review title: Possibly my favourite movie of all time.
Review_body: There are thousands of reviews about this film. Some critics love it, others do not. Some are indifferent.So what can be said about it that has not been said before? Not a lot really. But what I can say is that any film that can create so many opinions and discussions has got to be worth watching to find out what all the fuss is about.People will talk about the performances of the actors, the dialogue, the cinematography and hundreds of other in-depth subjects. But for the laymen such as myself, what do you get from this movie? Well firstly, the movie excites you with the action of the battles, then angers you with injustice of the new emperor. Then you feel the pain of our hero and his despair at the futility of his new existence. Then you are brought back with him as he once again takes control. The power, the invincibility. You feel euphoric as you sense that revenge is near...but then.... Every emotion you can think of is summoned in this movie. A cliché I know, but it is a roller coaster!! Crowe will always have his critics, but, if this movie is re-made a thousand times, no-one will do it quite like Russel.

This is the story of a roman general, Maximus, who displeases his new emperor, Commodus, because he was too close to the old emperor, Commodus's father, and is sure that Commodus killed his father, which he did. So Commodus has Maximus's family killed and Maximus ends up becoming a gladiator, having to fight for his life in the arena.I really liked this movie, even though I first saw it when I was a kid and there are some pretty violent or nasty scenes, like for example when Maximus finds his wife and daughter burned and hanged in front of his house. It's full of action, and you want to know how it's going to go, if he's going to survive and if he's going to stay a slave forever.I recommend to see it, because it's beautifully played and the settings and clothes seem authentic. If I had to give the negative aspects, though, it would be that you have to have time to watch it, since it is a long movie (that is if you watch the extended version, which is obviously better and more complete). Also, if you never saw it and already saw Pirates of the Caribbean, you will be thrown off by the music. Yes, it is the same. It's not plagiarism though, both soundtracks are by Hans Zimmer. You would have the same effect while watching Lord of the Rings if you saw Braveheart, so it's not that uncommon a fact, even though in that case the movies were NOT scored by the same artist.One last thing though, if you know a lot about roman history and want to watch 'Gladiator' to see how much of the movie sticks to real events, don't. It is a great movie if you are not easily upset with inaccurate facts. For example, Commodus did not actually killed Marcus Aurelius to take his place, they reigned together for many years before Marcus died.So in general I really loved it, except for these 'minor' details, and I think it's one of those movies which everyone should have seen before ever saying they have a good cinematographic culture.

"Gladiator" definitely is a classic film as it combines a simple, but moving, story with beautiful scenery, filming, direction and score  it is truly a "complete" movie.I am mostly compelled with the beautiful script which in a way reminds me of poetry, though it is still everyday language. I love the acting portrayed by the late Oliver Reed and also Richard Harris. Russell Crowe, Djimon Housou and Joaquin Phoenix are also superb and the parts suit them perfectly. There are also a number of less "popular" artists who also deserve a big "bravo". Amongst them I have to mention ex-Mr Universe Ralph Moeller who is mostly used as the comic relief of the movie. In Gladiator we can also the beautiful and popular Maltese TV Star and actress Ruth Frendo, who although has a small part, she is totally brilliant and outstanding.Actually I got to IMDb while I was looking for her name on the internet, in fact on IMDb she has some very stunning photos. I was lucky to meet Ruth Frendo whilst she was filming in another Maltese production. Ruth Frendo is not only a gorgeous and talented actress but she is also amazingly intelligent and very down-to-earth. We will definitely be seeing more of her work in the future... The scenery used for "Gladiator" is brilliant  and the opening battle scene is definitely one of my top favorite scenes. The modern camera technique contrasts sharply to the brutality of the gladiators actions and blood shed during the movie; and I love the light contrasts thanks to the lenses which most definitely have been used to create a surreal feel to the entire movie."Gladiator" deserves all the awards and great reviews it has received, and for those of you who still haven't gone and watched it  I can assure you that it will be well worth your time and money. So go on and rent it now!

Both my Dad and my Brother say this movie's overrated, I don't. Gladiator is everything I could ever ask for and more. I find the most common complaint is that the story is too simple and basic, but there's nothing wrong with that. Sure it's always great to see movies subvert genre conventions, but if there was any movie that did the basic tale of revenge to such an epic level, it was Gladiator.The characters are iconic, supported by powerful performances. Crowe's Oscar for best actor is well deserved and I will always remember Joaquin Phoenix as Commodus, the action scenes are intense and spectacular, the visuals are astonishing and the music is breathtaking, creating an overall epic and emotional experience like no other.Not only is this my favourite Ridley Scott movie, but it's simply one of my favourite movies of all time. If you haven't yet, watch Gladiator.

Review title: General Maximus,will forever rest in our memories
Review_body:
You,should have already,seen the film by now,so I'm not going to take the liberty of narrating it again.Ridley scott,is something,more than a director.He is more of an artist,I suppose,For,Gladiator,is his breathtaking masterpiece.Everything from the screenplay,to the music is on point,the casting is lit,the way they have showed the Roman Empire,the garden,the Colosseum,even the slave camps,are enchanting and mesmerising.(sounds very cliché?)
Russel Crowe.This guy,killed it!.
Right from the point when he whooped the arse of the German tribe,to the killing of Commodus,he keeps us glued to the screen.He makes us sympathise for Maximus,and rise with him,as he ascends to become Rome's Hero.When the entire Colosseum,chants "Maximus!",one finds it difficult,to control his excitement(I found it difficult.I was honestly jumping and cheering on the inside,but as none of that matters,LET'S MOVE ON!).
Joaquin,nailed the way he portrayed Commodus.He makes us grit our teeth,upon the mere sight of this dirty minded tyrant.Commodus,is an immature,wrong doing/thinking pig,who envies the fame of Maximus and has feelings for his sister.Basically,an unworthy ruler.I especially,loved the scenes,leading to the climax.Right from,when Maximus and Lucilla have a sweet tête-à-tête,in the Gladiator's resting camp,the movie really shifts its gear.We are then shown that Maximus is captured,and then moving forward a few scenes,BAM!the climax,one of the best,in the history of Cinema.When Maximus,avenges his family's death,by killing that twisted swine,Commodus,and imagines himself,meeting his wife and his son,the film transcends from a mere form of art that eats up 3 hours of our day,to something abstract,that leaves an indelible mark on the viewers.The film,depicts,many problems,that still exist in our world and evokes a feeling of satisfaction upon its completion.The film,like most of Scott's films,(especially those like Kingdom Of Heaven,Martian,Robin Hood),caters to the liking of all the film goers.
I speak for myself,when I say,Gladiator,is something,more than just a film.Gladiator,shall split the timeline of Historical epics,as Before Gladiator and After Gladiator.
Hail Gladiator,The Epitome of Historical Drama!

Throw your history books out the window, sit back and enjoy a roller-coaster of a ride through the life of the fictitious Roman general Maximus as he falls from power, only to regain it as the eponymous Gladiator who wins the hearts of the Roman crowds in the arena. There are some faults with this film - some parts of it do drag - but somehow it is completely compelling, and you can forgive them. All that's missing is the old-fashioned Technicolor look - although maybe that isn't a bad idea considering how graphic some of the fight scenes appear to be (it's what isn't shown that counts).

What Jurassic Park did for cgi creatures, this one does for cgi sets.  It looks like they put cast, crew, cranes, and a helicopter into a time machine and filmed it in ancient Rome. The aerial views of the ancient city and Coliseum, complete with crowds, are truly dazzling.Russell Crowe is most impressive as "the general who becomes a slave who becomes a gladiator who defies an emperor." Emperor Commodus is suitably smarmy - you want to reach up to the screen and whack him yourself!
A bit slow at times, but who cares? The visuals are breathtaking and the combat scenes are unequalled in any movie. Very realistic violence - might want to leave the youngsters at home.Came home to find Ben-Hur showing on PBS.  It looked terribly dated. During the chariot race, I wanted to hear the crowd chant, "Maximus! Maximus!

Ridley Scott has built a better Spartacus! Gladiator brings the old Hollywood glory of Ben-Hur (and even a touch of tongue-in-cheek bad humour a la Caligula) into a new age where it is difficult to tell where real life ends and the CGI begins. The story, the acting (particularly the last performance of Oliver Reed), the scale and the sentiments of Gladiator set a new standard for epic film-making. Breathtaking on the big screen.

After the first time I saw I was flabbergasted. I didn't know what hit me. Well, that's not completely true: the movie is a perfect example of action director Ridley Scott (Crison Tide, Alien).So I went back for the second time to find out what it was.Firstly the visuals are great, but the created atmosphere (especially the battle sequence in the beginning) throughout the whole film is exquisitely darkish.Secondly Russell Crowe plays Maximus as Steve McQueen did in his Heydays. It was a pleasure to see someone play the anti-hero in McQueen/Eastwood style. Supporting roles by great veterans like Richard Harris and Oliver Reed (the film is dedicated to him, having passed away last year after a drinking contest on Malta) make the cast and acting performances complete for me. Joaquin Phoenix, While a great actor-to-be, wants to star a little bit to much for my likeing, however he presents a villain devlish seldom seen on the white screen.Thirdly, having a major part in accomplishing that, the music contributes in a great way to the whole ambiance. Hans Zimmer outdid himself and Lisa Gerard Is mysteriously enchanting.I found he story itself is good, with a few unexpected plot twists. But it isn't great either.That's my two cents.

Review title: How did people make the mistake of calling this a good movie?
Review_body: How can everyone like this movie?  Any seventh grader that takes details from Braveheart (one of the greatest movies ever) could write a better script.  Pheonix did one of the worst acting jobs of the year, though what could he do when the script couldn't decide if we should hate him because he's a coward, because he's cruel, or because he's a pervert.  The three reasons didn't mix well at all.  I do have to say the fight scenes were great, with the exception of the direction in the first one and the blade on the wheel cutting someone in half.  Crowe is also a great actor, but he couldn't save the most overrated movie I've seen.

Hollywood has taken more than 30 years to return to the spectacular historic action movie.  Director Ridley Scott has delivered a movie that combines both action and excellent character development.  Russell Crowe (Maximus) is outstanding. Derek Jacobi(I, Claudius), Richard Harris, and the late Oliver Reed provide understated performances that enhance their characters.

Gladiator, set in ancient Rome is as fine a Roman Epic as I've seen.  The opening combat sequence is glorious for it's use of speeded up photography, perfectly capturing the mind numbing intensity such a battle experience must have been!  And the implements of war you see on the screen are worth the price of admission alone.  By it's end I felt I'd fought in the battle personally.Russell Crowe is superb as Maximus, and to my estimation played a better epic hero than Charlton Heston ever did.  Joaquin Phoenix's portrayal of the Emperor Commodus is somewhat lacking in range, but, I am not sure whether it is his fault, or the fault of the script.  I tend to suspect the script, because I enjoyed his performance overall.Connie Nielsen ruled the screen as Lucilla, a part demanding incredible moments of subtlety, which the lady accomplished with aplomb.  Oliver Reed, to our enormous good fortune, left us one last character, leaving out no detail with his wide range of skills.There are drawbacks, but talking about those reveals the heart of the movie. Suffice it to say that Gladiator will give you as good as you expect.

How can a film this simple, without a coherent script, no real lines ("What we do in life echoes in eternity" is not one of the lines, it's the only real good line), without a director (this Ridley Scott can't be the same that made Alien, Thelma and Louise or even Hannibal) and with only shadows of actors (don't tell me that Russell Crowe, Joaquin Phoenix or Connie Nielsen are really acting. The same can be said about Richard Harris, Derek Jacobi and Oliver Reed, the best actors of that film, but working with an auto-pilot) and a very weak soundtrack could win all those Oscars or even nominated for them? Furthermore, a film that isn't able to win the oscars for the script, the editing, cinematography, actors (besides Crowe, i've already told my opinion about that), director, music and soundtrack (these are really the oscars that award a film and make it good or bad) awarded with best film of the year?i think that everyone who knows anything about films understands my position. I don't consider Gladiator as one of the best films for 2000 (a rather weak year for films, by the way), i consider it as one of the greatest disappointments of the year. Sorry for those who don't share this opinion, to those i can only say: Learn something about cinema before issuing an opinion!!!

This is just one of those movies where you walk out of the theater thinking "Hell Yeah!"  There were occasionally crude looking digital effects and the skip-frame photography seemed a little out of place for a movie set in this time period, BUT the performances were all amazing, and "sandal" movie or not, I had a great time.

There are factual "liberties" taken.  Fetishists for pure accuracy will be displeased, undoubtedly. But this film is a triumph, regardless.  It's not for nothing that comparisons between the vision of Rome given here and Hitler/Speer's new Berlin are drawn; even the music is inspired by Wagner. This is an epic allegory, of sorts. It's about much, much more than the spilling of blood for the entertainment of the masses; it's about the culture that asks for such amusements, and the possible responses to that brutality. This movie is very, very surprising - I was expecting a wonderful Ridley Scott film, and got an astounding, funny, sad, terrible film. It will make you think, and feel.

Review title: A reasonable film, but a bit long and too "in your face"
Review_body: An interesting film which acts as an insight as to what it must have been like in Roman times, giving a much clearer view than films such as Spartacus and Ben Hur.However, it did feel somewhat like a series of (violent) set pieces, linked together temporary respites.  These set pieces were very "in your face" and left me feeling a bit stunned from the combined audio / visual effect - it made me think that the film might almost be better watched on the small screen.Russell Crowe was good as the hero, but I thought the best actor was Oliver Reed, who played a slave owner.Overall, the film is worth a look, but I can't rave about it as I have seen others do.

Anyone else see the Titanic parallels here? Kind of a pseudo-epic take on real history. The almost Disney-esque black/white villain/goodguy, the love interest, (although certainly not as direct as the Titanic love interest) and of course, the popular "twist" ending where the hero dies. That seems to be rather popular way of standing out from the standard Hollywood fare these days, but if not careful it can look contrived.Yes, it's formulaic Hollywood on some level, but Gladiator won me over despite that.  Beautiful scenery and realistic looking battle scenes (jerky camera, however). Great depiction of the infamous Roman era politics, sons killing fathers, sexual desire for your siblings, corruption...I liked.  ***1/2 out of ****

Review title: I won't even bother mentioning Spartacus!
Review_body: I saw this film with, would you believe, very little prior knowledge. All i had heard was that it was to be a movie of epic proportions, good looking and fast moving. Well yes, it looked good and yes, the gladitorial sequences were good but little else and when you've got that much money to use then what do you expect. I'm sorry to have to point this out but it really doesn't take that much talent to make what is an essentially predictable and some what dull film with a spattering of nice effects on a film that only seemed to have a budget of epic proportions! So please people, stop giving this movie more credit than it deserves and then maybe when this much is continued to be spent on films(which i don't deny will happen), it will be put to far better use.

Way overrated - despite great acting (Phoenix is surprising, while Crowe is expectedly excellent) & nice effects with the Roman architecture & look, the over-serious style tries to be Saving Pvt. Ryan meets Julius Caesar & fails at both.  Wooden dialogue, clunky narrative, & boring pace don't help, but worst of all are the Michael Bay-like action scenes - too many edits to make sense!  Ridley Scott continues to show that his only strengths are coming up with nice-looking films, but can't tell much of a story or emotional weight without an exceptional script.  C+
I enjoyed this movie from beginning to end. I would see it again. Can't wait to buy the video. What next for Mr. Crowe?

Review title: At last, violence with a purpose.
Review_body: An impressive movie with great acting and superb photography.  Underlying is a good comparison of what's going on in our own society.  Bread and games, that's what people are asking for.  Just look at those extreme combats shown on tv and that so many people enjoy.  Let's hope that we get more of that kind of movie and let's also hope that some will get the message.

Gladiator.  It conjures up images of honor, bravery, courage strength, and stoicism.  One would think that a Hollywood movie would not be able to capture such qualities on film, sacrificing realism for the fluff, sex scenes, gratuitous violence and stilted weak plots.Ridley Scott doesn't make that kind of movie.  He brings to the screen a very realistic seeming portrayal of life as a Gladiator in the Roman Empire. Russell Crowe gave one of the most amazing performances of his career, bringing the title character to life, and managing to make Maximus real in just a few short hours.Definitely a movie to see.  It has subtlety for those who like to think in movies, but it also has action and betrayal for those who don't.All I can say is, Thank you Mr. Scott.  Keep 'em coming.

Review title: Could have been fun, but impossible to follow battle scenes
Review_body: I saw this with low expectations but with the hope that it would at least have exciting battle scenes. I know a lot of people love this film, but for me the battle scenes almost all went something like this: grimace, cut, swinging arm, cut, blur, cut, chariot wheel, cut, flying arm, cut, close up of leg, cut, flying head, cut, chariot wheel, cut, tiger, cut, etc, etc. How could anyone follow it? I had no idea what was going on during the battles most of the time and thus found myself getting more and more bored. The film definitely looked great, but the battle scenes were a bore because of the extreme closeups and quick cuts after quick cuts. Weren't the battles the main attraction? I can't recommend this film as a result.

Review title: A great movie, but not an epic
Review_body: What was missing? I don't know. It was well worth seeing but it tended to lack something in terms of drawing the viewer into movie. I would suggest this is the fault of the director primarily, as the scenery and acting were great.Go and see it, you won't be disappointed.

I missed this on first release, but have watched it on DVD. To be quite honest, it's tripe of the first order. The script is awful, and the acting generally not much better (thank heavens for the computer-generated actors: they are at least the equal of their flesh-and-blood rivals). I found this film to be deeply contrived and boring. As for the garbage of the Emperor Commodus fighting 'mano a mano' with a gladiator, the scriptwriters must have been on something stronger than LSD.Presumably Ridley Scott hired Derek Jacobi for 'Gladiator' because he'd played a Roman before (to whit, Claudius, see below), but even in his minor role he out-acts the far starrier names (except for the late Oliver Reed, who steals every scene he's in).If you want a _real_ flavour of 'life at the top' in the Roman Empire, get the DVDs or videotapes of 'I, Claudius', the BBC's conflation of Robert Graves's 'I, Claudius' and 'Claudius the God'. This is far better written and it's superbly acted. It's also more convincing, despite being made on a shoestring budget. If 'I' Claudius' is an excellent fillet steak in a superb restaurant, accompanied by the finest wine, then 'Gladiator' is a gristly hamburger in a seedy fast-food joint, washed down with a 3rd-rate clone cola.

Superb opening half-hour (the battle in the German forest), but then deteriorates into cliche.Oh, and how does Maximus make it from Germany to Spain in so little time, with only one horse and no food?

Gladiator is a wonderful, epic film. Definitely the best I have seen in a long time. It is entertaining and though provoking. Scott's direction is spot on, the casts performances deserve a standing ovation and the score is wonderful. Combine this with the breathtaking CGI Rome and you have a winner!

As a huge fan of Braveheart, I must admit my skepticism before I saw the sneak preview of Gladiator tonight.  I was expecting a derivative action/adventure flick; decent, but not spectacular.  What I got was an amazing film...an epic of Braveheart proportions, not a cheap rip-off as I had expected.  Needless to say, my feelings going into the movie were dead wrong...it was terrific.  Russel Crowe was a strong and believable hero, and he has certainly become one of today's premier leading men. The casting and costumes were superb, and the story was simple yet powerful.
