I don't want to give anything away, as the movie has not yet been released in theaters, but I will say that  this is a must see for any movie fan.  Though it was a bit long (2 and a half hours), the story kept moving, and there was plenty of action and laughs to keep the audience interested. The theater was packed for the sneak preview, and everyone left talking about how great the movie was. My vote is a 10 out of 10.....this one is extremely entertaining...GO SEE IT!!!

Review title: The epic adventure we've been waiting for!
Review_body: Gladiator takes you back to the days of the Roman empire and gives a perspective of what life in 180 a.d. might be like. Not since the days of Ben Hur or Spartacus have we had a movie like this. It tells the story of Maximus, the saluted Roman general who becomes a slave and a gladiator after Commodus, the sinister son of the old emperor Marcus Aurelius, through patricide takes over the position of emperor and slays the general's wife and son, destroying his life. Maximus swears revenge and fights his way to the mighty stage of the Colloseum in Rome, where he squares off with his foe.I saw this movie at the premiere in a theater with over 600 seats, a screen reaching 65 feet from side to side, and the most brutal THX sound system this side of the known universe. The place was packed to the brim with people, dying to see this movie. From the beginning to the end, two and a half hours later, this movie delivers on all levels! Everyone in the audience started to applaud when the movie was over, something I haven't experienced since the premiere of Episode I, as they, just like me, were in utter awe of what they had just seen.From the acting to the photography, from the music to the realistic brutal violence, this movie never failed. It's a master piece deserving both a second and a third viewing at the cinema, and a definite pre-order when it hits DVD. Ridley Scott hasn't made anything this good since Blade Runner and Alien.I can't recommend this movie enough. You simply have to go see this picture now!

Review title: Russell Crowe shines as a Roman Mad Max...
Review_body: Despite the initial revenge by the numbers feel of the first half of the film, Crowe carries this film magnificently in his slide from hero to abject despair and redemption of a sort.On first watch, there are many similarities with the first Mad Max film - hero doing his bit for "society", wife and kid at home.  His family is killed by the bad guy and the remainder of the story is a rollicking ride to see how the revenge is pursued and ultimately obtained.Being an American film where the good guy has to win, that he will get his revenge is without doubt, only the path matters.Phoenix's character is almost a caricature of a bad guy, with no redeeming features whatsoever; the byplay with the Senate mostly lost in the story.Ultimately a satisfying story - the sweeping opening battle designed to either solidify Crowe's character's battle mastery and general status, or to self-justify the cost of staging the battle.Enjoy..

Review title: For a 2.5 hour show, it could have been longer. Great entertainment.
Review_body: Right from the start, this film strikes you as special with a scene that, if it is meant as an intro, looks like the finale of most other films. The special effects, although hugely impressive, do not take over the story which is simplistic but powerful. How Roman life was at that time is about as graphically illustrated as you would like to see but in more than a violent manner. The roles, and particularly the actors, especially Russell Crowe, Richard Harris and Oliver Reed, enrich the film to their credit. Altogether, miss this one on the big screen, and you'll never really see it again.

Ridley Scott, te saluto! This film was so much better than I expected when I'd seen the trailer, the old city of Roma Aeterna so much better done and the Germans so much more true to the possible truth than in most films! (I still wonder what the German in the beginning says...anyone who knows?) Sure, this is an action movie, but with enough heart and soul to keep you tight in your chair for almost 3 hours, which is more than you can say of most films... Of course, the film is not following the true story (Commodus was, as they say, strangled by a certain Narcissus), but that isn't so important when the film grabs you like this does. So: one complaint: why put in the birds? They're animated and you see it! Why???

See this one in the theatre. I haven't seen an audience react so collectively to a movie in a I don't know how long. Gladiator is the stirring story of Maximus and his fight against the Roman emperor. The previews hardly give justice to the bone crushing, decapitating, roaring battle scenes. The cinematography is almost perfect, transporting one to the wilds of Germania and bowels of the coliseum equally well. I know it's early but I wouldn't be surprised to see an Oscar or two come out of this movieRussel Crowe's carries this movie well. If were to compare this to Braveheart I would say Gladiator has Braveheart beat hands down. If you like a good old-fashioned action flick, definitely see Gladiator.

I have never written a review before but thought that it would be nice since I saw a sneak preview of this movie last Tuesday... This movie was spectacular. I thought it would be very boring and I only went because we got free tickets to it. The story is about Maximus (Russell Crowe), a general with the Roman forces. He knows the Caesar, Marcus Aurellius, and Marcus Aurellius wants him to take over when he dies. When Marcus Aurellius tells his son Commodus about this, he gets really mad and kills his father. No one knows that Marcus Aurellius wanted Maximus to take over, so Commodus does and proceeds to try to execute Maximus. He sent out men to kill him, but didn't realize he wasn't slain. He also killed Maximus's family. Maximus is found and becomes a slave. All he can think of, though, is how to get revenge on Commodus. This movie is brilliantly acted and gets 9 stars by me. The beginning of this movie is a war against barbarians and is not too graphic. I would have rated it PG-13 if it wasn't for the small amounts of gore. All in all, see this movie!

Review title: Is this an authentic Scott at all???
Review_body: Even if «Gladiator» weren't as weak and banal as it is on it's own right, the fact that it was supposedly done by the very same man who created «Blade Runner» and «Alien» would be enough to damn it in all eternity.What an unbelievable loss of filmic quality! What a shamefully predictable plot! What quaint dialogues! What - even that! - poor videogamey visuals! All right: there's patricide, there's revenge, there's lotsa blood. There's even almost incest. But all oh so underscored and looked at in such awe and abomination that it can only be there to  cater for a bourgeois (or adolescent, for that matter) need of a thrill, quickly followed by the reestablishment of order. Nothing more. No discussion, no actual leap into the dark. Nothing really unsettling, for the gods will eventually see to it.Not worth one of Sigourney Weaver's gasps or of Harrison Ford's broken nails.Whatever's the matter with Ridley Scott?? «Alien» shaped all our nightmares afterwards and the future was never the same after «Blade runner». And then, «Gladiator»... There's this very popular phenomenon of director's senility (just take a look at Coppola's «Jack» or Antonioni's «Jenseits der Wolken» for the sake of illustration). But then, R.S. isn't THAT old yet, is he...? Can't really fathom it.Due to a very strange paradox, I doubt «Glads»  would ever attract as much attention as it did, were it not done by the great author of «Alien» and «Blade Runner». Whoever would have enjoyed it anyway would enjoy it and forget it. More reasonable people wouldn't be seen dead in the theatre, not even gagged and handcuffed. For one thing, -I-  would definitely not be wasting my time writing about it. But, again, justice must take its course.

Gladiator was ultimately a bunch of alright fight sequences ruined by mixing it with the most trite and overused plot devices from every kings court political movie ever made.  The king dies, the son plots, the hero is almost assassinated and decides to overthrow the new King, blah blah blah... Just rent an Ultimate Fighting Championship video and King Lear, don't make yourself sit through something that tries to do both, but fails.

Would have been  a great film without the end.Once more Hollywood mistake,they can't figure out the end without a spectacle..a caesar fighting a gladiator in the arena!! Give me a break..Do they read History in hollywood?? 3 stars

For the first time ever we have seen what it was really like to be among the Roman army as they do battle.  The opening scenes of Gladiator are jaw-dropping, as we witness not the clean and  clinical Roman war machine that history describes, but a rough, dirty and brutal killing force. Russell Crowe is perfect as Maximus (among his other names - The Spaniard, The General, or just plain Gladiator).  Great performances too from the rest of the cast. The fight scenes are excellent, the gladiator costumes are brilliant. Ridley Scott has done it again, this film should do well at the next oscars. Hail Maximus!

Review title: Excellent in visualization but lack in Historical drama
Review_body: Ridley Scott always get his best in visual aura of the movie. So is right for Gladiator, but dry dialogues and "soap opera" moralisation playing bad joke for this effort. Overall it's much more "Scott" movie after his two previous bids.

I saw an advance screening of Gladiator and was for the most part blown away.  Russel Crowe's versatility radiates in this picture, compared with The Insider.  He is the ulitmate Roman hero, vanquished by political enemies.  His challenge will not only be to survive his predicament, but to restore the values, hopes and dreams of a forlorn nation torn by greed, economics, and evil.The cinematography is awesome- Kurosawa-esque in it's grandeur, magnatude, and graceful treatment of the action.  There are many smaller hand to hand encounters that are also exciting.The true power of this film lies in the brilliant performances of Crowe as a magnetic hero, and Joaquin Phoenix as the tortured heir of the Roman kindgom.

I thought that overall the movie wasn't very good. I did think Russell Crowe was pretty good, but the rest of the cast was unimpressive. I disagree with some readers that the movie was action filled. The action was short and was frequently dispersed with lengthy talking/dramatic scenes that tried to add to the intrigue and tension but failed. It seemed to me that the movie originally had some scenes that would have helped the flow and were cut out or something. Also, some of the characters were so inconsistent for example, Quintus, (Maximus' second in command [I think]) was his friend in one scene, betraying him in the next, and helped him in the end...what was that? Also, on the battle at the start...they really messed it up. I don't want to sound like a dork but ROMANS DIDN'T USE FIRE ARROWS or any arrows at all for that matter. The Roman army was composed almost entirely infantry. They only used bows when they had cheap auxiliary troops from a territory or something. Remember the spears the infantry had? The thin metal ones? THAT is what they would have used, you see, they THREW those if they had used those spears in hand to hand, they would've gotten wasted hardcore. A weird thing about that is, the cavalry had swords only, now tell me the sense of fighting from horseback with a Roman short sword. They would've used lances. A final argument to that scene is, they wouldn't have brought and set up those siege weapons for an infantry fight. They simply took too long to set up and fired too slowly to be useful. One the other hand, it was kind of cool to see and I thought the production values, as far as the armor and mass amounts of troops were cool. They were entertaining, but they weren't very well researched. Another thing that bothered me was I felt the camera actions throughout the movie kinda spoiled it.  The camera was jerky and the speed of it was constantly altered ad nauseum They should've taken some hints from other epic war movies and movies with that sort of action.My final thought is, the movie could've been a lot better, but it's worth watching once. Also, there is NO WAY it equals Braveheart in ANY respect.

Review title: A nail biting, intense modern epic!
Review_body: Most films require that the viewer identifies with the character to truly be engrossed with the film. If you can't feel something for the character, than the audience is lost.Luckily, in Ridley Scott's case, Russel Crowe is so captivating and convincing as a general loved by his troops and as a slave loved by the people that the movie really works. Possibly one of the greatest actors today, Crowe carries this epic film on his very capable shoulders.Not to say that he is the only reason this works. The supporting cast, most notably Connie Neilsen, buoy the film to new perspectives.Jacquin Phoenix definitely captures the egotisitcal persona he should display, stealing every scene he's in. Phoenix will surely be put on the map with Gladiator.But the real shining star in this film are the incredible action sequences which jolt the viewer right in with the opening sequences, as Maximus' true worth to the Roman Empire is displayed. Scott's camera work within these completed sequences takes a modern twist that really works for the gruesome scenes.Crowe will now get the respect he deserves for this collosal performance. Gladiator makes the most of its 2 and a half hours, marking a triumphant comeback for the long forgotten epics of the classic days of film. ALL HAIL MAXIMUS!

Watching this movie has caused me to once again wonder, how a director can manage to create images of perfect beauty, while producing such a horrible plot and dialogues that almost make me blush for just hearing them at the same time. I thought the 90s had finally brought movies with such appalling heroic pathos to an end. Unfortunately, I was wrong. Not only does Ridley Scott make usually excellent actors bring forth lines that let "The Phantom Menace" ring like Shakespeare in my ears. He also shows no scruples whatsoever twisting history around entirely and making the Roman Empire look like a benevolent pacifier. All in all, if it weren't for a few corrupt Senators and a megalomaniac young emperor, Rome seems to have had no flaws for Scott whatsoever. Ah, a little genocide here, some imperialism there...the others were all "barbarians" anyway. The only thing that really surprised me was that Russell Crowe was not draped by a flag at the end...oh, wait, that movie was about Rome, not about America, wasn't it? My mistake!

The first thing I want to say is I love this movie. It is only the second movie I've seen starring Russell Crowe, and in the words of my buddy and fellow movie critic, Robert G. Cash, "I think I'm in love with Russell Crowe." Similar to his character, Bud White in L.A. Confidential, Crowe is soft spoken, hard as nails, and outstanding as the principled and intrepid General Maximus Decimus Meridias.Maximus is favored by the dying Emperor, Marcus Aurelius (Richard Harris), to take over as the keeper of Rome upon the Emperor's death, and is given the charge to destroy the corruption rampant in Roman society, turn the government back over to the Senate and end the rule of the Caesar's forever. The Emperor's jealous and power hungry son, Commodus, played very well by Joaquin Phoenix, is distraught when he hears of his father's intentions and sets out to destroy Maximus and everything near and dear to the General. (By the way, Commodus is the Latin word for commode. No wonder nobody likes this guy.) Commodus orders the General's death, but is startled when Maximus shows up later in the Colosseum of Rome as a slave and a gladiator, determined to exact revenge on the new Emperor "in this life or the next."Richard Harris, always one of my favorites, gives a great though short performance as the aging and good hearted Marcus Aurelius Caesar. Connie Nielsen with her classical look is perfect as Commodus' sister Lucilla, forced to keep her unstable brother happy while at the same time aiding her former beau Maximus. It is good to see Oliver Reed again as the slave trader and gladiator trainer Proximo, and even though Reed died part way through the making of this film and they had to digitize some of his scenes, he is still a better actor dead than the entire cast of (we demand more money than we deserve) "Friends".The battle and fight scenes remind me of Mel Gibson's Braveheart in their realism and brutality of sword combat, however, the scenes seem more surreal than Braveheart and the "cut aways" are often too quick to really see what is happening.Finally, just my two cents when it comes to movies about ancient Rome in general. Why are there never any Italians? Is Rome not in Italy? Did they not talk like Al Pacino in those days or what?

Gladiator is a great action movie. It has been a long time since a quality movie about this era has hit the theaters. The details might be altered, but how many people today have even a vague idea of what life in the Roman Empire was like? Enjoy a great movie, and for those who need historical ficton with accuracy read Colleen McCullogh's First Man in Rome series.

I loved this movie.  I decide how good a movie is by how entertained I was. I was entertained by "Gladiator."  Russell Crowe was great, Oliver Reed was outstanding.  He will be missed.  I am glad I was able to see him perform so well in his last role.

Although this film is more than 2 hrs long, I remained glued to the seat until the end. This movie is a fantastic one! It is a return to more than 40 years of film history - when they used to make epics like Ben Hur, Spartacus and Quo Vadis. The actors are excellent especially Russell Crowe and Oliver Reed (who died during the filming stages in Malta). The opening battle scene is simply stunning and the gladiatorial fights in the colosseum left me grasping for breath. The scenery and cinematography are wonderful and full of colour - typical of Ridley Scott. The score written by Zimmer is haunting and at times very moving. Thanks Ridley for this experience. 10/10

Review title: GLADIATOR: THE STORY THAT TOUCHES THE HEART
Review_body: When I first saw this movie it reminded me of Braveheart.  Then I thought to myself that this movie posses a quality that Braveheart does not.  It possesses the quality that you get satisfaction at the end of the movie.  In Braveheart you do not get satisfaction at the end and it is difficult to watch many times.  I believe that that is the reason why Braveheart didn't do as well as Gladiator did in the box office but did win 5 Oscars.  This movie is a work of art.  The score complements the movie so well. Lisa Gerrard and Hans Zimmer deliver the movie in music notes rather than words. Russell Crowe is great in the movie and reminds me alot of Richard Burton. He is an up and coming star who is destined 2 win an Oscar.  Joaquin Phoenix also delivers a great performance worthy of an Oscar.  The late Oliver Reed is outstanding.  Reed seems to steal the scene that he is in from all the other actors because of his acting power.  Ridley Scott delivers a classic film that will remain in our memory and our hearts.  If you haven't seen this movie, please do, you will not regret it.

This movie was possibly the best movie made in a long time. It has everything, action, drama, romance, everything. Will keep you in your seats from beginning to end. Russell Crowe gives an excellent performance as well as the rest of the cast. A MUST SEE!!!!

Review title: If you see just one movie this summer see Gladiator
Review_body: I saw Gladiator last night and I felt that it was one of the best and most interesting epics I have seen in a very long time.  The movie has something for everyone. If you liked Braveheart, you'll love Gladiator.  I think that this movie has everything....great action and battle scenes.  There hasn't been a roman epic like this since Ben Hur and as we all know, Ben Hur is the record holder for most Academy Awards won.

I have seen this movie twice already and I have enjoyed it each time. Wonderful movie with great acting and Russell Crowe simply took my breath away.  Ridley Scott did a fantastic job in bringing Rome back to life. This movie truly pulls you into the story.  Highly recommend it anyone and everyone.

I'm not here to offer you a summary.  Rather, I'm here to ORDER you to see Gladiator.  As of now, it is a top contender for best film of the year in my mind.  Great special effects, exciting action, superb acting and an excellent plot makes Gladiator a film worth watching again and again.

Review title: Amazing, simply breathtaking...one of the greatest films ever made.
Review_body: Right from the start of this epic story, it proves its one of the greatest ever made.  Russell Crowe excels in his role of Maximus, as do all the actors.  Ridley Scott directs superbly, a project to match that of Citizen Kane and Fight Club.

Drawing the line between martyrdom and heroism is what makes Ridley Scott's Roman epic, Gladiator, such a powerful and moving movie.  Using some computer generated shots as well as a cast of extremely talented actors, Scott beautifully creates a fictional story that shows the start of Rome's eventual downfall.  I don't know too much about the history of Rome, but I didn't need to in order to enjoy this five star movie.  Despite all the action and bloodshed, the humanistic issues are what bring this movie above any Hollywood anti-hype it would otherwise get.There wasn't much to this movie that I didn't like.  Graphically, there were some great matte scenes of the city and the bird's-eye view of the opening battles added to the war-like feel of the movie (however this scene reminded me a little too much of the Gungans- Droids scene in Phantom Menace).  All the gladiator battle sequences were great- brilliantly choreographed and superb in cinematography.  The shots were rapid fire, not allowing the viewer to focus on any one image for an extensive amount of time, but slowing down before the victory.  Thus, the movie felt like it was more action packed, albeit bloody.  The themes of the movie, "Strength and Honor," were always in my mind and reinforced the concept of the tragic heroism of Maximus.  Maximus wouldn't be a martyr, nor would Commodus have him that way, so the element of tragic heroism overshadows the movie. Because of this feeling and the intense acting that Russell Crowe puts into his character, the closing scene was extremely moving, almost bringing tears to my eyes.  Adding to the emotion is excellent scoring by Klaus Badelt, Lisa Gerrard, and Hans Zimmer.  The classical music gives movement to the slow scenes as well as the fast paced battles, yet doesn't detract from the story itself.  Maximus deals with human issues such as death, honesty and trust, and loyalty to a cause he believed in.  Gladiator was probably one of the best movies I've seen in a while and although it is rather gory with several heads getting sliced off and a lot of bloodshed, the movie as a whole comes through as something that is definitely worthwhile seeing.  It probably wouldn't surprise me if some Oscar nominations are given to this movie, either to Crowe or Phoenix, but that won't be for another year. Definitely a must-see movie.

The opening battle sequence and subsequent fight scenes are superb. They feel realistic, bloody and uncompromising. The film looks great throughout.Unfortunately the plot is a cliche and completely predictable. The characters lack depth and the dialogue slow and dull. A lot of editing to cut this down to 90 minutes might have been a good idea.All the actors put in at least reasonable performances and you wish the same cast had been given a decent script to work with.

When I went to see Gladiator on opening day, I new it would be action packed, but I was a little aprehensive about the story.  After just and hour of the movie, I was blown away.  This movie has an excellent story backed by a superb cast, and the fights are breathtaking.  My advice is to see the movie as soon as possible.
3 words : Oh my god, and the music.. I mean, what an atmosphere.. Best movie this year, hands down.. Cheerio, Alex.

Review title: Today I saw a movie become more powerful . . .
Review_body: The movie is the story of Maximus (Crowe), a general who leads the Roman army to victory over Germania in the beginning of the movie. The dying emperor of Rome, Marcus Aurelius, is watching this battle.The emperor's son, Commodus, then arrives with his sister Lucilla, and it is discovered that Commodus fully expects to be announced the new emperor of Rome in a few days. Aurelius, however, has other plans--he wants to make Maximus emperor, and requests that of the general, who wants nothing more than to go home to his family.I went into this movie having just watched Ben-Hur in my film studies class and having watched an episode of Xena only a couple of weeks earlier that featured the story of Marc Anthony and Cleopatra. So you could say I was in the perfect mindset to watch a "sword-and-sandal" movie. I wasn't sure what to expect, having somehow avoided all the hype that accompanied this movie. But I was not disappointed.Gladiator features some wonderful cinematography by John Mathieson. The battle scenes are very graphic. (This movie is not for the squeamish, that's for sure.) There were some scenes in particular that really struck me, such as when Crowe appears to be floating over the ground very fast.  The use of color and color tones added a great deal to the mood of the movie. Excellent.The script was being written and re-written as the filming was going on, yet it doesn't show that the actors had no idea how the movie was going to end when they began filming.  The acting is terrific. Russell Crowe is wonderfully cast as Maximus. Many reviewers agree that he is now officially a star. Joaquin Phoenix also proves his mettle as the emotionally troubled Commodus, whose behavior and emotion toward his sister could give anyone the creeps. Connie Nielsen makes you believe that, as Lucilla, she really is torn between natural loyalty to her brother and doing what she knows is right. Oliver Reed, in his last performance, is memorable in his role of Proximo, the former gladiator who is the owner of Maximus and brings him to Rome.  In short, the actors were brilliant in their roles, not over-acting, but giving subtle, strong performances.The script itself is very good.  Although some elements are a little hard to believe--the fact that no one recognizes Maximus when he's a slave?--this film calls for a willing suspension of disbelief, which one would happily comply with.  (It's really no fun to nitpick such a movie.)It's true that this movie does pretty much follow the Braveheart formula. However, this movie includes some elements, such as the cinematography and the incredibly graphic battle scenes (one reviewer likened it to Saving Private Ryan, "only better"), that are spectacular in itself. Overall, a great movie that I highly recommend.

Review title: A soaring movie of epic proportions.
Review_body: This is an excellent film for those who are interested in the field of Roman History. The first battle was very realistic as to what would have happened. The sheer destructive power of pre-gunpowdered weapons was almost beyond belief. And all this in the first ten minutes of the movie.There are those who would not like this movie because of the violence in it. My reply would be, "How can you do a movie about a gladiator without violence". The violence was not the main feature of this film. It was about the will to survive, and about revenge.Overall, if you want to see a movie that grips you from the start and gives you an insight as to the political maneuverings in the Roman empire in the second century, this is definitely the movie to see.

Review title: Best movie I´ve seen this year so far...
Review_body: After watching the unbearable Mission: Impossible 2 two days ago (only for die-hard Cruise fans), I was a bit reluctant to watch a nearly 3 hours long movie about ancient Rome this afternoon, but I´m glad I did!This movie is great because you really get to feel sympathy for the main character, as the events take place and he ends up where he ends up (forgive my English, I´m sure there is a better way to type that last phrase.)Also the scenarios are greatly computer-generated, but that is not the main attraction of the film, and that´s good because many films these days rely on the computers to save the day. The movie is long, but it never gets boring, and the action scenes are really well done. The story is similar to those of the classics such as Ben-Hur or Quo Vadis but hey, everybody expected that.Anyway enough talk, go and watch it because it´s destined to become a classic, if it´s not already.10/10

Review title: not an epic,just a good night out
Review_body: Worth seeing just for the enormity of it all but I wouldn't pay to watch it twice.Richard Harris was really good I thought but Connie Nielsen,dear oh dear.Russell Crowe was much better in LA Confidential though he isn't BAD in this.Action scenes are very graphic but add to the whole story which at times you want to speed up because you know whats coming next.Certainly not on par with epics such as Ben Hur but worth seeing on big screen as opposed to video.

Review title: A Great lesson of Roman History!
Review_body: Great sceneries, majestic performances, an amazing soundtrack and an excellent story, that will thrill, amuse and teach those who see the movie, all about roman History. A great story of passion, drama and action, is what makes Gladiator, one of the best historical pictures of all time!

Review title: WOW But I thought something was missing
Review_body: I loved this movie but I can't shake the feeling that something was missing. I loved the scenery, the story, the fight scenes, every thing was great about it from start to finish. But I can't say on thing about the movie that I felt was memorable or outstanding. I know that sounds strange but I can't. I know this is one that I will own on DVD and I will see this one again and I do recommend you seeing this film. And when you do please tell me what stands out in this movie. Because I couldn't seem to find it. Maybe I will the next time I see it.

If you're looking for a visceral movie you've found it here. 'Gladiator' is a visually stunning thrill ride from beginning to end. Punctuated by a brilliant Russel Crowe performance, a fabulous blend of styles from the bombastic Hans Zimmer ('Crimson Tide') and the melodious Lisa Gerrard (Dead Can Dance) in the music department and the stunningly beautiful visual effects views of mighty Rome, this movie is a real treat. While some story elements are a little weak and some battle scenes may not be for the faint of stomach this movie is nonetheless a fun take on the classic Hollywood-epic a la 'Spartacus.'

Review title: The juxtaposition of emotions makes this movie.
Review_body: Cinematography,costuming, acting and music all played their part to create this spell-binding movie. I loved it from the getgo. There was spectacle and there was intimacy; love and hate;noise and quiet; treachery and trust.Gladiator has taken its place with Ben Hur and Spartacus in the triumvirate of Classical Roman movies. Bravo Ridley Scott.

Superb photography, intense battle scenes with realistic settings, good storyline but dialogues a little lengthy and repetitive. The editing could have shaved off a good five minutes of over-sentimentality.The afterlife glimpse and the sincerity of prayer in the context of a pre-Christian faith is a refreshing novelty.

This movie is a masterpiece. Gladiator has the same qualities as great movies like "Saving Private Ryan", "Braveheart" and "Titanic". Historical elements, stunning scenery and brilliant casting are the reason why this movie deserves to be compared with these other great movies, even though the story of the movie is not as authentic as the others. Russell Crowe is fantastic - he has the same presence on the screen as Mel Gibson. Connie Nielsen and Joaquin Phoenix also deserves credit for their performances. If you want to be entertained in a big way - see Gladiator, it will leave you breathless.

Review title: Exciting entertainment, but not much more
Review_body: The first thing I want to say is that the film was far better than I expected. The fighting scenes were good, the acting too, and the special effects were just amazing... I was really impressed how the film showed the ancient Rome , a great work of the special effect crew.But the story was just the same old thing. Bad man cheats good man and becomes king (in this case: emperor) , and good man fights for justice against the bad man although he's inferior. Well, you can also find that in Shakespeare's pieces, so this is certainly nothing new. And because the characters were all in all clichees, this is not shown very good either. Another point: the film is, historically seen, not correct: Rome never became a republic again, and Commodus reigned until 191 AD. And he was certainly not killed in the arena... The last point: Maximus is quite a stupid name, it just means "the greatest", and romans didn't name their children like that... well, these are all just unimportant details... 6/10

I always love the old movies about the roman empire. The peplum was always one of my favourite movie genre. This movie, gives us again the tremendous fun and the enjoyment of movies like «BEN HUR», «QUO VADIS». Of course the special effects are the main difference, but the suspence, and the action are fantastic. The story, the actors, the spectacular fighting scenes, the special effects...(in two words) all the production are tremendous glorious and they give us again the glory of the peplum genre. Congratulations. This movie is one of the most spectacular movies i ever seen. It is a great movie.

Although I thought that the movie was good, it was too long and there was way too much hype surrounding its release. It did not live up to my expectations.  Russell Crowe is superb.  The supporting cast was weak. Story line dragged.

Review title: The most epic movie for years
Review_body: Gladiator by Ridley Scott is easily the biggest and most dramatic movie since...oh, heck, it´s just GREAT. The story is straightforward and simple, but (as some folks wrongly thought) that´s nothing to complain about. The best stories are the most simple ones, and this one is about classic elements like friendship, betrayal and revenge. Granted, it´s a men´s movie. So if you don´t like it go see the new Julia Roberts comedy.The Acting is just terrific. Crowe, who already was great in "L.A. Confidential" and "Virtuosity" is going to get an Oscar or i´ll never again enter a movie theatre. Phoenix is also terrific as his Nemesis who has some very human weaknesses. The supporting cast is also very good. It´s also nice to see Ridley Scott back in town.The CGI Graphics are not always convincing; they look too artificial. Most impressive, however, are the battle scenes (did I hear someone say "Braveheart"? As another guy here pointed out, the battle scenes in "Braveheart" looked like a picnic, compared to "Gladiator". Nothing to add here.). The fight against the guy with the face mask, surrounded by tigers, is just breathtaking."Gladiator" is simply the best movie for some years (if you don´t count "Star Wars", which is beyond and above competition).Go see it!

When I saw gladiator, I couldn't help juxtaposing it with Braveheart: Very similar story lines and both movies try to be epic in scope (not to mention that people compare the two australian stars, russell crowe and mel gibson).  I enjoyed Gladiator's breath-taking visuals and its WWII style battle scenes and even its occasional gore, but i walked away from the movie thinking that it was lacking something.  Gladiator lacked qualities that made braveheart a true epic.  Perhaps i speak too harshly of gladiator because i compare it to Braveheart, but i thought that braveheart was immensely more powerful.  Gladiator's Maximus, though suave, spent too much of early screen time not wanting to be involved (then later being forced into action) whereas Wallace from braveheart is shown as a child to build history and align the audience's sight and sympathy with the soon-to-be older wallace.  Beyond little petty things such as that, Braveheart is more more grand in scope than gladiator.  Braveheart dealt with the issue a nation of people who were struggling againt tyranny and the passion of one man, further powered by the fury of his slain bride, to free his country. Gladiator shows corruption within one system of government and one man who is quite indifferent about it.  Only later... way later does Gladiator push its protagonist into limelight to shake up the scene; but with what motivation?  Only that to avenge his lost family (something that braveheart used as its auxillary motivation) and to kill the corrupter of Rome. Sorry Maximus, but Rome became corrupt anyway. Talk about phyrric victories.

This movie was great. The costumes were awesome (especially Maximus's fur general uniform, and his helmet when he was a gladiator). The story was really action-packed, suspenseful, surprising, and a little emotional. The special effects with the gore was awesome. I didn't even notice that the movie was a little longer than others, it's so good you wish it would never end. It has a great plot, and you really feel there along with the characters. I totally recommend it, 2 thumbs up!

Review title: Best Movie in a Long Time
Review_body: I find it extremely hard to believe that many critics voted this movie below an 8/10. "Gladiator" carried more presence, more power, and more energy onto the screen than any other movie in many years. All cinematic elements came together - the casting, the story, the setting, the costume, the score - everything.Russel Crowe's inspiring portrayal of the noble general Maximus brought faith back into the art of film-making. Maximus was played with such conviction that it was very difficult to remember that this was just a movie. What made Maximus so captivating was not his aggressive role as a fighter, but his loyalty to his family and his genuine care for the goodness of Rome. Crowe brought to life the very human qualities that all people wish to achieve: honor, courage, valor, respect.Crowe's on-screen nemesis, Joaquin Phoenix, also played his role as Commodus with an innate passion. Commodus was ingeniously portrayed as the evil, immoral emperor - the man for whom Maximus is to seek vengeance upon.The other cast members, Connie Nielson as the emperor's sister Lucilla, Oliver Reed as the ex-gladiator turned entertainer Proximo, and Richard Harris as the all-powerful Marcus Aurelius , were all outstanding in bringing to life the emotions of this time period.None of these actors could have achieved such on-screen genius without such an awe-inspiring and intriguing story. It has been a very long time since this genre has entered movie theaters, and "Gladiator" sure brought that history to life. One was only spell-bound to the experiences and events that the people of that era lived through. It is about time that a movie came along that shared this important piece of history with modern society, so that people today realize and appreciate the goodness of our current society.The spectacular landscapes and sets also adds to the beauty and realism of the film. The background and Coliseum scenes were put on screen with such precision. The costumes were also appropriate to this time period. The score was also an element which added to the drama and powerful impact of the film.Walking out of the theater I was nothing less than completely satisfied. My faith in movies was completely renewed with this movie. Gladiator stretches beyond the role of a conventional popcorn movie, for it is something that leaves the viewer with a new sense of inspiration and a new understanding of a monumental era in our history. Maximus' role also goes beyond the call of duty since it provides us with a new sense of how life should really be lived: with honor and courage.

I absolutely loved this film.  I have seen it three times and would see it again in a minute.  It was much better than Titanic (I would love to see Russell Crowe battle Leonardo DiCaprio...boy, would that be funny!)  A lot of people complained that the storyline was familiar and simple.  Well, most epics are similar..and why does one need complicated storylines all the time??  I thought it was refreshing to see a character that was truly good, without hidden agenda's or alterior motives. All of the acting was wonderful, but I have to especially mention Russell Crowe.  I first saw him in L.A. Confidental (which he deserved an oscar for) and have seen most of his movies.  Whether or not they were good (like Virtuosity or Rough Magic) he did a wonderful job.  I think the thing that amazed me the most about his performance was the way he could show so much emotion without talking--through his eyes.  It made me want to cry, seeing the emotions that man expressed.  I have to also mention the acting of Joaquin Phoenix...I couldn't decide whether I despised or pitied him more. Making the audience hate him really demonstrates his acting abilities, imo. The special effects, music, and acting combine to be one of the greatest epics of the past three decades....a must see.10/10

I had been waiting several months, trembling with anticipation, for the arrival of this film, and I am pleased to say that it did not disappoint me. Russell Crowe is instantly likeable as the world weary General Maximus, commanding the legions about to "unleash Hell" on the armies of Germania. His only aim is to see an end to battle, and return home to his farm and family. Certain events, heralded by the intervention of Joaquin Pheonix as the insane emperor Commodus, spectacularly prevent him from doing so. Commodus is a power mad, snivelling wretch who, when he isn't plotting and scheming to rule Rome, tries his hardest to get his sister into bed. The unfortunate Maximus gets in the way of his plans, and so has to be removed. Maximus winds up in the gladiatorial ring facing a madness far removed from that of the battlefield. He now has a different criteria. To survive the arena and exact revenge on Commodus for the brutal slaying of his wife and son. The battle sequences are bloody, violent and messy, and human life is cheap. But through all of this shines Maximus, a noble but reluctant hero, who touches the life of all those he comes in contact with.The excellent score by Hans Zimmer is powerful and emotional, borrowing some of the choral strains from his Crimson Tide offering, and Holst's Mars theme from the Planets suite. (He was the Roman God of war, after all.) The soundtrack hasn't left my car stereo since I bought it two weeks ago. Reading through other reviews, it seems that people either love or hate this film. I loved it with a passion; something about it touched a nerve. Some scenes left me breathless, while others had me fighting back a tear. I have seen it four times now, and it won't be the last. There are a lot of purists out there who say that Rome was never like this, and that history records these events differently. To these people I say, WHO CARES?! I go to the cinema to be entertained, not watch a documentary. I go to escape from the real world for a few hours, lose myself in fantasy. Surely this was the reason that Cinema was invented.I cannot stop praising this film, much to the dismay of my friends and family. Gladiator should be in receipt of a few statuettes come Oscar time, or there is very little justice in this world. Ridley Scott has, in my humble opinion, produced a masterpiece worthy of praise. We salute you!

I was entertained, but then I could watch Russell Crowe read the phone book. LA Times review mentioned trite dialogue in script.  I think it is a testament to the actors that none of the dialogue came off that way to me. In lesser actors then Crowe or Phoenix, the dialogue would have been awkward and full of bricks.  Script/story are full of holes but does that really matter here?  My main pet peeve was the undercranking and variable speeds in Cinematography during the battle scenes. Why?  Does it train our eyes to accept the intense digital matwork when we get to Rome?  I don't know.  It kind of got in the way of the storytelling in the battle scenes for my taste.

Review title: Superb in all departments. Russell Crowe you're a star!
Review_body: Believe all the hype,the film IS amazing in all aspects. The battle scenes (particularly the one fought in Germania) is one of the greatest EVER filmed.The gladiator arena scenes are bloody, brutal yet extremely well choreographed.Crowe shows why he should be instantly propelled onto the A List of leading men. His performance as the vengeful underdog/hero General Maximus is the perfect blend of strength, humanity and courage.Laurels aplenty also for the underrated (but not for long) Joaquin Phoenix who plays the villainous,troubled and love-starved Commodus, the beautiful Connie Nielsen and a fitting film finale for the late Oliver Reed (one of his greatest performances.)The SFX featuring old Rome are just SPECTACULAR.The towering Colosseum filled with spectators is just breathtaking, particularly when the camera does the 360 degree pan.A fine film making feat for Mr. Ridley Scott. Hail Ridley Scott!Hail Gladiator!

Review title: One of the best movies of the year !!!
Review_body: I went to see this for no reason. I was bored and just got up and made it my choice to see this. I am EXTREMELY happy that I saw this. The movie is by far THE best movie that I have seen this year. Do NOT, I repeat DO NOT let the marketing fool you into thinking this is just some hack em'/slash em' movie. The Marketing for Fight Club, Three Kings, and The Iron Giant killed those movies. Don't let the same happen to this instant classic. The movie itself is beautifully shot, almost as if any one shot could be placed above a mantle. The acting is done perfectly, although most of the credit goes to Russell Crowe, Joaquin Phoenix performed greatly with what little material he had to work with. Last, but not least, some people might complain about how the battle scenes are too hard to understand. The point of the battles were not to entertain, but rather to show how a real battle is like. Your friend and mine, this is Teenratboy signing off.

Russell Crowe is fantastic as Maximus in both physique and temperament.  As a man of honor who valued the simple things but who could back them up with his sword, Maximus is a character worth sitting nearly three hours in a theatre for, and Crowe brings Maximus to life in ways that makes me wonder if Russell is "acting" at all.  Connie Nielson is also well cast as Lucilla. A real beauty, (think Sharon Stone), her scenes with Maximus are first rate. The other cast members did a good job as well.  I would point out the boy who played Lucius only to say that he is a far better child actor than the one who played Anakin Skywalker in The Phantom Menace.  As for Joaquin Phoenix, I wanted him to be more "psycho," in that while he succeeded in making Commodus disturbing, I found myself laughing at him more than I was scared of him.  There were times when I simply wanted to tell Commodus to go to his room, and I would've done it without fear of reprisals, but I'm not sure if that's Phoenix's fault so much as it's the script's.The costumes are wonderful!!!  Especially Lucilla's outfits, and her jewelry and makeup are perfect as well.  The battle gear and gore make-up are also well done.Visual effects-wise, the inside of the Colosseum is great, but the rest of Rome seems so fake.  While breathtaking, it is obviously computer generated. As for the battle/action scenes, they seem rushed and choppy.  The opening scene for example, both visually and audially (esp. the arrows) reminds me of Star Wars for some reason, but I digress.  The first half of the battle is well done, showing the sheer numbers on both sides and the strategic planning involved.  However, the second half is annoying in the way in which it's shot.  It doesn't live up to any of the Braveheart battle scenes that people seem to want to compare them to at all.  The rest of the action scenes seem to follow the same pattern--great general set-up, horrible follow through.  The lighting however was well done in terms of when and how it was used to fit the theme of the movie.While obviously leaning on the action scenes with its epic proportions and gory grandeur to draw in and "entertain" the movie-going audience, the movie would have been better off focusing on the more intimate and human interest side of the story.  The best scenes in the movie were the ones that took place out of the sight of "glorious" Rome with its architectural wonders, its mob-like masses, and its moral corruption.  Those shot in dark, dank corners between two or three people, esp. those between Maximus and Lucilla, were fantastic and did more to draw me into the lives of the characters, where the real story should take place, than any that dealt with the fate of Rome.The Gladiator is still a movie that I would recommend to others however, if only to make sure that Russell Crowe and Connie Nielson get the recognition that they deserve.  But don't take my word for it, go see it for yourself.

For me, a "long" movie (3h) during which your mind never wanders away from the screen is to be considered real good. This one for me is a real "attention catcher" because it has a good story, great decors and sceneries, beautiful photography, great attention to details in recreating ancient Rome, and great staging of the battle and the combats. At times you don't know to which part of the screen to look at !Excellent cast but with, I believe, a particularly great performance by Joaquin Phoenix who proves to be very talented.  I loved it... and went to see it a second time in order to better grasp all the details.

The movie displays brilliantly the power and weakness of the Roman Empire. From victories on the battle field due to technical superiority and superior battle strategies, to the immoral actions taken by the Rulers of the Empire, to strengthen their own position of in the government. But the movie is much more then battle scenes and politicians fighting each other; it also give the viewer an insight into the different facets of love  from the ideal platonic love, to the sick desire of a brother to lie with his sister. To wrap all of this up, we have great computer graphics to really display the might of the Roman Empire. Great Movie  A `MUST SEE'!!!!!!!

Review title: Impossible history, but vivid fiction of Roman struggle for power with the circus maximus as arena
Review_body: The victorious general- whose name in Rome was imperator- is indicated to be Master of Rome by Marcus Aurelius, the philosopher-emperor. Commodus, his son, knowing the plans of his father kills Marcus Aurelius. Maximus, promised to power see his family assassinated, becomes a  gladiator, after being prisoner sold as a slave. In Rome with his triumphs in the arena of the Colosseum, the circus maximus,he defies the power of the tyrant Commodus. In the real history Commodus takes power with 15 years and has not killed his father; he loved the circus spectacle and even participated in it.Is this film a metaphor of modern relations of power- the mob, the media- inside the present dominant empire?

I loved everything about this movie. Russell Crowe and Joaquin Pheonix both deserve Oscars for best actor and best supporting actor. The music was excellent and so were the sound effects. The CGI effects were unbelievable. The un-sung hero of this film is Oliver Reed as Antonias Proximo. He gave a great final performance before he died. This film definitely deserves at least a nomination for this year's Best Picture!

Review title: A pretty good flick, but with some glaring errors :(
Review_body: Ok, I saw Gladiator last night, and on the whole I was impressed. The acting was good and there were some interesting in-jokes. However, historically it left much to be desired.First, the good parts: Marcus Aurelius' Meditations reveal that he did not much care for the public life, and longed to return to his quiet life on the farm back in the country. Sound familiar? Also, there had been a revolt by a senator named Cassius shortly before Aurelius' death, and he shows up in the movie, yay! I also liked the fight scenes, yes that makes me no better than the mob, but I thought it was interesting how the actual killings tended to be displayed either sped up or slowed down, in either case making them seem unreal. In regard to the mish-mash of accents, I thought it added charm to the movie, after all, Rome was a mish-mash of people, no?** There are some spoilers in the following section. You have been warned **As far as the history goes, I have heard some complaints from friends about Aurelius actually being in Germania (he did go out on the road with his armies) and Commodus entering the gladiatorial ring (which he also did). My major issue is the fact that Commodus enjoyed(?) a 12 year reign! He was not, repeat not, killed in the Coliseum by anyone, he was drugged and murdered the night before he was to accept a consulship. (Dressed as a gladiator, no less) For me, that brought this movie down a couple notches. Historical license is one thing, but killing emporers less than 6 months into their reign is too much for me.Final analysis: 6/10

Gladiator left me absolutely speechless, it is one of the finest films since the reminiscent days of Ben Hur and Spartacus.  The opening sequence of this epic, featured a realistic display of the battles that occurred during the time of Roman rule.  Ridley Scott's story of the General turned slave turned gladiator-- turned HERO, is truly captivating. The cinematography was seamless, the computer generated Roman Empire ie colosseum was so real, it was like you were there, while the action sequences were "out-of-your-seat" exhilarating.  Russell Crowe's (Maximus) performance, as usual was brilliant, showing he has the ability to add depth to all the character's inwhich he plays (ie The Insider, LA Confidential, The Gladiator). Crowe's presence is felt from start to finish.  As the evil and mad-hatter Caesar, Joaquin Phoenix  plays Commodus the Son of Marcus Aurelius perfectly. Though all three, Crowe, Phoenix, and Nielson (as Lucilla) bring together this epic to make this a truly spellbinding experience. Missing out on two Academy Awards for LA Confidential and The Insider (though much deserved), Crowe hopefully should see a look in for this years nominations -- if not, there must be something seriously wrong.  This is definitely a BIG-SCREEN experience, a must see.  I give it 10/10. Keep up the truly great performances Russell!

After reading some of the other reviews found here, it appears that you either get this movie, or you don't.  Well, I did in a big way, and I feel sorry for those who didn't.The details have been explained in detail in other reviews, so I won't bother with that. Suffice it to say that I was completely absorbed in this movie, primarily due to Russell Crowe's performance. Crowe is rapidly becoming my favorite actor, and he plays this role perfectly.  Others have commented negatively about the historical accuracy, and long running time, but I never noticed, and really did not want this movie to end.Do yourself a big favor and GO SEE THIS MOVIE!! Unless you're dead set on being critical, or determined not to get it, then stay away so I can have a better seat to see it again.

Review title: Like a nice, slightly ill-fitting suit
Review_body: I liked this movie: it had good action, some intrigue, the sets were beautiful, etc. However, it suffered from a few editing problems. For instance, the scene when the senator advises Commodus to imitate the sea-snake: why? Nothing comes of it. Was there a piece of story line that fell to the cutting-room floor? Visual mis-edits abound: gladiators in a tortoise in the center of the arena, then a scene of milling shields, then a faraway scene of the tortoise again. I found it distracting. Overall, I enjoyed the movie, but it left me feeling like I bought a nice suit that doesn't fit quite right. Having seen Ridley Scott's Director's Cut of Blade Runner, and finding it superior to the original, I wonder how satisfied he is with Gladiator as it plays in the theaters now.

I don't know why everyone is ragging on the plot; even though it was predictable at times, it was still gripping. I think this is the best movie I've watched the whole year; the visuals are just breathtaking. I haven't seen such beautiful cinematography since What Dreams May Come. George Lucas should ask Ridley Scott for some tips because while the special effects in Gladiator were less flashy, I believed it was real. Compare the computer graphics of the cityscapes of Rome to those in (whatever that city was called) in Phantom Menace. Same technical quality, but the stuff in Gladiator was a work of art. My only disappointment was the first battle scene. . . if I had watched the whole scene without turning away, I would have puked. Am I supposed to feel a rush just because they're pulling the film faster? The opening scene in Saving Private Ryan was by far superior. That had me ducking and wincing, Gladiator's did not. The acting was a bit cliche, on Russell Crowe's and Joaquin Phoenix's part, but so were their characters. I have to say though, I've never seen a better performance by Phoenix. In the scene where he kills his father, when he was giving that little speech about not being loved, I was moved to tears. That has got to be the most emotional scene in the whole movie . . . and a job well-done by Phoenix. Does anyone remember James Dean in East of Eden? Same speech, equally powerful. I wonder if that's where Phoenix got his inspiration. Overall, great movie. Too bad some people are anti-hype, anti-mainstream, because this film is really worthy.

Review title: I Fell in Love... with Maximus
Review_body: Russell Crowe was fantastic for the part as Maximus. In fact all casting was a job well done. Crowe's star has risen high with this one. I hope to see him again in similar epics.On other notes, the score was excellent too, especially in the opening battle scene. The brass notes were as terrifying as the killing. I felt like I was there.

Review title: One of the best I've seen in a while
Review_body:
Many movies that we all watch are disapointments because of all of the hype that surrounds movies (especially summer movies)now.  I was extremely excited to see Gladiator based on the trailer and the reviews I had read. This was one of the few movies where I was not disapointed at all.  Russell Crowe was outstanding as Maximus, as was Joaquin Phoenix as Commodus. Although I thought the movie could've used another battle scene or two, not once did I have to look at my watch or wonder when it was going to end, even after the 2 1/2 hours I just wanted more.  I won't go into the story line, because most reviews have already done that.  What I will say is that the first scene, the opening battle is in my opinion, the best scene of the film.  The cinematography for that scene was perfect, and like so many before me have said, it rivals the opening scene of Saving Private Ryan. Maybe not as intense, but the sheer action in the scene is breathtaking. The entire time I was watching it I couldn't help but compare it to Braveheart, which in my opinion is the greatest movie of all time. Although I still think Braveheart was a better film, Gladiator held it's own.  It is an epic, just as Braveheart was, and deserves to be held in the same regard.
Bottom Line:  It just makes you want to learn how to sword fight.

Review title: Very interesting and nice but still not the big one
Review_body: As I said it's a very interesting and well done movie. Battles, scenes, dressing, actors - all of them were 100%. It was nice 3 hours to seat in the theatre, but when leaving it I thought "It was great, but surely not the one I may be shocked". Why ? May be because it's just a simple story which was pictured very well. But still a very simple story. Nothing to be shocked from. Nothing to discuss after.

Review title: A movie MADE for the big screen
Review_body: It's hard not to react to the intelligentsia, who equipped with their Film Studies 101 from Cynics College seem to want to rip this movie to shreds. Gladiator is a wonderful piece of storytelling which paints a simple story very profoundly using all the tools available to the modern film-maker.I thought the acting was terrific, and Russell Crowe is wondrous in the role of Maximus, a man of courage and honour.  We can all share his pain as he fights for justice for his family and for Rome.  Maximus is a real hero who does what he has to do, not for personal glory or for wealth.  Joaquin Phoenix plays Commodus very well, at times you even sympathise for the spoilt brat.  But this film belongs to Crowe, I can honestly not remember a movie where a central performance has been so guaranteed to catapult the actor to mega-stardom.This is the type of movie cinemas were made for.  Take off your cycnic hat and go and see a film that tells the kind of story that made your ancestors believe in real heroes.Every other summer movie judged against this just pales.  See this on the big screen, I urge you.  This film will move you.

Though the plot of Gladiator is completely fictional, using historical characters requires keeping a certain accuracy. In this respect it is intersting to learn who Emperor Commodus really was... Marcus Aurelius became emperor in 161, and until 169 he reigned in cooperation with Lucius Verus, husband of his eldest daughter Lucilla. Then the latter died. In 177, Marcus Aurelius associated his son Commodus to official functions in order to prepare him for the succession. In that sense, Marcus Aurelius reestablished the blood succession. Marcus Aurelius died shortly after the victory against thr Danubian barbarians near the actual Vienna in 180, but, he wasn't strangled by his own son as in the film, but died or of the plague or of exhaustion.Commodus becomes emperor, but shows little ability to succeed in his new functions. He concluded a quick peace with the barbarians, came back to Rome and actually did not care about politics. He lived in his world of laziness and lust. Lucilla was very angry at him and did not like his lover Bruttia Crispina. She set a plot and an attempt was made to kill Commodus, but it failed. This marked the beginning of a series of executions within the royal circle and the senate. Dio Cassius, Roman senator said: "The fear was shared by us senators.He killed an ostrich, cut off its head, and came towards us with the head in his left hand, brandishing his bloody sword in the right. He wagged his head to show he would do the same to us." When he entered the senate, the senator had to salute him in this way: "You are Lord, you are first, you are most fortunate. You are Victor, you will be victor; from everlasting, Amazonian, you are victor". More than that, Commodus was clearly a mad man, influenced by oriental religious practices. He wanted Rome to be called Commodiana, and the Legion Commodian.. He called himself the Roman Hercules, and styled Rome the "Immortal Fortunate Colony of the Universe"! All the months were given his names: Amazonius, Invictus, Felix, Pius, Lucius, Aeliuys, Aurelius, Commodus, Augustus, Herculeus, Romanus, Exsuperatorius. He applied Exsuperatorius (his own image of Jupiter) to himself regularly to show that he surpassed mankind in many ways... Many statues represented him as Hercules. Commodus loved the games. He often went to the amphitheatre and entered the arena dressed as Mercury, beginning his exhibition barefoot and in his tunic after having got rid of his garments!. According to the historian Aurelius Victor, he was "so depraved that he often fought in the arena as a gladiator"!! He had a real fascination for gladiators and wild beast, and when he wanted in January 193 to kill two senators in sacrifice and to make a procession in Rome at the head of his gladiators, it became necessary to get rid of this dangerous psychopath! His surroundings plotted, and Marcia, his favorite lover handed him a cup of poison, and he was then strangled in his bath by his coach, Narcisse, on December 31, 192. The reign of Commodus marked 12 years of terror, lust, cruelty and greed. He was obviously a megalomaniac. If a date can be fixed for the beginning of the decline of the Roman Empire, it would be his reign. In the film, his folly is well represented, but in a different way though. We can see that he is a megalomaniac the way Ridley Scott made him enter Rome, and through the fact that he wants to rule alone. We als see that he loves the games, since he introduces 150 days of gladiators' fights. But his obsession with religion has been replaced by an incestuous love for his sister, whom he nearly consider as a goddess. But he didn't die in the arena (though he often fought as a gladiator), but was murdered. Nevertheless,with an astonishing photography and editing,  Ridley Scott's Gladiator is one of the best epics of the last 20 years, and will remain as such in many people's eyes...hopefully!

Gladiator is, in my opinion, a very good movie. It has a certain style not likely to be bested soon. The scenes are beautifully made, with good realism. What? Perfect! If I didn't know all those people died, I would not hesitate to argue so immediately. Very good.

First 1/3 of the film is great, I watched with my jaw opened. Then came the boredom. Boredom from prolonged dialogues and Joaquin Phoenix's acting.Last week I read Paul Newman quit acting after all these years. The reason he explained "I am sick of all these sex and violence in today's movies"I couldn't agree more, why on earth do we HAVE TO watch more and more queer, incest and other sick scenes in today's movies? I exclude films like Flawless or As Good As It Gets from these as they are meant to be made from different perspectives of the life. The story is OPEN. If you hate drag queens don't watch Flawless, simple as that. There's no cheating here. But putting disturbing scenes into an ACTION movie like Gladiator is something else...I think film industry should be based on one major fact: entertainment. It doesn't have to resemble to REAL LIFE. Everything can happen in real life and we do not want to remember every DETAIL of it.Let's face it do we enjoy watching a pervert Emperor who's trying to screw his sister? or a dialogue like "What do you want Maximus, a girl? a boy?" I hope most of you people do not reply "yes" to those questions!

Review title: Mediocrity - How Ridley Scott yet again neglects the script in favour of the image
Review_body: It wasn't surprising really. I should have known better, after all this had happened with the narratives in Legend, 1492.., Black Rain and even in his superior works Alien and Blade Runner(and will happen again, like Peter Pan?). Hope however springs eternal, and with the casting of Derick Jacobi some comparisons with the sublime I, Claudius were inevitably and subconsciously drawn. How desperately in need of those comparisons was this dire cocktail of flashy, confusing gore and risible 'intrigue' performed by a collection of actors who, with a few exceptions, appeared to have recourse to one facial expression to express the gamut of emotions required of them by an infantile, ludicrous and totally implausible script which took 2 1/2 hours to deliver a plot which could have been written on the back of a postage stamp.Are we so easily satisfied with mediocrity that we can praise this ramshackle, gloomy hi-tech affair as being the first 'epic' of the year 2000? Surely not. Even the highpoints of the film; the opening battle scenes and the chariots vs gladiators coliseum fight come nowhere near to matching the virtuoso displays in Saving Private Ryan and Spartacus.For the rest, give me a script instead of computer-generated images which if I want to watch I can do so on one of my son's computer games.Now if Mr Jacobi had been a screenwriter ...

I've seen the godfather, I've seen the usual suspects, I've seen Gladiator. Those are the three greatest movies I've ever seen. What a great movie. Russell Crowe is performing his biggest role ever and he does it with charisma. A throughout mighty movie.

Review title: satisfying epic, whatever the nit-pickers say
Review_body: I've been reading numerous comments about this movie over the last few weeks and I've been amazed at how pedantic many of the criticisms have been. To all those of you complaining how weak and cliched the screenplay is I'd ask you to name one movie set in Ancient Rome where there is no clunky or camp dialogue. What do you want,exactly? How would you have improved it? Have a go, if you think you're so hot.I'm not saying it's perfect by any means. However, on balance, any reasonable movie-goer should be able to admit that the triumphs outweigh the failures: beautiful cinematography (the complaints that the choppy editing in the fight scenes make it difficult to follow...please...don't you think the intention might have been to give the viewer the feeling of being in the heart of the action?),strong performances (Crowe's magnetic in a slow-burning, intensely powerful, dignified performance: can you imagine if Mel Gibson, or...eek...Arnie had been given the role?; Pheonix was superb with a complex and fascinating villain; Neilson was quietly impressive as a woman torn between 4 men: father, ex-lover, brother and son; even Oliver Reed proved he could act when he could be ar**d) and a screenplay that was not without cliche, but was able to tell a big story very concisely (the scene with Commodus and Lucilla arriving in Germania had barely 100 words of dialogue, but gave us mountains of information about both characters).Those of you complaining that there was not enough back-story or information about the motivations of the key characters, do you honestly need every last detail to be explicit? You are allowed to use your imagination sometimes.To conclude, I'd say that it delievered everything that one could ask for from a film of that genre, and I felt I'd had my money's worth...even on second viewing. You can nit-pick any film you care to mention, but why not just sit back, enjoy the spectacle and let yourself be transported to another (historically inaccurate, fair enough criticism)era for a couple of entertaining and sometimes moving hours?

Review title: Most powerful movie of the year
Review_body: That Ridley Scott is to be regarded as one of the world's most important and best director (as I always felt despite the lack of power and art in his last efforts), was just proven by the grand-scale drama he directed on GLADIATOR. This is a great movie, mixing high-octane action with deep emotions, striking visuals, wonderful performances and a story that's involving and credible. Despite some freedom to historical fact it is as realistic as any movie ever can hope to achieve. Since I'm not going to give away any insight into the story or character (you should find out about these things by yourself), I'm just going to say: Shakespeare would have loved it, because it's probably the best drama he had never written...

Review title: If you only see one movie this year...
Review_body: This is the best film I have seen this year. It generally takes an exciting prospect to get me out of my seat and down to my local cinema, and this film has that quality. When I first heard about the film, I was intrigued, especially when I heard Ridley Scott was to direct. Then people started talking about the remarkable special effects and fight sequences. I'd read some preview comments in the national press and that interested me more. I think what impressed me most about this film was not the prospect of Russell Crowe and friends in leather (however...), but the fact that there is no sex, no swearing, no gratuitous violence (apart from what is appropriate to the storyline). I thought the film was well-acted and not too far-fetched, quite believable in parts and very touching in certain scenes. I would go and see this film again (I probably will), and although I'll buy it when it's released on video, it's best enjoyed on the big screen. This film is an EPIC. Go and see it if you haven't already.

The opening scene is the best in the film.If the film managed to sustain the excitement and thrills of the first 10 minutes or so it would have been a masterpiece.But it unfortunately fails to do so.After the awesome opening battle scene the film goes downhill.The fight sequences are hardly groundbreaking in a time of huge special effects.It also tries to show a serious face which contrasts with other things in the film.But at the end this film is worth seeing.

Review title: Great Visual affects, great Cinematography, great actor...
Review_body: This movie has a class of Ben-Hur. After a long time I have seen such a great movie, with amazing visual affects and the outstanding view of the city and the coliseum. In first war scene, the fired arrows that were shot in the darks, the releasing sounds of the catapults. The fired arrows and catapults that were being shot made it look astounding.

Review title: We really enjoyed it (Warning Movie Spoiler)
Review_body: This is was a very good movie, I have seen Spartacus and Ben Hur but this has to be the best. the sets were unbelievable, the story kept you interested. There was a love interest, there was violence. there was homosexuality, incest.. it had it all. The costumes and sets really made it the best. Russell Crowe was very convincing as Maximus. Commodus did a good job and by the end of the movie both my wife and I were glad he died at the hands of Maximus. The music was excellent and it really did the movie justice. The arena fighting made it the best but it wasn't overdone. there was really only 2-3 main fight scenes in the arena. I especially like the opening scene fight as well.
I know I'm in a tiny minority, but I really hated this film.  Way too long, poor direction, and awful violence.It's this year's "English Patient" - a film you're supposed to love.

...a movie for boys!!? I don't think so...it's a movie for everybody (I should know I'm a woman!! Saw it last night...going again tonight! The best computer-animation I've ever seen, 'Titanic' can go sink itself again for all I care!! :-) Congrates to Connie & Sven-Ole...go DENMARK!

Review title: Gladiator - The next generation of films
Review_body: This film will leave you stunned - It has an epic story-line, it has some really gruesome violence during the gladiator scenes (how can it really be classed as a 15?)and the portrayal of the characters, especially Caesar Commodus (he really does make your flesh crawl!)...It's akin to The Matrix and Phantom Menace because it uses massive amounts computer graphics to show the audience things that are impossible to recreate in real life. If Oliver Reed really was dead part way through filming, and his face really was digitally recreated, actors better beware, because it's impossible to know which bits are real Ollie Reed and which bits aren't.Hail Gladiator!

From the start this movie grips you and takes you on a ride with a quality mix of gore and atmosphere. CGI in this film is fantastic and to be honest this is the best film I've seen since the Matrix. A must watch for everyone, everywhere.

I really loved this film. It reminded me of when they used to make films like this e.g. Quo Vadis and The Robe. My wife hated it as the violence was all too real and she spent most of the time with her hands over her eyes! All the more credit to the film for this.

Ridley Scott has done it again (creating a superb motion picture, like Blade Runner and Thelma & Louise). This time, he has made the first good picture on Imperial Rome since "Spartacus", a picture appealing even to those who do not appreciate the genre. From the opening scene to the film´s closing, the audience is drawn into the story and into history, led by brilliant camera work, solid acting, a captivating musical soundtrack setting the mood for every scene without interfering with the picture, and brilliant cinematography. Characters are well developed and realistic, true to historic records (in fact, history tells us that Commodus, the Emperor, was even more of a megalomaniac than he is portrayed in the picture. If the script writer had portrayed him as he really was, audiences would probably have considered it as too much of a Hollywood cliché...). The computer-designed scenarios are breathtaking, notably of the Colisseum.

Review title: Excellent film, but it's fiction, not history
Review_body: Great battle scenes, fine cinematography, excellent musical score, first-rate acting.  For these reasons, I enjoyed the film.However, I really would have preferred it if they had made up the names of the characters and the world in which the action took place, rather than butcher Roman history.  Examples: Marcus Aurelius groomed Commodus as his successor almost from the time of his birth (he was given the title Caesar when he was five years old, and became joint ruler with Marcus in 177, three years before Marcus' death); Commodus is reported to be blond and handsome, and saw himself as another Hercules; Lucilla did plot against him, but was found out and killed in 182, early in Commodus' 12-year reign; Commodus was lecherous -- having a harem of 300 concubines and an equal number of young boys for his sexual pleasure; he often appeared as a gladiator in the coliseum spectacles; he was smothered to death as a part of a plot led by Eclectus, his imperial chamberlain, Quintus Aemilius, commander of the praetorian guard, and Marcia, his favorite concubine, not killed by a General Maximus, who does not even appear in the biographies of Commodus that I have read.I suspect that they could have made a movie just as exciting if they had made it historically accurate, and somehow I would have found that to be preferable.  However, it would have been far more difficult to find a hero, which is probably why they decided to create characters and events and pass them off as history.  Too bad.

After seeing this movie for the 3rd time this afternoon, the ending still brought me to the point of tears. Ridley Scott and Russell Crowe combine to give one of the most powerful performances in an action/adventure/drama film since Saving Private Ryan. Other than Stand by Me, which i saw when i was just a kid, Gladiator, and Private Ryan are the only 3 movies that have ever brought me to tears. I only wish i would get an email address or agent address for Ridley Scott or Russell Crowe, just to write a letter of appreciation for the film. I saw MI2 the other day, and was grossly disappointed. More like Mission Ridiculously Proposterous, Gladiator is a far superior film.
