After i saw it the first time, i just sat there after the movie was over, unable to describe how much the movie touched me. I have recommended it to everyone from my mom, to Fraternity buddies, and have gone to see it each time with a new group of people who were seeing it for the first time. The soundtrack as well is amazing. The music alone brings me to tears, and as soft as i sound, i rarely cry at movies, where everything is scripted. But i listen to tracks 15,16, and 17, and i get teary eyed. The music is just very powerful and the vocals are incredibly haunting. Hans Zimmer did an amazing job, and while Hans did the ST for MI2, it doesn't compare. The whole package is an emotional tour de force, that isn't just a hack'em up bloody gorefest, despite the amount of killing that does occur, it has a story and emotion and brilliant acting by Russell Crowe and supporting cast. It's a must see for the summer, and a must own when released on VHS or DVD.

For more than two hours you live back then, you feel the sand, the heat, the fear, you smell the blood and sweat.I love the story, I like the image, the music and the unforgettable performance of the actors. As there has been a lot said about the fights, I would like to emphasize some other moments of the movie. Remember the desert in Zucchabar, and the cold forest in "Germania"? But how about the smooth wheat fields in Spain where HIS house was? The movie revives the Roman world again at is highest magnitude, on the screens as it was never done before. After all we all have a small piece of Romanity in us today. Think about it.The great movie ever!!! Go see it!!!P.S. To those who complained about the correctness of the history events: 95% of the whole literature is just fantasy, the rest of 5% is fantasy inspired from reality. What do you think Spartacus was indeed like? Like Kirk Douglas? How about Cleopatra, Moses, Jesus, Columbus, Shakespeare and all others? Do you think they did exactly what you saw on the screen? I think not, but let's love the movies for what they make us feel or think or for their power to make us a little bit better as Gladiator did.

An amazing mix of action, drama and splendid special fx. Russell Crowe superbly portrays his character and the epic feel of the whole film definately puts it up there with Ben Hur and Cleopatra. This film is sure to delight everyone from the big film buff to the subtle fan.

Review title: Why does everyone like this movie?
Review_body: Am I the only one who doesn't think that scenes of people relentlessly hacking away at each other and severing limbs, heads, etc, blood spouting everywhere is "beautiful" and "stunning cinematography"?  I'm absolutely astonished at the other comments about this movie! I found the fight scenes to be uncomfortably gory and grim; and there were so many of them, and they went on and on and on! I had been told that it was thought provoking, a love story (??) and not very violent or gory.  What movie was that?  Certainly not this one!  I was also annoyed at the gratuitousness of his wife and son being killed, just so he could be pissed off enough to justify his desire for revenge. (just like most of the old Charles Bronson movies)  Wouldn't he have been pissed off enough by the murder of his beloved emperor, the betrayal of the 'ideals of the Roman Empire' and the fact that he was captured and made a slave?  Guess not.I went to the 9:00 pm show, and in between the battle scenes, I kept almost dozing off. I just didn't find the movie or the characters particularly interesting, engaging or compelling.  "Gripping" is a word I have seen in other's comments--I don't see it.  I was anything but gripped. In comparison to Braveheart, it was about as violent, but you didn't really care about any of these people or what they were doing.  Braveheart made me want to find out more about William Wallace and that period of history; Gladiator made me want to go see Thomas the Tank Engine in the next theater to wash those gory images out of my brain and put something light in there instead!I'm not trying to belittle anyone's opinions who loved this movie; I am just nonplussed by them.  Basically, I just wanted it to be over, so I wouldn't have to watch it anymore.

I have always been an enthusiastic fan of ancient Rome. Romanticism is also my weak point so Gladiator meant everything and much more for me. Beautiful battle scenes and an old-fashioned plot colored by pure heroism almost sucked my soul of my body. I identified myself instantly with the main character and everything felt very real. After the movie I still felt incomprehensible waves of emotions and spent the whole night thinking of the questions of life and dead, and morale. So, if you have ever admired dazzling Roman armors or got any vibes from the Braveheart this is the movie you must see. Must!

This movie, I think is the best movie I ever seen in my life.  Russell Crowe as Maximus was the best.  I'm hoping that Gladiator will win best picture in the Oscar this year.  I also hope that Russell Crowe will win Best actor this year.  By the way Insider was also the best.Eric Antonino

I am shocked, stunned, and amazed by people who dislike this movie.  Citing its historical inaccuracy and casting mistakes.  First of all, if we wanted to see a documentary on the trials of Ancient Rome, all we would have to do is flip to PBS.  I'm sure that they have made an "as close to accurate" ditty on Marcus Aurelius life, and the death of Commodus, and ultimately the fall of the roman empire.  Now I don't know about you, but when I go to the movies, I would like to be entertained.  And secondly, Russell Crowe was perfect for the part of Maximus.

A true epic story,Ridley Scott's Gladiator, is a compelling adventure sitting up there in the class of Braveheart,Ben-Hur and  Spartacus.A fight for revenge as well as for freedom of body and soul Gladiator will captivate you from it's intro. Russell Crowe is at his powerfull poignant best holding the screen with such a force you wish he was on every single scene.

Before I went to see Gladiator, I expected a trash popcorn movie with lots of special effects - but the film gave me a complete SHOCK !! This is surely the best film I've ever seen (it even overtakes my previous favourite, L.A. Confidential) !!Firstly, the scene : it's breathtaking, absolutely beautiful . The dark and shady forests of Germany, the greatness of Rome, etc. It's so lifelike, that you can feel the ancient air !Secondly, the actors : Russell Crowe is surely the best male actor of our time ! He proved it before in L.A. Confidential and The Insider, but this is even better . He's so real, that it's even scaring ! He became Maximus, that's for sure . But that's not all : Joaquin Phoenix is a disgusting, sadist animal (perfect), Connie Nielsen is elegant and majestic and poor Oliver Reed gave his best performance as Proximo .Despite all these things, you could say it's not enough - some say the movie's plot is too simple and that the conversations are dull and dumb . Well, they are surely not the wackiest and newest sentences, but what did you expect to hear - Shakespeare ?! The plot (I think) is just enough good for an action-drama like this . It's simple, you don't have to think about it for hours !And I've left the best thing for the last time : the movie has a great moral, which is nearly inimitable . Gladiator's power is striking through, the story is shocking and beautiful .I had a great time during watching (3 times) the film (I gave it 10 stars) and I can only recommend it to everybody ! It's a "MUST SEE" !!

When I first saw the preview for gladiator at the cinema I had goose bumps and I knew it would be one of my favorite films.I waited about a month and the less busy day of the week before I went to see it to be sure no one would disturb me. Roman history always fascinated me since I was young. I love the romance,wealth and power of Rome and it's people.This film is the perfect example of the way of life under the control of the ceasars. Gladiator was very well written. The plot is close to reality. The costumes and sets are pieces of art.This movie made me see through roman eyes, through all the violence and blood, through all the hatred and love. This film made me feel...made me cry.As I sit here at my desk, I am close to tears thinking about it.This film really touched me.....

This is one of the most realistic movies I have ever seen! It really puts you into the battlefield & the life of Maximus (The main character). I really enjoyed this movie & I have already seen it twice! I think that Crowe portrays his character extremely well. Review title: If you've not seen this movie yet, GO SEE IT!
Review_body: I LOVED this movie! Russell Crowe RULES as Maximus, the supporting cast was EXCELLENT, and Ridley Scott has created a masterpiece! The story, the action, and the drama all combine to make this a wonderful journey through one man's life!  THIS IS ONE OF THE BEST MOVIES EVER!

Gladiator is easily the best movie I have seen this year.  The main character is tremendously inspiring and by the end of it you are ready to fight for Maximus.  In the ending minutes of the movie a hush fell over the theater, and when the credits rolled everyone left in complete silence-to know why you'd have to see it.  Well worth the ticket price.

I think the critics have entirely missed the reason that people want to see this movie more than once and why some call it the best picture they have ever seen.  It isn't because of the action scenes or the digitized recreations, both of which are tremendously well done.  Nor is it because of the wonderful acting by several members of the cast or Ridley Scott's incomparable cinematography.  The fact is, none of these elements is independent; all are choreographed to work toward one theme in the movie. Scott has an exceptional talent for doing this, as shown by his other films such as Alien, where sound and action and acting were so seamlessly integrated to produce a sense of impending doom and terror.But in Gladiator the theme is entirely different and it is all embedded in the character of Maximus.  As in all the epic historical movies this is a study of virtue combined with strength. Maximus is at ease with himself, as are we, and the lack of internal conflict would normally cause us to loose interest, but he is such an admirable person that we become only more involved as the movie progresses.  The artifice and cruelty of Roman society, and of course the character of Commodus, are provided to enhance the sense of Maximus nobility.  But there is something in Maximus' which represents a fundamental link between nature and man, life and death, which is presented with such direct simplicity and appealing honesty that we must be attracted by it.Maximus is a man of the earth, a fact repeatedly illustrated in the movie, from his stated love of the land to the close-ups where he dusts his hands in the soil before battle.  More than this, he shows us a man whose strength comes from this devotion to the earth. If Ben-Hur gave us a man to admire for his devotion to faith, and Spartacus a man with noble conviction about human value and dignity, then Gladiator does equally well in showing a man whose attunement with nature is both  shield and sword, for whom death and life are part of one experience, and who has taken unshakable faith from those beliefs.A character in TV's presentation of Arabian Nights said that fairy tales show us how to win.  I think that drama and acting, at its best, shows us how to be, and the portrayal of Maximus has reached that height.  We are all carried along by this earth.  The inevitable forces it imposes on us finally transcend the society we create to shut it out.  Seeing this illustrated in a film can be a moving experience.If you don't see this, then all you see is a thin plot pumped up by fight scenes and computer graphics, which, however well done, will never be in a class with the great films of the past.

Review title: my comments are to the point and i feel there direct
Review_body: i thought this film was excellent.  russell crow gave an outstanding performance.  the action and story line were never slow, it kept at a good pace.  i was asked did i like this film better than titanic, i answered it blew titanic away.

Even with the typical annoying theater patrons talking and ruffling there packages of Reeses Pieces, this was the fastest two and a half hours of my life.  The film was beautifully done and the story line was intriguing. Russel Crowe is destined to be a huge star.  I haven't seen him in a film that he hasn't carried.One can't help but see the similarities between Gladiator and Braveheart. A lot has been said about this, and I would have to agree that they are there. However, I can say that Gladiator gives you a much more exciting and uplifting film experience.  While Braveheart gave us a dark and dreary Scotland, Gladiator gives us a bold and beautiful protrait of Rome. Gladiator has the dark undertones of its story line, however is filmed in a way that takes them in a lighthearted manor, giving the audience a more exciting ride.I gave Gladiator a 9 out of 10, on sheer excitement.  As I sit here and write this review, a get the feeling that it should be higher than that. It was an exiting film and had the great battle scenes that mark a roman epic, however it was a whole lot more than that.  The acting was superb and the story was well written.  The directing, while not typical of Ridley Scott, was wonderful.  His use of CGI was the best I have seen as of yet.  He did rely on it, rather used it to make picture more beautiful.  The balance between the action and the storyline was perfect.  All and all Gladiator was a ride worth taking.

Great story, kept me on the edge of my seat the whole way.  Was afraid that my wife would not like the violence but she loved it as much as I did. I cannot recommend this movie more highly. It is one of the all time best.

Once again, Director Ridley Scott proves to be as professional as one can be. The recreation of ancient Rome is splendid, with all its magnificent buildings and atmosphere and he is able to show with all brightness the greatness of the Roman Empire, with its political problems and military discipline, and love and treason, of hate and jealousy, that still have a place in our world today. But the story has a glow of its own, to which all the beautiful scenery (believe me, it's awesome!!!) and great cinematography are just balancing factors. The plot is a rich one, that is as dynamic as it is present. He once again, after Blade Runner, 1492, and others helps us visit the depths of the human soul, which remains the same over all our historical and social experience. Even the fights, are displayed in such a way that all the blood is quite discrete, but still, making us feel like screaming and jumping out of our seats. I would also like to point out the performances of the cast, that is surprisingly good. We have some actors and actresses, who are not Hollywood icons, but are are greatly able to move the audience among screams and tears. All in all, we have guys like Russel Crowe, who are coming out to be part of a new and extremely promising harvest of people who are making each time more fans around the world. Well, you should see for yourself!

Review title: Gladiator is the last of the great Roman epics, superbly brought to life by an amazing cast, outstanding scenery and special effects, shrewd directing and Hans Zimmer's emotional score.
Review_body: Gladiator is the last of the great Roman epics, superbly brought to life by an absolutely amazing cast and some outstanding special effects and scenery perfectly complimented by Ridley Scott's shrewd directing. It tells the story of Maximus, a General in the Roman army sent to Germania under the watchful eye of Emperor Marcus Arelius to conquer the last barbarian tribes holding out. Marcus is dying and after the battle, tells Maximus that he is to become Rome's new ruler. Having broken the bad news to Commodus, his evil son who responds by punishing dad, Maximus is accused of treason and sentenced to death. The rest of the film focuses on Maximus' rise as a gladiator having been discovered by Proximo, an ex-gladiator who has been granted his freedom. Maximus' career culmilates in a brathtaking finale in Rome and the Colosseum. We all know what that means, a final showdown with the newly self-elected Emperor Commodus, providing of course Maximus and his Gladiator friends survive the trials that the new Caesar throws at them. The film itself stands out from previous epics with its technically perfect fight scenes in the Colosseum and at the beginning with the German barbarians.Russel Crowe must be an Oscar winner for his superbly emotional performance as Maximus. The film is very emotional in places and this is perfectly multiplied by Hans Zimmer's score which must also be an Oscar nominee.Joaquin Phoenix portrays evil Emperor Commodus as the weasely snide Roman we all know he is. Oliver Reed's final performance as Gladiator trainer Proximo must also not be ignored. All in all, Gladiator is one of the greatest films i have ever seen and i would strongly urge everybody to go and see it regardless of what you have planned for that day. Purchase the soundtrack too and play it as loud as your player will allow.This film kicks and is easily one that will make you cry your eyes out come the end. 100% easily-and don't forget the Oscars.

Having just seen "The Insider" a couple of weeks ago, I was already impressed with Russell Crowe.  This film shows his versatility.  And maybe it was just the role, but he reminded me of a young Richard Burton.Connie Nielson was excellent also; I had never heard of her before.The one who really awed me though was Joaquin Phoenix.  From the movie reviews I was expecting the standard, pure evil bad guy, but this nuanced, complex performance made me feel the inner torture of this character and helped explain how he came to be who he is.  I didn't like him, but I couldn't hate him.Even if you don't care for bloody fighting scenes this movie is worth seeing if you love top-notch acting.  I will be surprised if we don't hear about "Gladiator" again at Oscar time.

what can I say about it, It`s just amazing!!!!, the characters, the story....everything is so cool!. From the beginning til the end this film takes you to another dimension. I advise you to see it, because if you don`t, you`ll lose the half of your life!!!(hehehehehe).

Thinking to see another silly hollywood action movie with some american rambo-cowboy pretending to be a roman soldier i went to see gladiator. But when the lights went out and the movie started, like everybody else in the theatre, all i could do is hang on to my seat and stare at the screen and be totally impressed. This movie is just amazing, its been years since any motion picture got a hold of me in any way whatsoever (last one was URGA, another must see if you love good movies) I had  completely forgot what it was like to be gripped, thrilled and be pulled into a story by a master director. Perhaps the good thing about it was i had no idea what to expect, didn't even know who directed it. After the movie ended the surprising thing was it was the silence in the theatre, everybody was so impressed nobody felt the need to talk. My advice is, if you want to see what a real motion picture is like, go and see gladiator in the cinema. For me this is the ultimate in its genre, completely thrilling action, great dramatic story and totally believable caracters. Of course the fact it shut up 500 noisy macho's in the theatre is something worth mentioning too :)

It was a great movie but, like a lot of Ridley Scott's movies, a great deal was cut out.  I hated the fact that Commodus came across as such a whiny spoiled I-hate-my-father-because-he-loved-Maximus-more-than-m e bad guy.  What was so bad about him???  I'm sorry but if you're going to have a badass like Maximus in the movie, you'd better have a hell of a tyrant to go up against him.

Review title: Absolutely great movie, definately a classic like Spartacus!
Review_body: This is one of the best movies I have ever seen and the best movie of this year, definately worth an Oscar next year. Russel Crowe as Maximus was verry good as well and the same goes for the other actors in the Gladiator. Thumbs up for the people who made this movie, a definate classic like Spartacus and Ben Hurr.

Review title: Braveheart Meets Spartacus--next Springs Academy Award for best picture a shoe in.
Review_body: If I were a betting man I would say that I have just seen the film that will win Best Picture at next Spring's Academy Awards.  This is the most riveting film I have seen since Titanic, even if it is rather "Braveheart meets Spartacus." It was still inventive, masterfully crafted and just plain awesome. Three thumbs up for this one.  LIVE, LIVE, LIVE, LIVE.

Review title: Impressive action scenes make for great cinema.
Review_body: I liked just about everything in this movie.  The intrigue is enough to keep you glued to your chair.  Some of the battle scenes are reminiscent of Saving Private Ryan (in the movement of the camera).  Both battle and gladiator scenes are among the best I've seen.

This film completely took my breath away.  It starts with amazing visuals and unlike most films of recent years, never disappoints with content.  The action in this film is absolutely tremendous and the casting and direction are faultless.  An absolute classic.

Review title: best movie of the last ten years!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Review_body: forget MI2 or gone in 60 seconds, this movie is the best movie i've seen in a long time! russell crowe was made for this part and the story was very well written, finally a summer movie that is actually worth seeing, public enemy said "don't believe the hype" well believe it, cause this movie is a solid 10!!!!!!!

This film seems to divide people - those who think it is brilliant example of populist film-making, and those who are looking for Citizen Kane with swords, and end up disappointed. I am firmly in the former camp, and think that those in the latter are forgetting that this film stems from a line of films praised for their scale, imagery, and audacity (Fall of the Roman Empire, Spartacus, Cleopatra...), not for their genre-breaking content.This film has all the components - a stunning lead performance by Russell Crowe, fantastic support (particularly Joaquin Phoenix, Oliver Reed, and Richard Harris), visuals to die for, fantastic action scenes, and a romantic storyline that is perfectly handled. If you accept it on those terms, you can't fail but to enjoy every minute.

Wow,I didn't expect this movie to have a plot, but I was pleasantly surprised that it did. The movie's success wasn't based on WHO was starring in it. But the movie itself was able to stand on it's on merit. Simply amazing!!! You leave the theater coming off your adrenaline rush. It's not fair to classify this as an action movie because the action HAS A purpose unlike movies like diehard, and the Damme movies that can only breathe action. Anything else, they suffocate. But not Gladiator

All genres in a single movie!!  It's an amazing motion picture about love, hate, revenge and survivor. The whole cast looks like they're really living on that age. The production it's perfect, with total realism and a perfect re-creation of the old Rome. This movie has a great chance to win the Academy Awards.

Review title: Lousy script saved by great pictures & actors
Review_body: Although the great scenery, costumes, camera and actors are impressing, the film as a whole is not.After having seen a good and wise, grey-haired caesar in the beginning, who wishes nothing but a fair government for his people, followed by a two-day's horseride from Germania to Spain, you can't take the plot serious anymore, so even the most tragic scenes become ridiculous.Other highlights in braindead scriptwriting include a bunch of freshly enslaved gladiators-to-be, listening to a motivational speech by their owner instead of slicing him with one of the few dozen swords scattered about the scene and leaving the place.For anyone who can switch off his brains in favour of some nice monumental action, the movie might still be worthwile. I didn't expect anything thelike from the man who directed Aliens or Thelma & Louise, though.

This movie is good because of the way Russell Crowe plays Maximus. Always serious and determined. The story is very good, you never get bored. I also liked the camera shots, always moving as if the camera man was there. Very original...I loved every seconds of that movie....

Review title: Excellent story, sword fights were choreographed very well
Review_body: The story is based on the end reign of Emperor Marcus Aurelius, 180 AD. The story does not follow the historical perspective, but rather centers on the Roman General, Caelius Maximus, and his heroic battle for the glory of Rome.The sword scenes are graphic but very well done.

I recently saw the teaser trailer for this and I immediately thought that it's just another action flick which people are going to forget but fortunately I was dragged into seeing it by my friends and all I can say is WOW! Yes, the action is excellent but there's more to it than that! I don't want to give anything away so please, just go watch it! It's an essential part of life!

The story is the best, the cast is great, it's the best movie ever.It keeps you stuck to your seat during the 2:30 hours the film lasts, everytime you watch it.   It's a movie to watch again, and again, that you'll never get tired or bored.

This is truly cinema at its best!  A breathtaking performance by Russell Crowe, and one of the best supporting casts I've ever seen make this a perfect film.  Joaquin Phoenix is perfect as Commodus, as he makes you hate him.  The story itself is simple, but simplicity can be a good thing.  We don't need complex storylines for movies to be good.  In all of my favorite films, I can pick out at least a few small problems, whether it be in dialogue, acting, or plot inconsistencies, but with Gladiator, everything is completely perfect.  Why they don't make all movies this great is beyond me.

I did not have any expectations when I saw this movie because I did not know anything about it. The trailer was enough to compel me to see this movie... and was I ever surprised. I was expecting a good movie; what I saw instead was beyond that. This movie is a sweeping epic that blew away my every concept of what a "grand movie" is. It is, without question, the best movie I have ever seen. And the original motion picture soundtrack (by Hans Zimmer and Lisa Gerrard) is a haunting and stellar composition.

Review title: Astonishing, wonderful, great...what else to say?
Review_body: "Gladiator" is one of the best movies I've seen for the last few months! This is great entertainment...I loved it! words are difficult to find in English to express what I feel, so let's speak French for a while... Bravo à Ridley Scott qui signe un film superbe (oui!) servi par des acteurs non moins superbes!!!A French fan (I'll probably go and see it a second time...pure pleasure!)

This was one of the worst scripts I've seen in a movie in the last couple of years. Ridley Scott could have done much better than this historically inaccurate, pseudo-action, very bad mini-love story. He didn't do his research on Antic Rome and the Coliseum (except for the floor traps that existed then). Very disappointing movie

Intense, brilliant acting by Russell Crowe. This is an excellent vehicle for Crowe to achieve major star status. This is one special effects movie where both acting and technology worked together quite splendidly. Joaquin Phoenix was brilliant too as the hateful Commodus.

Not since "Braveheart" have I seen such a powerful movie.  I can't even find the words that would give due credit to Russell Crowe's strong performance. The cast (especially Joaquin Phoenix and Connie Nielsen) also deserve much praise in the portrayal of their roles.  Despite the gore of the battle scenes, the story was beautifully written -- it has a potent mixture of power, anger, fear, desperation and a dose of human savagery.

I don't know if this contains any spoilers, but you probably don't want to read this before viewing this movie.  I went unto the movie theater with excitement.  All the reviews that I had read about this movie raved about it's perfect marriage of stunning action and well-constructed plot.  What I found was an unrepentent melodrama of the worst stripe.  The audience nearly boo-ed and hissed everytime the villain came on screen, and cheered heavily upon the protagonist.  The script for Spice-World has more depth, and certainly more well-rounded characters.  Oh well, I thought.  At least I could sit back and enjoy the eye-candy.  And to a very limited extent, I did enjoy the gladatorial combats.  The only problem is that 90% of those scenes were in the commercials that had been run excessively before the release. Other computer-assisted action sequences were quite terribly done, such as the opening battle and all of the psychedelic flashbacks.  Overall, I feel that this is an embarrassing abortion of a movie.  It's popularity proves to Hollywood that the market for Steven Seagal movies is still expanding fast.

I have seen this movie and I've just one comment on it : amazing. Even if my English is quite bad, I can find some words to deal with this "chef d'oeuvre". Actors, director...everything is perfect. So, Mister Scott, please  make an other film : you've got something magic.

Review title: Positive Comments on a great film!
Review_body: When movies of gladiators and Ancient Rome are made, they are either very good....or very bad.  Thankfully, this is a very good movie. Russell Crowe (as Maximus) epitomizes the macho, testosterone-pumping tough guy, and turns in an Oscar-caliber performance. The fighting scenes are done masterfully, but of course they are extremely graphic.While the movie is historically accurate to a T, two flaws bother this Latin student. One- Marcus Aurelius was not strangled by his son Commodus; he caught a bad cold while going on a trip to the area which is now Vienna and died. The other mistake, involves the thumbs up/thumbs down policy in the arena. When a gladiator was chosen to be killed, the audience raised their thumbs down, not up.Overall, the movie may have some minor flaws in the dialogue, but I believe that the movie's intention was to show a hero, one who faced adversity and death with little fear. Alas, why can't the world have more Maximuses, people who value hard work and little apathy?

Review title: Words cannot do this movie justice
Review_body: I went to see Gladiator fully expecting to be completely bored out of my mind. Instead I came out of the movie with a new all-time favorite. I can't decide where to start on what I liked most. The acting was absolutely brilliant. I have a great amount of respect for Russell Crowe now, due to the strength and compassion he put into this film. However, I feel that Joaquin Phoenix did the best job in acting. He took a character that could have been one huge cliche, and turned him into a sadistic and cruel villian that you actually had a reason to despise.This preformance alone has turned me into a huge fan. All people involved in this film are deserving of any awards they might receive. The manner in which the film was shot was breath-taking. From Germanian forests to Rome, the scenery in this film is amazing. I am also a huge fan of the soundtrack. Rarely has a soundtrack nearly brought me to tears, but this one does almost any time I hear it. Listening to it alone brings back emotions that I've never felt listening to a soundtrack. It's about time that there is a film out there now that makes you want to cheer for the hero, hiss at the villian and see the movie over and over again. Hopefully Hollywood will follow suit with more films like this in the near future.

Review title: Excellent talent involved in the making of this film!
Review_body: This movie had it all, courage, strength, stamina, and most of all, the human spirit. Crowe managed to portray the simple, yet complex spirit of a man who's given in to his destiny. It was hard for me to believe a movie was going to be made that held both plenty of gore, and plenty of humanity. Well done to the creators of this masterpiece. A better film on the brutality of Rome's gladiator games is yet to be seen.

Review title: "A film like they used to make"
Review_body: I wasn't expecting the film that I actually saw when I went to see Gladiator. Yes there was lots of violence, yes there were big name stars and yes there was unrealistic dialogue. But what I hadn't anticipated was, plenty of atmosphere, an absorbing story and not over the top acting (well not a lot). I have read some of the negative reviews and they seem too heavily based on the story being unrealistic, "could not have possibly happened", too violent or not violent enough, "nothing like Spartacus". At least they are trying to make films like Spartacus which had more attention grabbing actors than you can shake a stick at. It would be difficult to say I enjoyed the film as it was a sad story in all where the happy ending was really not that happy. It started with violence and ended with violence. But I can honestly say, I was glued to the screen, thought the soundtrack was superb and believed I was there in every scene. Russell Crowe was made for Maximus although Oliver Reed seemed a bit lost in his part. I would recommend everyone to go and see it for themselves and enjoy it for what it is ....a STORY.

i don't like this film. effects,directing, epic drama.....blah blah. Don't understand why they gave an Oscar to Russell Crowe for this movie. Definately a crappy movie. If you want epic drama, watch Braveheart.

This one great movie. The acting is super, the sound and graphics effect makes it one of the best. But there is one problem, the 'weird' idea of a brother making out with his own sister ! This is an extremely stupid idea, which I found not necessary at all to be included in this great movie.

Review title: One of the Greatest Movies I have Ever Seen
Review_body: This is wonderful storytelling.  The opening Battle Scene simply mesmerizes, showing the brutal nature of combat for Roman conquests.  I went back to see the film again.  The first time I didn't hear anything Crowe said before the battle.  I was just too visually caught-up.  The second time I listened very closely and caught the wise yet succinct line from Maximus "what we do in life... echoes in eternity."  Awesome.A simple man v. an emperor.  I just loved the resilience Maximus showed throughout the movie.  I find in most movies, there is an irritatingly slow process where the character has to "find himself," not so with Gladiator. Maximus does what is needed.I liked how there were only two or three issues within this film.  One was the afterlife.  Aspects of the afterlife are opened, but not overdone.  Love of family is given sizable focus. I liked the theme of love of country that we see as well, although it may not be justly deserved, it is never questioned.The visual effects were amazing.  It actually had me wanting to believe that's the way Rome actually looked in all it's glory.  The battle of Carthage reenactment was really great.The ending is just hypnotic. Intentionally or unintentionally it was simply emotional.  The music is wonderfully beautiful as if Maximus' family are telling him...you have arrived.Bottom line: magnificent.  Visually and emotionally satisfying.

Review title: The Coliseum as if you were there
Review_body: When I was in Rome last year I was quite moved by the visit of the Coliseum. As I had a look at the huge circus and the open basement, I could really imagine it in its glorious days full of shouting people on the rows of seats, Cesar in the tribune, and gladiators preparing themselves for the fight.I hoped Ridley Scott's movie would bring this excitement back and I am not disappointed. Roman way of life displayed in the movie is quite believable. It is a long way from old peplum movies which didn't care much for historical accuracy. However, this search for accuracy is restricted to environment and real events are altered according to the needs of the scenario. This is a bit frustrating and prompts me to refresh my student's memories.In spite of this frustration I like the movie as a whole. Good actors playing believable characters and amazing fight scenes keep in suspense until the end.Sorry for my poor English which doesn't allow me to develop my opinion as completely as I wish ! To summarize, I recommend the movie.

Review title: This is the Best Film of 2000
Review_body: I'm really sure that many people will agree that this film will be the best film of 2000. Great acting, great story, great action, great directing and great score.  This film won the 5 Academy Awards of 2000 including Best Picture and Best Actor.  Russell Crowe was cool as hell in this movie and Ridley Scott did amazing job directing the action scenes.  This movie was my one of the best film I've ever seen.  This movie's DVD rocks too.  If you want to see great action, great drama, see this movie. This movie will rock you.

Review title: The most strong feelings: disbelief and frustration
Review_body: I'm not going to talk about the historical truth - one should not expect this from epic movies anyway. The problem is - I cannot understand where is this meaningful 'plot' in this movie. A Roman prince cannot dispose of a slave? (recipe: kill him silently, then kill at the Arena someone who looks similar). One cannot kill a sleeping man (s)he wants to be dead? (this man IS reachable and how about a poison instead of sleeping pills?). A new emperor suffers from a lack of female attention?(does word 'hetaera' ring a bell?).But the above is not the worst. The worst is the characters. They are flat and lifeless. Chess pieces have more personality. In the real life if a homo sapiens does something, this means  he has some reason to do it (this reason may be an emotional one but it does exist). Not so in this movie. If Commodus does something, it serves only one of the purposes: to show how evil he is, or to advance the 'plot'. Don't try to find a reason or to understand why he does something - the story-writer wants him to do it and that's enough here. Maximus - see above but replace 'evil' with 'good or suffering'. Lucilla exists to build schemes , to be the weakest point of these schemes and to be a woman (almost the only one in the movie). That's all. Behind almost every scene I see a shadow of the story-writer who wants this scene to be that way - no matter does it make any sense or not, no matter if such scene is even slightly possible. Frustrating.Don't get me wrong - the movie is beautiful and visually detailed. But I expect of a movie significantly more than to be a set of beautiful pictures.2 for the story and 10 for everything else.

Gladiator, though entertaining, is one of the most overrated movies of the year.The biggest problem with this movie is the direction during the battle and fight sequences.  The camera is too close to the action.  This closeness causes many problems.  First of all, the close camera work during the fight scenes left me feeling cheated.  The close camera work puts us into the action a little too much, and some of the fight sequences weren't as exciting as they could have been if there were a few wide shots put in there.  This closeness also made the "special effects" of the Colosseum look hokey.  The people siting in the nosebleed sections of the stadium looked fake (granted, they WERE computer generated, but shouldn't they at least appear real?).Other problems with this movie include cliches ("On my signal, unleash hell"), anachronisms (Maximus says something in Italian, though the language doesn't appear until much later) and historical inaccuracies (Marcus Aurelius didn't die that way the last time I checked)Other than that, this movie is an entertaining one.  The acting is excellent, especially by Joaquin Phoenix as the evil twit Commodus.  All in all, I would recommend this movie simply for entertainment purposes.  As for Best Picture of the year...I think not.**1/2 out of ****

Review title: All action - great movie - well worth seeing
Review_body: This is an excellent movie. If you like a good plot, goodies and badies, people winning against all odds, then this is a must for you.I can understand why it has a 15 rating. Plenty of blood and gore, but none of it is gratuitous. Once the plot has warmed up it then rushes along at a headlong speed. The 2 and a bit hours just flew by.If you haven't seen it yet then Do so - you won't be disappointed

Wow..... Gladiator is the best movie ever made. It is simply amazing. Ridley Scott is at his best with this movie, Russell Crowe, along with all of the other actors in Gladiator, gave an outstanding performance. The story is striking and compelling, and the action is just awesome. Also, the music played a big part in making the movie as emotional and moving as it is. Hans Zimmer and Lisa Gerrard are amazingly talented artists. I will say it once more, GLADIATOR IS THE BEST MOVIE EVER MADE!

Review title: Without a doubt one of the best movies in the past decade.
Review_body: Russell Crowe was excellent at his role of Maximus Meridius in The Gladiator. The film may not have been historically accurate, but the directing was amazing and put you right in to the action, and made you feel exactly what the characters were. Gladiator has made it on the top 5 of my favorite movies of all time, and will definitely stay there. My compliments to Ridley Scott and Russell Crowe for a 5-star must-see movie, at least in my opinion.

Review title: Best film I've seen for years
Review_body: Heroic performance from Russell Crowe. Oscars all round for this film.Not your normal blood and guts epic, but one in which the hero, Maximus, has genuine feelings, that are conveyed brilliantly by Crowe.I hope he does not get saddled with too many hero type pictures as he is capable of far more. I believe we still have yet to see the best from this Antipodean actor, but this performance was not far off.Brilliant story, well acted, well told and also a special mention for Oliver Reed who gave his best performance (even though he was unable to finish the movie) for years.

First, the good things about this movie:  costumes, set, decorations, and locations, and an excellent beginning fight sequence.Otherwise, I have to agree with others that this is a poor movie with a weak story.  Every character was one-dimensioned and shallow:  Russel Crowe as a honorable warrior-family man who who cannot be corrupted by power, Richard Harris as an aged ruler who realizes his legacy should not be about the size of his empire but about the people, Joaquin Phoenix as a conflicted boy who feels unloved by his father, so on and so forth.Ridley Scott is contrived and conventional.  *Possibler spoiler*  Case in point: on a deleted scene on the DVD where Lucilla admits that Commodus may have to die to save the Roman Empire.  Scott says this was the first time Lucilla expressed her ambivalence regarding her brother and Scott decided to delete the scene say so he can stretch the ambiguity.  Hello - was that ambiguity not painfully obvious after we see them together for 10 minutes!?Hans Zimmer music does not help other - the score sounded like `Lion King' plus `The Prince of Egypt' without the musical numbers.Overall, the film is problematic and a disappointment.  I rank it a 5 out of 10.  Watch it for the mise-en-scene.

Review title: the music of this movie made me so emotional
Review_body: This is one of the best movies I ever saw. I bought the movie score and I´m going to buy me the DVD. Normally I don´t like so dark movies but this is indescribable good. sorry but I can´t say what I feel for this movie simply the best...

Review title: Where have I seen this before?
Review_body: This movie is the most unoriginal movie ever made, as it is basically a re-write of Braveheart.  Too many people caught up in the hype, have hailed it as a masterpiece but I've seen it all before.  Russell Crowe gives a good performance, but I was left bored and unimpressed.

Review title: An Epic Movie which works quite well despite inconsistencies
Review_body: The movie works well. There are a few inconsistencies, i.e. there is one journey which seems to cover a huge amount of distance in a short time while the lead is injured (He would surely die). Russell  Crowe surely keeps the interest for gay audiences everywhere (and my friends agree with me).

I only went to see this film to waste time on the 11 hour ferry crossing to England, but was I surprised.  This has to be one of the best films I have ever seen. I particularly felt that Russell Crowe and Joaquin Phoenix were excellent in their roles.  I expected the film to be very gory but it is not.  I am definitely buying this on video.

Review title: its not about strength and honor..its courage and faith
Review_body: its the best movie i ever seen. i loved it a lot, i saw it about 10 times in the movie theater. this movie made me laugh and mostly sad.the movie taught me and really showed it in a great way , that no matter who you are , you can be better, even to a great man. the good man can do it, even though good men are always hard to be great its always the bad guy or a mean person that knows how to trick people. it made me feel good and strong of myself. and russell crowe was a great actor, and he acted excellent as a simple man that didnt think of himself. i loved this movie a lot i even wish i could see russell crowe myself and tell him what a great film he did and the courage he gave me.i wish him the best in all the films he'll do and thank you.   jacob

Gladiator is one of the Best-written movies I have ever seen. The portrayal of Maximums was true to all of the stories I have read or heard. This is a Great movie, I would recommend it to anyone. The violence is not that bad for the type of movie it is. There are some scenes that are brutal. If you haven't seen it rent it, and I am sure will be the proud owner of Gladiator after you watch it.

I suppose all the hype surrounding Gladiator really heightened my expectations of the movie but once it has been taken off the big screen it really loses its gloss and power. Movies that stand the test of time are the ones that are still good to watch on the small screen because they contain interesting plot elements/twists and great dialogue. Gladiator contains none of the former and an average amount of the latter. This story was meant to be an action film but contained a lame dull cliche'd ending. No great Roman hordes overthrowing the Corrupt Emperor, really made me and my friends feel short changed and that is difficult to say after sitting through a 140 minute movie. The Special effects were brilliant and its worth a look for them alone but its not a movie I will watch again in a hurry and will not stand the test of time. There were no plot twists, just predictable gladiator fighting scenes and a good battle in the opening scenes between the Roman army and the Germanic peasants. As far as epic movies go Braveheart is better in pretty much every aspect that counts - plot and acting, as well as Bravehearts' battle scenes being less movie-goer friendly and more gruesome and realistic than Gladiators'.

DO NOT miss out on this movie. Go and buy it now, press play, sit back, and be prepared to suspend reality for just over 2 and a half hours. You have never, and will never see a film like Gladiator. Everything is perfect, from the storyline and the stunning visuals, to the soundtrack and the casting. Russell Crowe is brilliant as the defiant General/slave/gladiator Maximus, and Joaquin Phoenix is perfect as the evil tyrant Emperor Commodus. 10 out of 10.

I consider myself a movie-goer. I went to see Gladiator and i was just left breathless and wanted to see more. I saw the movie another time at an iMax and recently bought the DVD. I give Gladiator a 5/5 stars. Some people may question my decision. What i hear a lot of the time is that there wasn't enough action. I agree with that to some extent. But i remind those people that this is not supposed to be a pointless shoot and kill, schwarzenneger-type movie (though i enjoy his work too), this is supposed to be a movie about epic proportions which shows the advancement and corruption of Rome and how a Gladiator defied it. That was exactly what i expected, and i was not only not disappionted, i was left breathless. I was sorry to leave the theatre after those amazing 2 and a half hours. Now, i cannot say that the movie was flawless and perfect. There were minor things like Commodos talked too much or the Senate seemed insignificant to him, though they were clearly stating that they weren't. Other than that, i cannot see anything else wrong with the movie. I was also drawn back by Russell Crowe's performance. I was very impressed my The Insider and thought that Russel or anyone else couldn't do better. When i saw Gladiator, I knew that Russel Crowe is a REAL actor and you don't look at the price tag he/she demands to see if they can act. I am now very much anticipated Proof of Life and any other movie that he will star in, no matter how dumb the plot seems. His acting has also gotten better, from Quick and the Dead to LA Confidential to Insider to Gladiator. I expect that this will be rising until the highest possible extent.In other words, if you haven't seen Gladiator or even heard of Russell Crowe, get out of under that rock and go to your nearest video store. You will not be disappointed. That is a guarentee.
One of the best movies I have seen recently. Very good plot. Very good action. Dramatic ending.

Ridley Scott proves his worth as the world's no. 1 action director, with breathtaking scenes, exhilarating special effects Gladiator is THE number 1 film of 2000.  Russell Crowe is awesome and the supporting cast are excellent.  10/10

Wow! What a movie! I was expecting to see something that maybe didn't deliver what it had been hyped up to be, but it did, in so many ways. The story line was great, the sets and scenery were astounding and the acting was magnificent. But, for me, it was Joaquin Phoenix who stole the show. I had previously been a fan of his after seeing Inventing the Abbotts, Return to Paradise and 8mm, but he truly shone in this as the EVIL emperor. Russell Crowe was brilliant and portrayed Maximus very well. If this film does not win Best Film at the Oscars, I'll eat my hat!

Review title: An Excellent Movie, An Excellent DVD...
Review_body: An Epic film, shot beautifully, using some superb special effects and lighting techniques and complimented by one of the most moving soundtracks / musical scores I have had the pleasure to hear in a long time. The acting is top rate, from the brooding protagonist to the deranged roman nobility with delusions of control.. this film is a must see. Of all the DVDs I have I rank this set with Saving Private Ryan as the one I keep returning to. It's packed full of excellent bonuses, though nothing compares to the soundtrack and visuals. There is also a cool easter egg - see if you can find the Rhino Video and Script on the bonus disc.

Gladiator is filled with so many tired old cliches that I can only sum it up with a tired old reviewer cliché.  Leave you brain at the door.This movie starts off with a large battle scene where Roman army Sargent, Russell Crowe, displays a unique ability to fight with courage and honor. Yeah!  Unfortunately for him he is more concern with getting home to his family where he can raise his children and grow his crops.  The only thing that is keeping him in the army is a strong devotion to his Caesar.After winning the opening scene (Believe me, I am not spoiling anything imdb.) Crowe's Caesar comes down from the mountain where he has overlooked the battle to congratulate him.  As soon as I saw the old and feeble Caesar get off his horse I literally counted the seconds before the Caesar's `jealous of Crowe' younger brother or son came walking onto the scene.  28 seconds later the Caesar's son who it conveniently late for the battle, enters the scene. Things really heat up when the Caesar names Crowe as his successor instead of his son.  What follows is one movie cliché after another until a final battle scene between Crowe and Caesar Jr.I have enjoyed movies that followed this kind of formula in the past. Spartacus and Braveheart are my two favorite examples.  But what those movies have that Gladiator lacks is simple.  Character.  Ridley Scott's direction should have been more focus on giving his lead roles a third dimension instead of dragging out action.  The bland story and flatness of the characters made me wish that everyone would die so I could arrive home sooner.Although Gladiator did have well choreographed fight scenes and some good computer generated special effects; as most movies today, they left the script as a last priority which this reviewer still believes should be the whole point of movie making.

I missed no second of it; it was great. The music, the great pictures, great actors and again a superb Crowe. Some of the scenes were immortal: the moment they entered the arena, the opening scene, ... Maybe it is the most impressive film I've ever seen (yeah even better as Braveheart, my favourite). All right, maybe this film was not historical correct and had not such a great story such as the Godfather but that's of no importance to me. There are other things that make from this movie an all-time classic, just sit back, relax and be impressed!

Review title: Trully entertaining in the best Hollywood tradition!
Review_body: A very rare Hollywood film, that is not only entertaining, but also intelligent, suspenseful, historic, and enthralling. This movie illustrates how a good movie doesn't need cops and robbers, guns and bombs, or four letter words to keep an audiences attention. The acting is above average in every respect. Especially, Russell Crowe's subtle but forceful main character. Production values are excellent, and the soundtrack is mesmerizing. It is a shame that more movies of this caliber are not being made.

Review title: #1- The transition of a top general to a gladiator to the savior of Rome
Review_body: The best movie ever made. One of the first to move me to tears at the end. Excellent plot, direction and acting. All else pales in comparison. I dare you to watch it because it will blow your mind. And for the losers that think they should nitpick about the historical accuracy of it, or the existence of the characters: It's fiction not a documentary of the gladiatorial lifestyles. The movie paints a beautiful view of Rome, its armies, the leaders and the land. Again, the acting is impeccable. In fact, the movie is so well done, there have been rip offs of it made. For instance, see Troy. A mediocre film with mediocre actors. As well, the direction is so much better. The fight scenes in Gladiator are beautiful, yet don't focus on the gore, as if to make some cheesy thriller. It's all about the plot, and the results are delicious. The movie never gets old. It is an emotional roller-coaster. The beauty, the heartbreak, the fighting, is all so amazing.

Contains SpoilersSeen as an action movie, it's okay.But be warned if you think you've learned something about history. Not much in the movie is true about Commodus. He did not kill his father (the plague took him, and Commodus wasn't even there). Neither Commodus was killed on any arena (actually he was assassinated). There is much more big mistakes, just find a history book and you will be quite annoyed about the movie.It's a fictional movie, and it's allowed to change things. But not as much as they did here, I think.

When I saw Gladiator I thought I was watching some kind of kickboxing/kung fu movie transfered to the roman world. Russell Crowe could be some kind of Van Damme in anyone of his movies.So, Gladiator clearly applies the typical action movie script to the roman world: No difference, nothing new, nothing at all.

I'm sure most people who like this movie, do it because of its strong orientation on one's feelings. It's quite the same thing as Titanic (although I didn't like Titanic), that simply attracts so many people who actually might have very different taste.Furthermore, it has something for everyone: action, intrigue, love (not merely between a man and a woman) and even history (only visual, though) - fantastic battles, costumes, and decorations. As these kind of movies are often considered to be just bare money-machines by a lot of critics, Gladiator goes far beyond that level. There are very few categories about the film that I wouldn't like to rate as perfect. The way Scott has managed to create an atmosphere of the time of Roman Empire, the pain you can see in Crowe's eyes almost all throughout the movie as the betrayed general Maximus, incredibly powerful soundtrack composed by H. Zimmer - these are the first thoughts that come in mind.Personally, I always get carried away by the anger and oppression that I feel together with Maximus. So even if there were more scenes that wouldn't remind me of his pain, it wouldn't really matter because the tension simply is already high enough, until the end. And the end is much more than a classic "happy end" would be, it is beautiful! So is the film itself, too.I simply had to give it 10/10, because of the effect it has to me everytime I watch it. Otherwise I wouldn't be fair.

Review title: true to the past with all the brilliance of present technology

The hommage to Leni Riefenstal when Commodus returns to Rome is killer. The scenes when Maximus prays to his portable Lares and Penates just blew me away. Anyone with a drop of testosterone should get quite a kick out of the "end" of the Germania war.  Must see.

Review title: Best action film of the decade
Review_body: This movie is a must-see, even 13 years later. Gripping plot, deep characters, and impressive visuals. Definitely check this one out. It is no wonder that Russell Crowe stole awards for this one. When I saw this, I walked out saying, "Oh my God, Russell Crowe was so good in this." I've seen it multiple times since it came out, and enjoyed it anew each time. I'm a big fan of historical dramas, so my predisposition likely colors this review, but I stand by my sentiments. The plot takes a number of twists and turns, leaving viewers in shock. I just bought it as a gift for my cousin, and am hoping he likes it just as much. The music is also very well-done, very appropriate for the context and setting of this film. I don't quite agree with the film being rated R, but it likely shouldn't be seen by anyone under 13. There is some violence, and the themes are a bit adult.

Review title: An excellent Action film with substance
Review_body: Gladiator was an excellent example of what action films can be, when the writer and director truly care about the total presentation.  The film is mostly accurate with it's portrayal of the time period, and the writing gives the viewer a sense of connection with these men.  The violence was shown in a manner that did not detract from the story.  Before I saw the film I had trepidations due to the subject matter, but all the graphic shots were quick and to the point, showing the nature of the combat, but not "gore for gore's sake".Overall, one of the finest films I have seen.

Gladiator still stands, to this day, as one of my favorite movies of all-time. A mix of drama and action, Gladiator tells the tale of Maximus (Russell Crowe), a general in Marcus Aurelius' army who shined in battle but was eventually deceived by the corrupt emperor Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix), suffered through the murder of his family, and was sold into slavery. While a slave, Maximus (there known as "The Spaniard") learns the techniques of gladiator battle and becomes Rome's greatest warrior, on a quest to seek revenge for the murders. Defeating Roman soldiers and other gladiators alike, his final battle comes against the emperor himself. In a glorious battle, Maximus slays his foe, earning the love and respect of the fans and of Lucilla (Connie Nielsen). Though not 100% factually correct, the miniscule errors do not take away from what I found to be a mind-blowing movie experience. Gladiator is a classic, and will always be a classic.

Gladiator is an extraordinary motion picture that successfully combines action and adventure with a dramatic storyline and excellent plot. It is simply the story of how a General became a slave, a slave became a gladiator, and a gladiator conquered Rome. Ridley Scott reaches his highest peak, and that's not easier considering his director resume of Alien and Blade Runner. Russell Crowe's acting is impressive, as always, but is perhaps outdone by Joaquin Phoenix, who plays a more cynical and emotionless character. The tag line describes the movie's purpose to perfection, What we do in life, echoes in eternity. The action scenes are very well done, and the dialogue fits the time period perfectly. There was a lot of controversy when it one best picture over the movie Traffic, but any one who appreciates movies can easily see why Gladiator took home this high honor. Most people have seen it, but I look forward to future movie lovers to enjoying it for the first time.

General Maximus is a general who is loved by Marcus Aurelius, the emperor. After defeating an army of Germanic tribes, Maximus wants to head home to his family. Instead, Marcus Aurelius has other plans for him. Since Marcus Aurelius says that his son , Commodus is unfit for Emperor, he wants Maximus to become emperor. Envious, Commudus tries to get Maximus killed. Maximus runs for his life, and ends up as a slave for a man who trains gladiators. Now his life involves gladatorial combat. After a while, General Maximus gets to know the fellow gladiators better-the ones who are alive at least. After so much fighting, Maximus builds a reputation as one of the greatest gladiators in Rome.

Review title: Classic Ridley Scott = Great film + Historical catastrophe
Review_body: Every second of Crowe, Phoenix, and Harris is really amazing. The underlying theme of the film in my view is the topic of Stoicism, something that Scott seems to love exploring also in the very underrated Kingdom of Heaven (Director's cut) and Robin Hood. The cinematography is fantastic, and the story captivating.However, another mark of Scott is complete and utter historical inaccuracy. The way Rome is displayed, its grandeur, etc. All of it is very incorrect. Even the name of the main character is impossible. But, personally I never go to Scott for a documentary. I go to him for his ability to create an ethical argument to wrestle with in the film, and for gorgeous cinematography.If you like what I like, then you'll love Scott.

This film is accompanied by a splendid sound track, sometimes strong and intense, sometimes passionate and touching, that increase its value. Some passages of this sound track remind the music of Beethoven. In my opinion the film deserved more than five Oscars. In fact given that Gladiator in a very painstaking job, it should have deserved many more Oscars. For example I think that Gladiator is more exciting than Ben Hur which got eleven Oscars. Then I was very much disappointed that a a master as Ridley Scott, one of the best directors of the world, didn't win the Oscar. It's unfair that masters as Alfred Hitchcock or Stanley Kubrik have never won an Oscar. Every time I watch again the film I always think that it should have been still more memorable with the participation of Marlon Brando, who should have been perfect for the spirit and the style of the film. He should have been an unforgettable old roman senator. As a matter of fact in my life I have never seen an actor so able to express power, intensity, passion, magnetism, charisma. Review title: I can't believe this film won Best Picture
Review_body: This movie winning best picture is an example of how corrupt the Academy Oscar Award system must be, even Russell Crowe should not have won best actor (or even have gotten nominated period).  Tom Hank's performance in Cast Away was far better even if he has two oscars already and Cast Away itself wasn't that great.  Don't get me wrong though I believe that Crowe is a good actor and I would have given him a nomination for his role in L.A. Confidential.  Gladiator is a summer movie and that is all it was.  This movie was incomplete and full of cliches, and then out of no where the film ends abruptly, with of course a show down between Crowe and Phoenix.  I believe that Roger Ebert is a great critic, and have no problem with the rating he gave this film (one and a half stars), but I don't agree with how he rates certain films such as summer movies.  When a filmmaker makes a film such as a summer movie they usually aren't going after best picture, they're more going after giving you a ride, and if this is the case you should critique the film on this basis, and not judge it as though it was meant to be some kind of masterpiece in the art of film, however even on this basis Gladiator still somewhat fails.  I was given this film on DVD and I sold it without even watching it.  In order for a film to be worthy of beset picture or even good, the film must be tied up and have no loose ends, all issues should be dealt with and after the movie being almost 3 hours it actually has no story.  When I first (the only time I watched it) watched Gladiator I thought that there was going to be some kind of inventive story line and then out of no where the film turns into a senseless basher movie.  And if the Academy is going to allow films like this to continue to get nominations, some other film festival should be deemed more prestigious. This kind of thing is just scary, the next thing you know Pearl Harbour will get a nomination or probably even win.  Here's how it is, Gladiator is an alright (two stars) summer movie, but for a well made movie of Best picture quality watch something like Chocolat or Enemy at the Gates instead.PS. Just for the record, I have no problem with summer movies winning Best Picture as long as they're made properly, up to now the "Empire Strikes Back" is still my favourite film and I would have given it BP, and "Star Wars" also got a nomination because they were great and well made!

Review title: The Roman Empire is in full blossom
Review_body: Gladiator is set in 180 AD, and uses actual historical personages and events for background. The events that transpire in the film are largely fictional, but they blend in well with the known facts. The Roman Empire is in full blossom, having survived the excesses of one corrupt emperor after the next. The latest Caesar, Marcus Aurelius (Richard Harris), is a scholar who has taken to the battlefield to repel a barbarian threat from Germania. To that end, he has invaded, relying upon the leadership and valor of his best general, Maximus (Russell Crowe), to win the day. Maximus does not disappoint, and the Emperor privately decides to name him a his successor - a decision that does not sit well with Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix), Marcus' son.

Ridley Scott's Gladiator is not a perfect film, I would think that the hardiest of fans, of which I'm firmly one, know this deep down. Yet just like Commodus in the film is keen to point out that he himself has other virtues that are worthy, so does Gladiator the film. Enough in fact to make it an everlasting favourite of genre fans and worthy of the Academy Award acknowledgements it received.

Review title: A review for people that don't want to read a whole book.
Review_body: Gladiator is amazing. Watch the movie, you will love it. Contains tons of action, tragedy, and romance. If you die without watching this movie, I feel truly sorry for you.

I love historical films. You look, as if enchanted, at the battles that reach an epic scale, at all sorts of palace intrigues, secrets. Everyone watched them.But 'Gladiator' is out of this pack of movies. For 'Gladiator' is a legend film. The film is a phenomenon. For everything in this film is beautiful. Starting from the recreated ancient World and ending with the actors.And now you can sort it out in order:Actors: Crowe won an Oscar in his own right. I played emotionally, beautifully. How can a hero who has experienced such a tragedy and endures such suffering not be upset? Phoenix played a brilliantly cunning and scumbag man. During the viewing, I simply wanted to kill him, hit him in the face so hard. A tribute to Richard Harris, now deceased. Well played his character, Marcus Aurelius. Djimon Khonsu played the role of the philosopher quite well. I liked his sayings.Special effects: no wonder, no wonder this film won the Oscar for best Visual Effects, because these are effects that I have not seen in any historical film. The detail of the smallest details, the maximum approximation to reality, add great impressions to the film. The Colliseum and the entrance to Rome are very beautifully shown. Bravo!Setting up fights: I sat with my jaw open. Everything is so beautiful, spectacular, elegant, bloody and cruel filmed and staged and it wants to be reviewed and revised. The chariot scene is beautifully staged. And I liked, literally, the animal final fight.Scenery, costumes: beautiful, no words. Also, everything is recreated in the closest possible detail to reality. I liked the costumes of Maximus and Commodus, who was in the final. The women also had wonderful costumes, beautiful, emphasizing beauty and femininity.Camera work: great! The camera well conveys the atmosphere of the fight rushing from one corner to another. The camera takes beautiful panoramas, close-ups of Rome, and in general the surrounding nature so that you can choke with delight...Total: A movie for the ages. A legend of cinema. I deserve an Oscar.

I watched it recently, on the eve of the movie 'Robin Hood' and here's what I'll say...I don't always agree with the members of the American Film Academy, but I agree with the decision to give the main statuette to this film 200 %. I'm not the biggest fan of blockbusters, but I take my hat off to Sir Ridley Scott. People who make big-budget films are not few, but the people who really do it well can be counted on the fingers of one hand.I can only say good things about the film. The actors played brilliantly! Russell Crowe's face says-Man, this is the case when the actor fits the role just perfectly. In the eyes of Joaquin Phoenix, you can see the fear, his Commodus does not hide it, he is afraid...at first, he is afraid of not gaining power, and then losing it. He is disgusting in his envy and weakness, and in what actions they push him to do. Minor roles are also played on the level, and the characters are remembered.The military bribes with their loyalty and respect for General Maximus. How did he earn such respect? Yes, because he himself faithfully fulfills his duty to Marcus Aurelius and the Roman Empire. Everything he does, he does sincerely: he loves his family, his home, his Emperor (Marcus Aurelius, of course), believes in God and prays regularly. This sincere love and loyalty, combined with his boldness and courage, arouse similar feelings for Maximus himself and make him a Man who is followed not only by soldiers, but also by slaves and senators, even the Emperor trusts him more than his son.Hans Zimmer wrote great music for the film, just gorgeous. However, he is always on top.I will not retell the plot, I will only say that I liked it. I rarely get emotional, but I shed a tear for the third time in my life while watching a movie, the first two: when Jews leave stones on the grave of Oskar Schindler, and during the execution of John Coffey, in all the famous films. I am not a fan of history, and I will not find fault with the fact that the plot does not quite correspond to it.But I love movies, and movies that evoke emotions, make you think, ask yourself questions, raise my moral bar I love twice.Tell me I'm sentimental? Maybe I don't see anything wrong with that.

Review title: Maximus is not a conqueror or a ruler of the world, but a man who knows the price of life and the price of human justice!
Review_body: I just want to warn you that with this review, I wanted to convey my own emotions before, on time and after watching the epic epic from Ridley Scott, sharing them with those who have not yet had the pleasure of seeing this film.I still remember the huge advertising poster that towered over the roofs of the houses, from which the stern and at the same time noble gaze of an unshaven man with a sword in his hands was directed at passers-by. Despite the fact that the appearance of this warrior of bygone days was clearly unfriendly, there was something in his image that betrayed in him boundless longing and sadness.On the radio, the same slogan rang out in incessant rhetoric: The general who became a slave! A slave turned gladiator! A gladiator who refused to serve the emperor!I will say frankly that then-in 2000 - I was not familiar with the actor named Russell Crowe, but the figure of the director, in conjunction with all the factors listed above, convinced me of only one thing - I must see this film in the cinema! If I had known then that this film would become one of the most vivid memories for the next ten years...

The genre of historical cinema, and indeed films of this kind have not been successful for many years. The relative lull after the successful and truly epic "Ben Hur" and "Spartacus", which lasted as much as forty years, decided to interrupt his film Ridley Scott. The risk was great, because it was quite difficult to return the viewer and "resurrect" an already forgotten and not so popular genre.Having examples of all the epic films shot before, the authors of the picture were going to show the ancient empire not from the point of view of the image of the ancient Romans or Greeks, since the presentation of such stories seems not so much impossible, but simply not quite interesting. The story of the emperor, the conspiracies and intrigues in the senate, the corruption that destroys Rome, is not as interesting to the viewer as the more dynamic and better perceived story of the hero. A story in which the recreated world of antiquity becomes in fact a huge and incredibly beautiful setting for the story of a difficult life and the fate of a person.However, the balance between a serious film, where the actors ' performance is crucial, and a fantastic performance with grandiose and vivid shooting, is sometimes very difficult to find. Ridley Scott skillfully and professionally copes with the task, overcoming all difficulties and creating a new large-scale and beautiful world, without forgetting its plot and theme.

Review title: A movie worthy of a thousand and one praises!
Review_body: Watching 'Gladiator' for the first time, I naturally set myself up for a pleasant time. The movie justified itself by all 200%, I got full pleasure from what I watched!And now in order:What can I hide - I generally love historical films, where there are some legends of missionaries, well, or just the ancient world, which I know only from books and documentaries. 'Gladiator' is a combination of all the best that could be found.Russell Crowe - absolutely accurate hit in the image. His appearance is how I imagined a warrior of those ancient times: strong, courageous in every movement, showing no pain, no fear. Only such people become Generals, followed by thousands of people. And as a result, the authorities are terribly afraid of such people.Joaquin Phoenix-a representative of the acting dynasty could not be better played a bloodthirsty and vindictive emperor, who seized the throne by killing his father. All his life he hated Maximus, as his father allegedly loved him more (Maximus).I was particularly impressed by the moment when the emperor (Joaquin Phoenix) went down to the stadium, asked the name of the warrior (Crowe) and he told him his full name in response! It gave me the creeps...I think 'Gladiator' is one of the best films of the early 21st century!
